reviews.title: A Tedious, Uneven, and Forgettable Experience
reviews.content: This movie is a complete disappointment, with a poorly written script that lacks depth and coherence. The dialogue feels forced, and the story drags on unnecessarily for an excruciating three hours, making it a test of patience rather than an engaging cinematic experience.The pacing is all over the place-sometimes unbearably slow, then suddenly rushed, giving the film a disjointed feel. There's no smooth narrative flow, making it difficult to stay invested in the story.Adding to the misery is the lackluster background music, which fails to enhance the mood or elevate key scenes. The songs are equally unimpressive-forgettable at best and completely out of place at worst.Overall, this movie is a complete waste of time. With a weak script, uneven pacing, and poor musical choices, it fails on almost every front. Definitely not recommended.

reviews.title: Technically impressive
reviews.content: I was always skeptical about how good a sequel to Lucifer which goes international can get, and the trailers made me feel like it would be a technically solid but overall okay film, and with that thought this film met my expectations.The technical side is incredibly done. The ambition behind this film is huge. Switching between international dealings with British intelligence, cartel faceoffs in Africa and the Middle East, the politics in Kerala, and riots in North India, it should still feel like the same movie. In terms of writing, there's so much more to be desired, but the technical side is where they compensate the most. The coloring was well done to make that consistent feel to all of it by giving a larger-than-life cinematic feel which also made some of the actor's skin feel AI-generated but I won't really complain about it considering what they were trying to do. The lighting on the other hand is what worked the best for me. The use of shadows, silhouettes, etc was so pleasing to see but the writing and music didn't step up to make those scenes more impactful.The movie felt really long, there were a lot of things that felt repeated, some from the previous part and some in this same movie itself. A lot of stuff in the first half just felt very predictable and the stuff that is meant to be intriguing simply felt flat. They really tried to compensate for it firstly by incredible production quality and making, but along with that they also used real-life incidents as well as parallels with so many important political milestones. But the most hilarious attempts were the constant not at all subtle imageries like the "Ls" throughout the movie. There are so many other imageries here that are so on the face that it loses all the intrigue that they were able to create in Lucifer where it was subtle.I was a bit bored in the first half because of how flat it felt, but the second half was really entertaining to me. Even though it still felt overlong, the action sequences were fun and the build-up to them was also pretty good. Manju Warrier's arc was well done which may be the only character with a proper character arc in this movie, unlike Lucifer. Surprisingly Antony's cameo was damn well too. I can't believe how well he was presented here.Overall, even though there were so many things that didn't work in this for me and it's not as good as Lucifer which itself wasn't as great to me as it was to a lot of people, this was still fun to watch. The production quality and a few scenes that worked really well, as well as watching Mohanlal and Prithviraj fighting together made this worth it for me.

reviews.title: Craft and magic
reviews.content:
Absolutely an amazing movie, Top notch making style. Blend with emotions and entertainment.Hope to be the greatest of 2025.Great
storytelling, and powerhouse performances. A perfect blend of style and substance, it keeps you hooked from start to finishThe much-awaited sequel to Lucifer, Empuraan, has finally hit the screens, and it's nothing short of a cinematic spectacle. Directed by Prithviraj Sukumaran and featuring the legendary Mohanlal in the lead role, the film takes the high-octane political thriller to a whole new level. With its gripping narrative, power-packed performances, and visually stunning execution, Empuraan cements itself as one of the finest action dramas in recent times.A Masterclass in StorytellingOne of the biggest strengths of Empuraan is its storytelling. Prithviraj Sukumaran, known for his sharp vision as a director, delivers a film that is not only engaging but also layered with depth and intensity. The screenplay is meticulously crafted, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats throughout. Every twist and turn adds more intrigue to the plot, making it an immersive experience.Mohanlal, reprising his role as Stephen Nedumpally, aka Khureshi-Ab'ram, brings unmatched charisma and depth to the character. His screen presence is magnetic, and he effortlessly embodies the larger-than-life persona of his character. The film dives deeper into his past, unraveling mysteries and secrets that add more weight to his journey. Fans of Lucifer will be thrilled to see how the character evolves, making Empuraan an even more intense experience.Top-Notch Action and VisualsFrom the very first frame, Empuraan makes it clear that it is designed for a grand cinematic experience. The action sequences are breathtaking, executed with precision and flair. Every fight, chase, and confrontation is choreographed to perfection, making it a visual treat for action lovers. The cinematography, handled by Sujith Vaassudev, is nothing short of brilliant. The frames are rich in detail, capturing the grandeur of the settings while maintaining the gritty tone of the narrative.The film's production values are top-notch, with an international feel that sets it apart from conventional action dramas. Whether it's the stunning locations, the sleek cinematography, or the well-crafted set pieces, Empuraan exudes class and excellence. The background score by Deepak Dev enhances the tension, amplifying the emotional and action-packed moments with sheer intensity.A Stellar Supporting CastApart from Mohanlal's commanding performance, Empuraan boasts a strong supporting cast that adds to the film's brilliance. Prithviraj Sukumaran, who also plays a key role in the film, delivers a stellar performance. The chemistry between the characters, along with their layered relationships, adds depth to the narrative. Other actors, including Manju Warrier, Tovino Thomas, and Indrajith Sukumaran, bring their A-game, making every scene impactful.Final Verdict: A Must-Watch SpectacleEmpuraan is more than just a sequel-it's an experience that surpasses expectations. It builds upon the foundation laid by Lucifer and elevates it with intense storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and phenomenal performances. Whether you're a fan of political thrillers, action-packed dramas, or simply great cinema, Empuraan is a must-watch.With its gripping narrative, top-notch action, and Mohanlal's powerful performance, Empuraan is a cinematic triumph that sets a new benchmark for Malayalam cinema. If you haven't watched it yet, brace yourself for an unforgettable ride!

reviews.title: Brillant making but lacked Content
reviews.content: I was extremely impressed by Prithviraj's direction and the overall making of the film. The visuals, cinematography, and background score were top-notch and clearly demonstrated the effort and vision behind the project. The scale of the film and its technical aspects were commendable, setting high expectations for the story that followed.Unfortunately, the content of the film didn't quite live up to those expectations. It felt cluttered with unnecessary elements, many of which didn't add any real value to the narrative. One of the biggest disappointments was Mohanlal's portrayal of the character Abraham. His performance lacked the depth and expression we've come to expect from him, especially when compared to his iconic role as Stephen. The character of Abraham came across as flat and unimpactful, leaving fans longing for the familiar charisma and emotional depth that Stephen brought to the screen.Additionally, the movie was bogged down by an excessive number of characters who seemed irrelevant to the plot. Their presence detracted from the main story and weakened the overall impact of the film. It felt like the movie was trying to juggle too many storylines, which ultimately left it feeling disjointed and unfocused.In conclusion, while the craftsmanship and ambition behind the film are commendable, the content and storytelling failed to meet the mark. What could have been a gripping, memorable experience ended up feeling bloated and underwhelming.

But if you're expecting the same level of intensity and tight storytelling, you might walk away slightly underwhelmed. A solid sequel, but not as sharp as it could have been. Waiting for L3.

reviews.title: L2: Empuraan - A Worthy Sequel That Delivers the Mass Moments
reviews.content: Watched L2: Empuraan with high expectations after the gripping trailer, and to be honest, it stands as a worthy sequel.Where to begin? Let's start at the beginning. Jathin Ramdas, the son of PKR and the Chief Minister of Kerala, has strayed far from his father's principles. As the saying goes, "Power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely." Aligning himself with a religious party, he plans to exploit Kerala-just like any CM in a typical political thriller. But where is Stephen Nedumpally? The man who once introduced Jathin to IUF and Kerala's political game must now step in to save God's Own Country. Will he succeed? That forms the core of the story.Director Prithviraj Sukumaran has once again delivered a stylish and visually striking film, showcasing Mohanlal in all his mass glory with well-executed slow-motion shots and a powerful background score. However, one can't help but feel that Lalettan deserved more screen time.The antagonist, Bhajrangi Bhai, is introduced as a menacing force in his flashback sequences, but unfortunately, this intensity isn't sustained in the second half, making his character feel somewhat underwhelming. Prithviraj himself gets ample screen time and, as expected, delivers a strong performance.Overall, L2: Empuraan is a solid sequel that delivers stylish action, political drama, and mass moments. It may not be perfect, but it's definitely worth experiencing on the big screen.

reviews.title: Just Another Fan Service Movie
reviews.content: After all the bells and hype, the grand reveals, the gossip, the record-breaking bookings... the movie turned out exactly how I discreetly knew it would. But hey, there was a sliver of hope-after all, Prithviraj has been on a roll lately, almost like he cracked the formula for making a great movie. Well, I stand corrected.Let's start with the most glaring issue: the plot-if you can even call it that. Even the most die-hard fans would have a tough time pretending it has any complexity or substance. It felt like something ChatGPT could cook up in an hour, but worse. The only time it seemed like it had any structure or direction was in the first 20-30 minutes when it actually looked like it might deliver on its promise with tactics, mission briefings etc. There was an air of professionalism you'd expect from people at this level. But that illusion shattered the moment Kureshi made his grand entrance. From then on, any hope for a compelling story was buried under an avalanche of slow-mo shots, sunglasses, overcoats and the same BGM that kept playing over and over again. But I guess that's what at least half the audience came for, so hey, maybe they got their money's worth. Maybe a little too much, considering slow-mo sequences make up roughly a quarter of the movie.The film is basically an average male power fantasy, with just enough moral authority sprinkled in to keep things respectable. I can't help but laugh at the idea of glorifying underworld warlords while conveniently drawing the line at narcotics-because, of course, gold smuggling is all rainbows and sunshine, right? So our hero takes on a drug lord, fakes his death, and dramatically returns within 20 minutes (I won't even bother with a spoiler warning-anyone could've seen this coming). Zayeed gets his revenge after a series of painfully predictable 'twists,' spoiled from the very beginning of the movie, and then, just when you thought it was over, the long-awaited reveal of the Triad leader happens. *Cue the dramatic music.*Now, let's talk about the dialogues. Oh. My. Days. Murali Gopy, maybe consider a career as the next Shakespeare instead of a screenwriter? Every line out of Abraam's mouth is an exercise in self-praise and dramatic elevation, a certified cringe-fest masquerading as *punch dialogues*, more like a punch in the gut of someone looking for a realistic conversation. It's like he took biblical quotes, mixed them with old English and Shakespearean theatrics, and thought, "Yes, this will hit." Hint: it doesn't. But oh boy, does he keep trying...I'm still struggling to find a single believable aspect of this movie. The political landscape? Nonsense (The first movie at least made it interesting). The plot armor? Thicker than a medieval fortress. The characters' ability to teleport to "cool" locations? Unparalleled. Kuereshi can also apparently turn into Thor and conjure lightning to create the perfect fight ambiance. Priceless. At the very least, with a budget like this, you'd expect some decent fight choreography. But somehow, even that managed to flop.In the end, all I can say is-what a ride. Just not the kind I'd want to take again. But hey, don't mind me, the movie is still a gigantic hit financially, the crew and some hardcore fans goes home happy.

reviews.title: What a waste of 3 hours!!!
reviews.content:
The biggest issue with Empuraan is how it selectively presents power, righteousness, and salvation through an Abrahamic lens, completely sidelining India's vast and diverse spiritual traditions. While Lucifer handled the redemption of a fallen angel in a way that allowed multiple cultural interpretations, its sequel seems heavily biased towards a single perspective
The storyline is all over the place. Going by social media posts, it seems like actor-turned-director Prithviraj is surrounded by sycophants, including his own wife. That said, better editing might have salvaged the film to some extent. At times, it almost feels like they were deliberately trolling the very audience that made Lucifer a blockbuster.

reviews.title: Empuraan: A Cinematic Masterpiece that Redefines Malayalam Cinema
reviews.content: Director Prithviraj's magnum opus, Empuraan, is a film that will leave you awestruck and wondering about the sheer brilliance of its craftsmanship. Starring the versatile Mohanlal in the lead role, Empuraan is a cinematic experience that will linger in your minds long after the credits roll.From the onset, it's evident that Prithviraj has pushed the boundaries of Malayalam cinema with Empuraan. The film's world-class frames and visuals are a testament to the director's vision and attention to detail. Each shot is meticulously crafted, with a focus on lighting, color palette, and production design that's unparalleled in Malayalam cinema.Mohanlal, the complete actor, delivers a performance that's nothing short of phenomenal. He brings a level of depth and nuance to his character that's astounding, making it impossible to take your eyes off him. His ability to convey emotions through subtle expressions and body language is a masterclass in acting. It's a performance that will be etched in your memory forever, and one that will undoubtedly earn him numerous accolades.The music in Empuraan is another highlight of the film. The score, composed by a renowned music director, is hauntingly beautiful and perfectly complements the on-screen narrative. The songs are catchy and well-placed, adding to the overall cinematic experience.One of the standout aspects of Empuraan is its storytelling. Prithviraj's narrative is layered, complex, and thought-provoking, keeping you engaged and invested in the story. The pacing is well-balanced, with a mix of high-octane action sequences, emotional drama, and witty humor.The supporting cast of Empuraan delivers impressive performances, adding depth and texture to the narrative. The chemistry between the lead actors is palpable, making their interactions a joy to watch.Cinematographer Sujith Vaassudev's work in Empuraan is breathtaking. His use of lighting, camera angles, and composition creates a visual feast that's awe-inspiring. The action sequences, choreographed by a renowned stunt director, are slick and well-executed, adding to the film's overall adrenaline rush.Empuraan's themes of love, loss, and redemption are universal and will resonate deeply with audiences. The film's message is powerful and thought-provoking, leaving you with a lot to ponder long after the credits roll.In conclusion, Empuraan is a masterpiece of Malayalam cinema that redefines the boundaries of storytelling, cinematography, and performances. Mohanlal's versatile performance, combined with Prithviraj's vision and direction, makes Empuraan a must-watch film. With its world-class production values, haunting music, and thought-provoking narrative, Empuraan is an experience that will leave you spellbound and eager for more.*Rating:* 5/5*Recommendation:* Empuraan is a film that will appeal to a wide range of audiences. If you're a fan of Malayalam cinema, or just great storytelling in general, Empuraan is a must-watch film. Don't miss it!

reviews.title: A Cinematic Masterpiece - Flawless from Start to Finish
reviews.content: From the opening scene to the final credits, this film stands as a monumental achievement in modern cinema. It is a rare gem, a work of art that succeeds in every conceivable way. A perfect 10/10, this movie is an emotional rollercoaster that blends impeccable performances, extraordinary direction, breathtaking cinematography, and a script that is both sharp and thought-provoking. It leaves an indelible mark on its viewers, ensuring that it will be remembered for years to come.The direction of this film is nothing short of genius. Every scene, every frame, is crafted with such precision that it feels as though the director poured their heart and soul into every detail. The pacing is absolutely perfect-there are no lulls, no wasted moments. The narrative flows effortlessly, guiding you through its twists and turns, making you feel as though you are living and breathing within the story. Even during slower, quieter moments, the film never loses your attention. Instead, it deepens your connection to the characters and the world they inhabit. There's a careful balance of tension and release, with each scene building upon the last, keeping you at the edge of your seat until the very end.One of the standout features of this movie is the performances. The cast delivers work of the highest caliber, offering portrayals that are as rich and complex as the script demands. The lead actor delivers one of the finest performances of their career, fully embodying the emotional depth of their character. The way they navigate the inner conflict and emotional turmoil of their role feels authentic and raw, with every subtle nuance captured beautifully. The supporting cast is equally remarkable, bringing depth and heart to their respective roles. Their chemistry with the lead is palpable, creating an atmosphere of genuine connection that draws you deeper into the film. Together, the ensemble cast forms a perfect unit, elevating each scene they're in.The screenplay is another triumph, blending sharp wit with profound emotional weight. The dialogue is intelligent and thoughtful, yet accessible, with every word serving a purpose. The film's script balances personal and universal themes, offering insights into the human experience that feel both intimate and grand. There are moments of humor that provide much-needed relief, but they never undercut the gravity of the story being told. Instead, they complement it, offering a sense of authenticity to the characters and their interactions. The script also allows the characters to evolve over the course of the film, making each of their journeys deeply satisfying to watch.Visually, the film is a feast for the eyes. The cinematography is nothing short of breathtaking, capturing the beauty of both the landscape and the characters in intimate detail. The framing of each shot feels deliberate and purposeful, with each image contributing to the overall tone and themes of the movie. The color palette is striking, enhancing the emotional resonance of each scene. Whether it's a sweeping landscape or a close-up shot of a character's face, every frame feels meticulously designed to evoke emotion. The visual storytelling here is as compelling as the narrative itself, adding layers of meaning to each scene.The soundtrack further elevates the film, perfectly complementing its emotional tone. The score is hauntingly beautiful, and it becomes an inseparable part of the film's identity. Each piece of music is strategically placed, swelling in the background during key moments, heightening the emotional stakes and drawing the audience deeper into the story. It's not just a soundtrack; it's a character in its own right, providing both subtle and powerful support to the narrative.In the end, this film is an experience. It doesn't just tell a story; it immerses you in a world that feels real and lived-in. It challenges your perceptions and makes you reflect on life, love, and everything in between. It's a cinematic event that demands to be seen, felt, and remembered. With its perfect execution across every element-direction, acting, writing, cinematography, and music-it's a 10/10 film in every sense of the word. A true masterpiece of modern cinema that will remain a benchmark for years to come.

reviews.title: Lucifer, Mahi Ravanan, Iblis
reviews.content: "L2: Empuraan," the much-anticipated sequel to the 2019 blockbuster "Lucifer," has finally graced the silver screen, and it unequivocally lives up to its monumental expectations. Directed by the multifaceted Prithviraj Sukumaran and headlined by the legendary Mohanlal, this film is a masterclass in cinematic brilliance, seamlessly blending a gripping narrative with technical prowess.From the very first frame, "Empuraan" immerses viewers into a world of political intrigue and power dynamics. The screenplay, meticulously crafted by Murali Gopy, delves deep into the complexities of Kerala's political landscape, offering a narrative rich with twists and intense moments. The film's ability to intertwine personal vendettas with larger societal issues is commendable, making it not just a mass entertainer but also a thought-provoking piece of art.Mohanlal, reprising his role, delivers a performance that is nothing short of mesmerizing. His portrayal is both powerful and nuanced, capturing the essence of his character's evolution since the events of "Lucifer." His screen presence is electrifying, commanding attention in every scene and reaffirming his status as one of Indian cinema's stalwarts. Prithviraj Sukumaran, apart from his directorial brilliance, shines in his on-screen role, bringing depth and intensity that complements Mohanlal's performance. The camaraderie and tension between their characters add layers to the narrative, making their interactions a highlight of the film.The supporting cast, including Manju Warrier, Tovino Thomas, and Indrajith Sukumaran, deliver stellar performances that elevate the film further. Each character is well-etched, contributing significantly to the storyline and ensuring that no role feels superfluous.Visually, "Empuraan" is a feast for the eyes. Cinematographer Sujith Vaassudev captures the grandeur and grit of the narrative with breathtaking precision. The use of lighting, aerial shots, and FPV drone sequences beautifully encapsulates the vast landscapes and intricate settings, adding a layer of visual storytelling that complements the plot. The action sequences are choreographed meticulously, striking a balance between realism and cinematic spectacle. Each confrontation is intense, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats and showcasing the film's commitment to delivering high-octane entertainment.Musically, the film resonates profoundly. The background score amplifies the tension and emotion in pivotal scenes, while the songs are both soulful and situationally apt. The music serves as a narrative device, enhancing the storytelling rather than merely acting as interludes.One of the film's most commendable aspects is its pacing. Despite its intricate plot and multiple subplots, "Empuraan" maintains a rhythm that keeps the audience engaged throughout its runtime. The first half lays a solid foundation, introducing characters and setting up conflicts, while the second half takes viewers on an exhilarating ride filled with surprises and a climax that leaves a lasting impression.The film has not only garnered critical acclaim but has also achieved remarkable commercial success. According to reports, "Empuraan" made history by becoming the first Malayalam film to register a worldwide gross of over 80 crore on its opening day. This monumental achievement is a testament to the film's widespread appeal and the anticipation that preceded its release.In conclusion, "L2: Empuraan" is a cinematic triumph that sets a new benchmark for Malayalam cinema. It seamlessly blends a compelling narrative with technical brilliance, delivering an experience that is both entertaining and thought-provoking. Mohanlal's towering performance, Prithviraj Sukumaran's visionary direction, and the collective effort of the entire cast and crew culminate in a film that is bound to be remembered as a classic in Indian cinema. For those seeking a film that offers depth, drama, and dynamism, "Empuraan" is an unmissable masterpiece.

reviews.title: A BIG FAT Shame for Malayalam Industry

The film is all hype, attempting to cash in on big names and grand visuals while offering little substance. Despite the marketing and the buzz, there's nothing compelling enough to keep the audience engaged. The story lacks depth, the execution feels forced, and the overall experience leaves much to be desired.At the end of the day, this is just another overhyped project that fails to deliver. Instead of taking Malayalam cinema forward, it takes a step back, proving that style without substance will never truly win over the audience.

reviews.title: Class A propaganda movie by rajappan
reviews.content: I had high expectations for L2: Empuraan, especially considering the hype and anticipation surrounding its release. However, after watching the film, I was left feeling disappointed. The movie failed to engage me, and I found myself questioning whether it was worth the time and money I had invested in it. While it had the potential to be a gripping and well-crafted sequel, L2: Empuraan ultimately fell short in several key areas, making it difficult for me to recommend it to others.One of the major issues I had with the film was its lack of engagement. A movie of this scale should captivate its audience with a compelling narrative, well-developed characters, and moments of cinematic brilliance. Unfortunately, L2: Empuraan struggled to keep my attention. The pacing felt uneven, with certain scenes dragging on unnecessarily while others seemed rushed. The storytelling did not flow seamlessly, making it difficult to remain invested in the plot. While I understand that films often take creative liberties, L2: Empuraan failed to create the immersive experience that I had hoped for.Another aspect that contributed to my disappointment was the thematic approach of the movie. It felt as though the film was pushing a particular narrative rather than offering a balanced and nuanced perspective. This lack of objectivity made it difficult to appreciate the story without feeling like it was trying to influence the audience in a specific direction. While every film has underlying messages and themes, L2: Empuraan seemed to prioritize its agenda over organic storytelling, which detracted from the overall experience. For those who prefer a movie that presents a more impartial or thought-provoking exploration of its themes, this film might not be the best choice.Additionally, the character development in L2: Empuraan left much to be desired. While some characters had intriguing setups, their arcs did not feel fully realized. There was a lack of depth in the way certain key figures were portrayed, making it difficult to connect with them on an emotional level. A well-written film should allow the audience to understand and relate to the characters, but in this case, many of them felt one-dimensional or underdeveloped. This further contributed to the film's inability to leave a lasting impact.The cinematic aspects of the movie, such as cinematography and action sequences, had their moments of brilliance, but they were not enough to salvage the overall experience. There were visually impressive scenes that showcased strong technical execution, but they were not supported by a strong narrative foundation. As a result, even the most well-shot sequences felt hollow, lacking the emotional weight needed to truly resonate with the audience.Another major drawback was the film's length and pacing. While some movies justify their runtime by keeping audiences engaged with compelling storytelling, L2: Empuraan struggled to do so. There were stretches that felt overly prolonged without adding much value to the story, while other key moments felt rushed and underdeveloped. This imbalance in pacing made the experience feel tedious rather than exciting, which is not ideal for a film of this nature.Overall, L2: Empuraan did not meet my expectations. It was an unengaging experience that felt more like a vehicle for pushing a particular viewpoint rather than delivering an entertaining and thought-provoking film. While it had potential and moments of visual appeal, the weak storytelling, lack of character depth, and unbalanced themes ultimately overshadowed any positive aspects. For those looking for a film that offers a well-rounded, captivating experience, L2: Empuraan might not be the best choice. I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this film to those who are seeking a truly engaging and unbiased cinematic experience.Rajappan please put ur sudappi stuff in wastebin :x.

reviews.title: Its a good movie but it could have been so much more
reviews.content: This is my first-ever review on IMDb, and even though I visit this site every time before deciding to watch a movie or series, this is my first time actually writing one.And what better film to start with than Empuraan!To be honest, if Lucifer was an 8, I'd rate Empuraan a 6. However, I'm giving it a 7 here because I don't want to see the movie fail-Malayalam cinema is reaching new heights, and I'm proud that Empuraan has already broken records, becoming the most booked movie on BookMyShow. May it continue to break more records!10/10 for the trailer edit-hats off to that one. Loved it.A few things I want to highlight here: I felt that Lucifer had better visuals and color grading-a beautiful blend of black and white with the right composition. Especially the colors of that Stephen/Bimal scene in the beginning. Empuraan lacks such visually appealing scenes.The first half felt a bit slow at times.I watched a lot of Prithviraj/Mohanlal interviews in the past few days, and Prithviraj sir emphasized that, just like in Lucifer, Mohanlal sir would have less screen time to make his character feel harder to reach to. I loved that concept, but the execution didn't work as well.Hats off to Prithviraj and Murali Gopy for the amazing script and for pulling off such a massive film.Some scenes were absolutely on par with Hollywood standards-especially the opening sequence.Comparing this to the previous film, Vivek Oberoi was a charismatic villain-different and top-notch in his acting. This time, however, I felt like the villain casting was typical of a regular action masala movie.I know that writing a review here takes less than five minutes of my time, and judging a film is easy. But executing a film like this takes an immense amount of guts, hard work, determination, and skill.The efforts these people have put in-their blood, sweat, and dedication-is evident on screen.Before watching the film, I had a certain image of the character Khureshi Abraam, and the reality didn't quite match my expectations. The way he talks, walks, looks, and so forth.Also, I felt Mohanlal sir looked far more legendary in his original Lucifer look as Stephen Nedumpally.May the film and project be a huge success which is a dream for many, and may many more directors get such chances to execute such huge films.All the best.

reviews.title: A courageous effort but lacks emotional depth
reviews.content: Empuraan is a technically outstanding film that showcases the exceptional craftsmanship of indian / Malayalam technicians. The socio-political themes tackled in the story are bold and courageous, and the film's ambition is undeniable.However, despite its many strengths, Empuraan falls short in terms of emotional depth. The characters, while well-acted, lack a certain vulnerability and relatability that would have made the viewing experience more impactful.Tovino's character/ plots involving him in particular, feels underutilized/ un emotional and fails to leave a lasting impression. The second half of the film also suffers from a lack of nuanced detailing, which detracts from the overall narrative.Overall, Empuraan is a commendable effort that highlights the growing prowess of Malayalam cinema. While it may not be a perfect film, it is a step in the right direction, and its technical excellence and thematic bravery are worthy of applause.

reviews.title: Not upto Lucifer
reviews.content: After the phenomenal success of Lucifer, expectations for Empuraan were sky-high. However, what we got instead was a sluggish, self-indulgent sequel that tries too hard to outdo its predecessor but ultimately falls flat.The biggest problem? Empuraan lacks the gripping narrative and tightly packed storytelling that made Lucifer a standout. Instead of building on the intrigue of Stephen Nedumpally's rise, the movie drowns in overcomplicated plotlines, excessive action sequences, and an unnecessary expansion of its universe that feels more like a setup for future installments rather than a solid film on its own.Mohanlal, while still charismatic, is given a script that glorifies his character to the point of absurdity. What made Lucifer thrilling was its balance of mystery and realism, but here, the film turns into a larger-than-life spectacle that seems more concerned with making Prithviraj's cinematic universe feel grand than delivering an engaging story. The supporting cast feels wasted, reduced to mere pawns in a game where only one character truly matters.Moreover, Empuraan leans too much on style over substance. The sleek visuals and high-production value can't mask the lack of emotional depth. The dialogues, instead of being sharp and politically charged like in Lucifer, often feel preachy and forced.While there are moments of brilliance, particularly in the action choreography and cinematography, they aren't enough to justify the film's overlong runtime. What should have been a worthy successor to Lucifer ends up feeling like a classic case of a sequel that tries too hard but delivers too little.Verdict: A visually stunning yet hollow attempt at expanding the Lucifer universe. Fans deserved better.

reviews.title: Terrible movie
reviews.content: Even with big names of the Malayalam industry involved in this movie, the acting is over the top and exaggerated. Plot is almost hilarious, making it feel like watching a comedy movie. The filmmakers have stretched what could've been a 10 minute short film into a 3 hour feature film, which makes it highly boring to watch at the theatre. Dialogues are highly cliched. The Hindi dialogues look like something straight out of a B grade masala movie. Cinematography adds to the hilariousness of the movie. The camera angles utilised are subpar. Extreme, nauseating violence is shown frequently. Overall a very unwatchable film.

reviews.title: A Visual Spectacle That Falls Short on Story
reviews.content: Empuraan is a visually stunning film that pushes the boundaries of Malayalam cinema, but it falls short in terms of storytelling.The movie starts with a violent action sequence, setting the tone for what follows. The Hollywood-style cinematography and fight scenes are something never seen before in Malayalam cinema. The explosion shots are brilliantly executed, adding to the grand scale of the film. However, there are several repeated shots, which make some parts feel stretched.The music, compared to other mass masala films, doesn't quite hit the mark. While the makers took a different approach, it worked well in some places but fell flat in others. The background score elevates certain scenes but lacks the energy needed for a film of this scale.The film cleverly mocks modern politics in Kerala, which adds an interesting layer to the screenplay. Speaking of Mohanlal, his costumes didn't work for me, as they didn't match the larger-than-life character he portrays. Stephan gives me goosebumps but A. K was disappointing.Visually, this is unlike any Malayalam film before. But despite the technical brilliance, the overall film doesn't fully meet expectations. reviews.title: Absolute trash! v Absolute trash!
reviews.content: L2: Empuraan aspires to be a gripping action thriller, blending personal vengeance with socio-political turmoil. Directed by Prithviraj Sukumaran, the film ambitiously tackles themes of loss, revenge, and political corruption, yet struggles to deliver them with coherence or impact.Set against the harrowing backdrop of the 2002 North Indian riots, the story follows Zayed, a young man whose life is upended by communal violence. His journey entangles him with the elusive Khureshi-Ab'ram and the ruthless Balraj-who later emerges as the powerful and influential Baba Bajrangi within Kerala's volatile political landscape. The film ambitiously straddles multiple genres, incorporating elements of action, crime, and political drama, but ultimately buckles under the weight of its own excesses.The cinematography, rather than elevating the story, actively sabotages it. The relentless overuse of speed-ramping isn't just a questionable choice-it's a disastrous one. Instead of heightening tension, this visual gimmick saps crucial moments of their intensity, reducing what should have been gripping sequences into repetitive, over-stylized monotony. The film drowns in a flood of slow-fast edits, exposing a fundamental failure in visual storytelling. The result? A bloated, exhausting viewing experience that may test the patience of all but the most ardent Mohanlal fans.Adding to its missteps, L2: Empuraan leans heavily on Hindi, with an excessive use of "saala" that feels forced and out of place, eroding the film's authenticity. At nearly three hours, the runtime drags, stretching what could have been a taut, compelling thriller into an overlong, indulgent affair. While its ambition is evident, the film would have benefited from tighter editing, more restrained stylistic choices, and a stronger grasp of its linguistic and cultural nuances.For those looking for similar themes handled with more finesse, Shireen Shah (2019) explores the aftermath of the 2002 Gujarat riots through a deeply personal lens, while Amu (2005) takes a poignant dive into the scars left by the 1984 anti-Sikh riots. Both manage to balance storytelling with social commentary-something L2: Empuraan desperately tries to achieve but ultimately fumbles.

reviews.title: A Colossal Waste of Potential, Time, and Money by Mohanlal and Prithviraj Sukumaran
reviews.content:
L2 Empuraan (2025) :
Movie Review -At times, we ponder how to make a bad sequel to a good film. Well, here's L2 Empuraan as a fine and recent illustration of it. Occasionally, people create a good movie and then make a forced sequel to it to earn some good money. That's what L2E is. Directing the legendary Mohanlal is a dream for any prominent director, and then Prithviraj Sukumaran got that chance as a newbie when he made Lucifer (2019). He truly made a good film, and the movie was filled with moments of his fanship towards the superstar. After the huge success of Lucifer, Sukumaran decided to continue the story, but sadly, he and the entire film disappointed big time. If this is how you make a hyped sequel, then it's better not to make it. Not everyone can do what Baahubali 2 (2017) or Drishyam 2 (2021) did. But L2E is a significant failure, man. I mean, forget the critic reviews, but even the masses are going to hate it, and I can see the box office tumbling down after the huge opening already.L2E starts with a foreign operation by an international team as they try to nab Abram Khureshi (Mohanlal). Cut to Zayed Masood's past and the revenge he has been seeking for 23 years. Immediately, cut to Kerala politics, as Jathin Ramdas (Tovino Thomas) has turned bad and has joined forces with the villain, Balraj (Abhimanyu Singh). Cut to Priyadarshini's counterattack, and then there is news of Abram, aka Stephen's, death. As God's own city is under political threat, the devil, Lucifer, must return to save it from evil.L2 Empuraan completely wastes the first half with several plot setups that are far too predictable, even for a child. Mohanlal's entry scene was dull, as it resembles the visuals and style of Lucifer's ending scene. The second half features Mohanlal in one action-packed sequence in dark settings, which remains the best scene in the entire film. The climax fight sequence is similar to the mid-action dramas usually seen in Telugu and Kannada cinema. L2's script has nothing to offer as a sequel to Lucifer, and it doesn't do any justice to its predecessor. It's outdated, tedious, and moreover, stretched to almost 3 hours. It feels so incomplete because you hardly see Mohanlal and Prithviraj in action for barely 20 minutes; then where the hell did those other 145 minutes go?Mohanlal has delivered a decent performance, and for me, it wasn't an acting-driven role. This is about witnessing the massy avatar of the legendary superstar, and he does it right. Sukumaran was underwhelming in the climax and much weaker compared to his performance in Lucifer. Tovino Thomas was quite decent, while Manju Warrier was better this time. Abhimanyu Singh didn't really scare me as an antagonist. Indrajith Sukumaran was fine, and Suraj Venjaramoodu didn't get enough space to be noticed.Regarding the cinematography, this film looks better in IMAX but could have featured those top views and close-ups done better. The widescreen format helps extend the horizon, but only if the director knew how to use it. The best frame in the film remains that "L" sign with two metaphorical elements-cross and fire. The background score is another disappointment, but the reuse of the score from the previous film was effective in the forest fight scene. Prithviraj Sukumaran should have scrapped the script written by Murali Gopy in the first place to save himself and his film from this disgrace. L2E is a prime example of how not to make a sequel that will disappoint not only critics but fans as well. Sukumaran's vision was wrong and outdated. Lucifer worked because it was rooted in Kerala, and the Malayalam audience connected to its genuineness, but here L2 completely broke that link and took the film into international affairs and the political turmoil of the state. That's so childish, and so is the film.RATING - 4/10*

reviews.title: Officer on Duty: A Thrilling Crime Drama That Gives Goosebumps!
reviews.content: "Officer on Duty" is an amazing crime thriller that keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The movie delivers a gripping experience, packed with intense moments, solid action, and a thought-provoking message.Kunchacko Boban absolutely nailed his role with outstanding acting. His performance carried the film, making every scene feel real and powerful. Whether it was the action sequences, the emotional moments, or the intense confrontations, he handled it all brilliantly. This is easily one of his best performances, and he completely owned the character.The film's storyline is not just about action and suspense; it also raises awareness about the safety of young girls, which makes it even more impactful. It sheds light on hidden criminal gangs that exist in society, adding a layer of realism to the thriller. The way the film presents this issue is both shocking and eye-opening, making the audience think beyond just the entertainment value.From the very beginning, the movie sets a serious and intense tone, keeping you hooked till the end. The first half moves at a perfect pace, with thrilling sequences that keep building tension. However, the second half felt a little stretched at times. Some scenes could have been trimmed to make the pacing even sharper. But despite that, the overall experience remained engaging.One of the biggest highlights of Officer on Duty is its action sequences. The fight scenes were outstanding, executed with great choreography and intensity. Every punch and move felt real, making the action sequences highly impactful. The way these scenes were shot, along with the powerful background score, gave me goosebumps. It's the kind of action that feels raw and immersive, making it even more thrilling to watch on the big screen.Speaking of sound, the background music and sound effects were top-notch. The music played a huge role in building tension, making certain scenes even scarier. There were moments where the sound design alone added to the suspense, making you feel completely absorbed in the movie. The eerie and intense music created the perfect atmosphere for a crime thriller like this.Overall, Officer on Duty is an amazing crime thriller that deserves to be watched in theatres. It delivers a thrilling experience with a great mix of action, suspense, and a meaningful message. Despite a slightly stretched second half, the movie keeps you engaged throughout. Kunchacko Boban's performance, the action sequences, and the gripping story make this one of his best films. If you love crime thrillers, this is a must-watch!

reviews.title: Great first half, derails in the second
reviews.content: The first half of this is a great procedural thriller. Good attention to detail, very fast paced, logical, great score, cinematic. Throughout the second half, you'll be so distracted by various motives, and how certain characters would have achieved certain things (and found certain people, and why) that all the credibility of the first half starts draining fast. It was all just washing over me by the overlong climax.It's a shame, because without addressing motive with the emotional intelligence of a ten year old, it could have been great (and forty minutes shorter). It's the same "ugh, really?" feeling I had in the last act of Spectre. It ends up turning the very real problem of child grooming and abuse into a really ignorant plot device.Also, the divisive framing of these characters into 'villains' and 'hero' leaves a bad taste the more you think about what actually happened. The general idea could have been dealt with so much more intelligently (like The Last Of Us Part 2 for eg.).

Kunchacko Boban shines as the demoted officer, portraying a man driven by a desperate need for redemption. The film masterfully weaves a complex web of deceit and danger, as he delves into the intricate counterfeit jewelry racket. The pacing is superb, never allowing a moment of respite, and the action sequences are gritty and realistic.What truly elevates this film is its intricate plot, expertly crafted by Shahi Kabir. The twists and turns are genuinely surprising, and the suspense builds with each passing scene. Priyamani's performance adds depth to the narrative, and the supporting cast, including Jagadish and Vishak Nair, complements the lead perfectly. The direction by Jithu Ashraf is taut and assured, creating a palpable sense of tension throughout.The film's climax is where it truly excels. The ending, in particular, is a powerful punch to the gut, leaving a lasting impression. It's not just a simple resolution; it's a culmination of the film's themes of justice, corruption, and the human cost of both. "Officer on Duty" is a must-watch for fans of action thrillers, and a testament to the strength of Malayalam cinema. It's a film that stays with you long after the credits roll, primarily due to its intense thrill and powerful, unforgettable conclusion.

reviews.title: Officer on duty: Abosulte masterpiece
reviews.content: I recently watched Officer on Duty, and I have to say, it's definitely one of the most gripping action thrillers I've seen in a while. The movie follows Harishankar, a police officer who has been demoted but still finds himself caught in a complex investigation that tests both his professional abilities and personal demons. What initially seemed like a straightforward action movie quickly became something much more profound.Kunchacko Boban absolutely nailed the role of Harishankar. The way he portrayed the internal conflict of a man struggling with anger, grief, and duty was so compelling. He made Harishankar's journey feel real and raw, especially as the character battles with his past and confronts his own flaws. There were moments in the film where his performance really moved me, showing just how deeply the role resonated with him.Priyamani, as Harishankar's wife Geetha, gave a strong performance as well. She brought a level of empathy and emotional depth to the film, providing a perfect balance to Boban's intense portrayal of Harishankar. The support she gives to her husband, while also dealing with her own struggles, made their relationship feel believable and heartfelt.The antagonist, played by Vishak Nair, was equally impressive. Christy Savio was menacing and mysterious, and his presence added a lot of tension to the film. The interactions between Harishankar and Christy were some of the most exciting and suspenseful moments in the movie.What I loved most about Officer on Duty was how it combined action with emotional depth. There were enough thrilling sequences to keep you hooked, but at the same time, the movie took the time to explore Harishankar's character and the toll his job takes on him. It made me think a lot about the personal sacrifices that law enforcement officers make and the emotional baggage they often carry.The direction by Jithu Ashraf was top-notch. The pacing was spot-on, and the cinematography really helped set the tone of the film-gritty, intense, and full of suspense. The music was also perfectly placed, amplifying the film's tense moments and emotional beats.In conclusion, Officer on Duty is a must-watch for anyone who loves intense thrillers with strong character development. It's not just about action; it's about the human side of law enforcement, and the price of doing what's right. If you haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend giving it a watch. You won't regret it!

reviews.title: The story of the year!
reviews.content: This production, while initially presenting a police officer with a somewhat jarring attitude, ultimately delivers a compelling narrative that delves into the gradual erosion of a person's spirit under the weight of relentless service. The initial "off" demeanor, rather than being a flaw, serves as a stark introduction to a character deeply scarred by his experiences. It's a bold choice, refusing to sugarcoat the realities of a profession that can wear down even the most resilient individuals.The strength of the narrative lies in its patient unveiling of the officer's journey. We are not simply presented with a hardened figure; we are invited to witness the accumulation of losses and disillusionment that forged him. The subtle cues, the fleeting expressions, and the gradual shifts in his behavior paint a vivid picture of a man grappling with the moral ambiguities and emotional toll of his work. This slow burn approach allows the audience to understand, if not condone, the character's initial attitude, transforming it from a point of contention to a point of profound empathy.The actors' performances are instrumental in achieving this delicate balance. The lead actor, in particular, navigates the complex emotional terrain with remarkable nuance, conveying the character's internal struggles without resorting to melodrama. The supporting cast, equally adept, provides a rich tapestry of personalities that contribute to the overall authenticity of the world depicted. The director's vision is evident in the seamless integration of these performances, creating a cohesive and compelling ensemble.Furthermore, the production's technical aspects, from cinematography to sound design, are executed with precision, enhancing the immersive experience. The attention to detail in the sets and costumes adds a layer of realism, grounding the story in a tangible world.The narrative itself tackles a timely and relevant theme, addressing a "new gen" form of crime that demands our attention. By shedding light on these often-overlooked issues, the production serves as a powerful social commentary, prompting viewers to consider the complexities of modern-day criminality. The story doesn't shy away from the uncomfortable truths, presenting a raw and unflinching portrayal of the darker aspects of society. This commitment to realism is both commendable and necessary, given the urgency of the subject matter.The production's strength lies in its ability to blend character-driven drama with a compelling narrative that resonates with contemporary concerns. It's a testament to the power of storytelling to educate, provoke, and ultimately, inspire reflection. The gradual transformation of the police officer, from a seemingly unsympathetic figure to a deeply human character, is a masterclass in character development.In conclusion, this production is a must-watch for those seeking a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant experience. It successfully navigates the complexities of human nature, delivering a powerful message that stays with the audience long after the credits roll. The collaborative efforts of the actors, director, and supporting crew have resulted in a truly remarkable piece of work that deserves widespread recognition. This production is not just entertainment; it's a mirror reflecting the realities of our time.

reviews.title: A mainstream, commercial cop thriller cooked with mostly the right ingredients! [+68%]
reviews.content: Shahi Kabir's most mainstream thriller screenplay (..thus far) largely works because of its strong performances and technical efforts. Yes, there are some usual cop movie tropes like the PTSD-induced protagonist, his family eventually coming under threat, rape-revenge-blackmail implementing baddies, and so on. But credit where it's due, this absolutely does NOT feel like a debut director's work. Jithu Ashraf (who also acts in a key role) understands the assignment and navigates the splendidly-paced screenplay in a non-linear manner, making most of the little details matter. Kunchacko Boban pulls off CI Harishankar like a seasoned veteran, letting his rugged body language do most of the heavy lifting. We learn of the character's past in a sufficiently effective flashback, and to some extent, such an evolution contributes to the physicality involved in the latter acts. The stylized gang of baddies, led by Vishak Nair, includes some interesting finds.Roby Varghese Raj (director of Kannur Squad) is cranking the camera here, and his shaky, handheld approach works wonders for the chase and fight sequences. Chaman Chakko is now an editor in high demand, and the way he paces the film and weaves the action in between regular procedural scenes (and toys with contrasting lighting) is excellent. Jakes Bejoy uses a little too much Saw-inspired score, but he succeeds in delivering a solid soundtrack overall; a couple of soundbites are instant earworms.Also, the women in the film (other than the victims) hold their ground. That goes for Priyamani, the two women antagonists, and even the little girl who plays Harishankar's younger daughter. A fight sequence set inside a mortuary is deliciously choreographed and shot. The final act does lose a bit of steam and reminds you of Memories, yet the film manages to keep you on edge. Though somewhat formulaic and predictable in places, I'll recommend Officer on Duty for those who enjoy intense, sporadically violent cop thrillers.

reviews.title: Intense, Gripping, and Almost Nerve-Cracking
reviews.content:
Officer On Duty (2025) :
Movie Review -Malayalam cinema has produced another fine action thriller this year in the form of Officer On Duty. Even though the film isn't truly exceptional, the overall impact is nearly nerve-cracking for someone who has grown bored of typical action thrillers from the South. However, Malayalam cinema is a different ballgame altogether. That said, this film remains very much in the must-watch league for its gripping storytelling and intense narrative.The film opens with the suicide scene of an "officer on duty," followed by the entry of our protagonist, Inspector Harishankar (Kunchacko Boban). He is a bit frustrated, depressed, and has anger issues related to his daughter's tragic past. The storyline soon reveals the POCSO angle and how a gang of young druggists is behind these murders. Hari finds the killers, but they are too powerful and cunning to be stopped. However, a few more murders occur, and Hari almost catches them-but would that be enough?Officer On Duty adheres to the traditional norms of classic action thrillers and unfolds the narrative in a gripping manner. The action scenes occasionally look good but are otherwise too typical and stretched. I don't understand why our action directors lack the creativity to realize that realistic action has nothing to do with tired clich√©s.If killing someone is easier in one second than beating someone for 60 seconds, only for that person to rise again for more beating, then one should use basic sense instead of succumbing to fake cinematic appeal. This film is filled with such foolish scenes, leading me to deduct half a star from the final rating. One can beat someone until the situation necessitates a different conflict, and then drive it toward the conclusion accordingly. Let's stop this nonsense because it's 2025, not 2005.Kunchacko Boban delivers a fine performance in the lead role and makes every second of his presence felt. Priyamani has a small yet important role, and the same goes for Jagadish. Vishak Nair was formidable, Meenakshi Anoop was good in a blink-and-miss cameo, and the rest of the supporting cast performed well.From a technical standpoint, Officer On Duty is a solid production, with cinematography, editing, and a background score creating a significant impact. Jithu Ashraf deserves praise for avoiding a dated mainstream template while addressing a sensitive issue, but he must be criticized for not focusing enough on these sensitive topics, such as POCSO, drugs, youth, officers' mental and physical struggles, and their family problems. With a little smarter vision, could have been a memorable film, but nonetheless, it deserves your viewing time for sure.RATING - 6/10*

reviews.title: Messy Yet Memorable - Officer On Duty's Ending Saves the Day
reviews.content: Officer On Duty delivers a mix of thrills and action in a commercial cop drama format. The first half does a decent job of setting up the story with suspenseful moments and character introductions, keeping the audience engaged. However, the second half loses some of its grip due to exaggerated villain portrayals and unrealistic action sequences, where the police seem oddly underpowered against criminals. Some moments feel illogical, especially when officers and the hero engage in fights without proper backup or resources, making the action seem forced rather than intense.Despite these flaws, the film redeems itself with a gripping and satisfying climax. The final moments leave a strong impact, making up for the weaker segments and ultimately elevating the viewing experience. Initially, the flaws made it feel like a 3-star movie, but the powerful ending was enough to push it to a solid 5 Star.

reviews.title: Smart Screenplay, Strong Performances, Solid Thriller
reviews.content: I watched Officer On Duty on Netflix after seeing all the excellent feedback online. Yet again, the Malayalam film industry delivers one of the finest thrillers. This is the fourth Malayalam movie I've watched this year that I really liked-all of them thrillers, action-packed, and story-driven. It's amazing to see so many good films coming out in such a short time from the same industry. It really shows the strength of Malayalam cinema-especially the writing and direction.The story revolves around police officer Hari, who starts off investigating a case of counterfeit jewelry. What begins as a seemingly small crime slowly unravels into something much bigger, affecting him both professionally and personally. The way this investigation ties into his personal life, and how it connects to drug rackets, is something best experienced while watching.From the very beginning, the movie grabs your attention. It starts with curiosity, introduces Hari and the case, and then gradually builds up with twists and emotional layers. The screenplay connects all the dots beautifully by the climax. If someone narrates the plot in a straight line, it might sound like a simple story. But the way it's told-nonlinear, revealing bits and pieces as it goes-makes it so much more gripping. That's what sets Malayalam films apart. They don't follow the usual Hero-Heroine-Villain formula. Instead, they focus on telling a good story in an engaging way. I really hope they keep making films like this. And I'm happy that this one also did well commercially.The casting is spot-on. Kunchacko Boban, who plays Hari, is fantastic. Known mostly for his romantic roles, he completely transforms here with a calm yet intense performance. He carries the seriousness throughout the film so well-you wouldn't think this genre is new for him. Priyamani, who plays his wife, also fits her role nicely. There's also a group of friends in the film, and their connection to the story is something you should watch unfold. They all acted brilliantly and added a lot of tension and depth.Like the hit film Pani, this movie also touches on the issue of drug use among today's youth-how they're getting pulled into crime for the sake of fun and thrill after getting high. It's a disturbing trend, and the movie handles it without being preachy.The background score by Jakes Bejoy is excellent-some beats even feel Hollywood-style. Roby Varghese Raj's cinematography is brilliant. I watched some behind-the-scenes footage of the chase scenes, and you can clearly see the effort that went into filming those sequences on real locations. The color palette in many scenes also helps set the mood perfectly. The action choreography is also well done-neither too flashy nor too dull.It's hard to believe this is director Jithu Ashraf's debut film. He handles everything with confidence-from the storytelling to maintaining the tone and character consistency. It never feels like a first-time effort.Overall, this is yet another superb film from the Malayalam industry. If you enjoy thrillers, suspense, and well-written stories, you should definitely give this one a try.

reviews.title: Violent & gory thriller thats a bit all over the place
reviews.content: Officer on Duty delivers striking visuals and a powerful soundtrack, but its narrative is riddled with inconsistencies. The film's treatment of violence-particularly against women-feels exploitative and excessive, lacking nuance or sensitivity. What begins as a grounded story quickly spirals into unrealistic action sequences, where both the protagonist and the villains seem to gain superhero-like resilience, walking away from brutal attacks with ease. This tonal shift feels jarring and undermines the film's otherwise serious tone. Characters remain emotionally one-dimensional-constantly angry, grim, or brooding-with little emotional range. Adding to the implausibility is the portrayal of the police force, repeatedly outsmarted by a group of teenagers, leaving little credit to the intelligence or competence of law enforcement. The violence is so excessive after a point it feels comical. This was an attempt to do a "gritty thriller" but you can do that even without so much in your face gore and violence. The film was however a huge hit in Kerala probably a reflection of the state of the land and peoples mindset.

reviews.title: An Emotionally Brutal Thriller That Stuns
reviews.content: Watched 'Officer on Duty' - Malayalam Movie.What. A. Thriller!Seriously, this is one of the most gripping, mind-bending thrillers I've seen in a long time. The storyline? Packed with twists and turns that keep you on your toes the entire time. The investigation is razor-sharp - you need to keep your eye on the ball constantly.That opening scene? I literally fell off my chair. One punch (or was it a kick?) - and emotionally, I was knocked out. Still not over it!This film isn't just a thriller - it's emotionally brutal and intellectually jarring. It makes you reflect. We're all so quick to judge based on surface-level logic and experiences, but this movie shows how the truth, when revealed with patience and depth, can shock you to your core. It's a reminder that logical thinking alone isn't enough - true capability comes from a mix of logic, empathy, patience, sharpness, and understanding.The police force is portrayed in the most grounded, realistic way - no superheroes here. Just raw, intense action. I actually shouted 'Adi!' during the police beatdowns. That's how immersed I was!And don't even get me started on the background score - absolutely top-notch. I raised the volume just to soak in that thrilling BGM during key scenes. Gave me chills.Even the ending doesn't let go - twists till the very last frame. Brilliant storytelling, emotionally impactful, and incredibly well-executed.Highly recommend if you're into thrillers that stay with you. One of the finest I've watched in a long time.

reviews.title: Warning Movie for the current Generation
reviews.content: "Officer on Duty" is a gripping Malayalam police thriller directed by Jithu Ashraf, featuring Kunchacko Boban in the lead role as CI Harishankar. The story revolves around a seemingly minor gold chain theft case, which unravels a deeper connection to organized crime and the drug mafia. Harishankar, a dedicated but aggressive officer, is demoted due to a controversial encounter and reassigned to a new station, where he gets entangled in a complex investigation.As he digs deeper, he discovers that the case is linked to a brutal drug network that mercilessly eliminates those who stand against it, including police officers and informants. The film sheds light on how drug abuse destroys young lives and exposes the terrifying reality of the drug mafia, which exploits victims through blackmail and physical and psychological torture. The narrative also highlights how girls are lured into traps, drugged, and manipulated, warning the youth about the dangers of bad company and addiction.Review"Officer on Duty" stands out as a family crime thriller that intertwines elements of action, suspense, and social awareness. While the film focuses primarily on Kunchacko Boban's character, Priyamani delivers a commendable performance in a role with limited screen presence.One of the movie's strongest aspects is its realistic portrayal of the drug menace in contemporary society. The brutal tactics of the drug mafia-eliminating those who resist, targeting police officers, and silencing informants-are depicted in a chillingly realistic manner. The film serves as a stark warning about the dangers of substance abuse, particularly among the youth, and stresses the importance of choosing the right friends to avoid falling into these dangerous traps.The screenplay maintains a tight grip on suspense, keeping the audience engaged, while the action sequences and investigative elements are well-executed. The film's emotional weight is also strong, especially in how it portrays the struggles of those who fall into the clutches of the drug world and their families.Final Verdict"Officer on Duty" is an intense crime thriller with a strong social message. Though not groundbreaking in its approach, it effectively conveys the devastating consequences of drug abuse and organized crime. Kunchacko Boban delivers a powerful performance, supported by a gripping narrative and impactful action sequences. While the film could have given more depth to Priyamani's character, it remains a compelling watch for those who enjoy investigative thrillers with real-world relevance.

reviews.title: Officer On Duty Movie Review: A crime thriller that revisits violence against women.
reviews.content: Officer On Duty Movie Review: A crime thriller that revisits violence against women.Jithu Ashraf's Officer on Duty is a crime thriller that thrives on the disturbing realities of violence, drugs, and abuse-particularly against women and children. Kunchacko Boban plays Senior Officer Hari, who returns to duty after a traumatic break, only to be thrown into an investigation that drags him deep into a horrifying world of crime spanning Kerala and Bengaluru. What starts as a routine case quickly unravels into a dark network of drug trafficking, sex crimes, and brutal exploitation. With Nayattu fame Shahi Kabir penning the screenplay, the film packs in tension, action, and a chilling sense of realism.The film's technical finesse heightens its impact. Roby Varghese Raj's cinematography captures the grittiness of the underworld with raw, moody visuals, while Jakes Bejoy's background score builds an atmosphere of dread. Chaman Chakko's sharp editing keeps the tension high, and Sankaran A. S.'s immersive sound design ensures the film's horrors feel disturbingly real.Performances add to the intensity. Kunchacko Boban delivers a gripping portrayal of a cop weighed down by trauma yet determined to crack the case. Vishakh Nair and his gang exude an eerie menace, embodying the ruthless predators that fuel the film's nightmarish world.But here's the unsettling truth-this is yet another crime thriller that feeds on the horrors inflicted upon women and children. Assault, abuse, and sexual violence drive the narrative, reinforcing the familiar trope: women as victims, men as aggressors, and the ever-righteous male cop seeking justice. The film does not hold back in its depiction of brutality, forcing the audience to confront the darkest corners of crime. But it also raises an uncomfortable question-why does mainstream cinema keep returning to the same formula? Are we so desensitized to violence against women that it has become a storytelling staple?While Officer on Duty is a gripping, well-crafted thriller that keeps viewers on edge, it also serves as a stark reminder of how crime films continue to exploit the suffering of women for shock value. The film may entertain, but it also demands reflection-how much longer will we keep witnessing the same cycle of violence on screen?Jithu Ashraf's Officer on Duty is a crime thriller that thrives on the disturbing realities of violence, drugs, and abuse-particularly against women and children. reviews.title: An excellent movie.
reviews.content: We meet Joe (Srogue The story focuses on 2 rogue spies, who quit the espionage life after falling in love and getting married. But their getaway is ruined when a fleet of spy organizations come knocking, guns-a-blazing in search of a 'flight pill,' a MacGuffin hard drive, suspecting the pair of joining rogue spy network Alarum. The pair have to survive fleets of baddies sent by the CIA's Ronald Burbridge (D. W. Moffett), including legendary killer Chester (Sylvester Stallone) and sociopathic operative Orlin (Mike Colter).Alarum first and foremost boasts a talented cast. Scott Eastwood is a strong lead with overall believable action credentials. Stallone has a simple role (and not one too far outside his rhetorical wheelhouse), but he's effective and watchable in it. Colter has been rocking top-shelf roles like Luke Cage and Evil's complex priest, David Acosta, and he's memorable here (with one central caveat, below). Fitzgerald was exceptional in Strange Darling, and she's good here when she is onscreen--though her presence is regrettably limited for much of the film.'Alarum has real action and surprisingly breathtaking events.Sylvester Stallone is an expert and the acting was great and so is the direction. A hit movie indeed.

And also when he got a shot on the actual target of that chaos he simply didn't kill him...Absolutely written badly on purpose.My opinion...I am still trying to understand why...

reviews.title: For the most part...
reviews.content: ...it was entertaining for those who love action films. With fading star-power to help it along.Lots of action, and very few plot holes.A gaggle of spy networks all working to get "the goods" from an ex-agent whose married to an active agent. She's working for yet another agency. Pretty normal when it comes to these types of flicks,The JJ Abrams lens flare technique show up in several scenes, but thankfully not overused.It was the ending that ruined it for me. It came up fast, and unexpectedly. Willa Fitzgerald's character delivers the only line that gives you a sense of a happy ending, but it's two words, and doesn't have much meat on the bones.When movies end that way, I get a strong sense that there will be a sequel.It was a fun ride, for the most part, but with such a dismal ending I won't be giving this one a second viewing, or a higher rating.

True, some of the participants in this gave it a try but, alas, to no avail). Did you know that you can perform a large shootout (no one reloads even once) with a lot of explosions and noise in a relatively small town (they call it village), allegedly in Poland ("enemies" speak Russian, of course, and die like in John Wick, by dozens, being incompetent like kindergarten children), and no inhabitants even come to the window to see what happens? There's nobody anywhere near but "our heroes". The cherry on top of this mess is a strong hint on possible sequel, since this abruptly ends. God forbid! There are A movies, B movies, even C movies. At the bottom there are BS movies. This is a fine example. Two stars for skill of engaging Sly and Scott Eastwood. Were they blackmailed to participate? Nothing else could explain it. Run from this before it's too late.

reviews.title: Stallone, why are you here?
reviews.content:
Alarum (2025) is the first of possibly many direct-to-video action thriller movies that I will probably have to suffer through in 2025 because this movie was straight up garbage.Positives for Alarum (2025):
If you like these low budget straight-to-video action thriller movies, then you'll have fun with this movie.Negatives for Alarum (2025):
The script in this movie is unbearably generic and boring. The acting from the cast is laughably terrible and you have great actors like Willa Fitzgerald, Scott Eastwood, Mike Colter and Sylvester Stallone here and they are all horrible. Actually, Sylvester Stallone is barely in the movie and he's one of the big names on the poster, so why is he even in the movie. The action in the movie is either generic, subpar or lame. The dialogue is bizarre and awkward. And finally, the movie drags on and on for what felt like forever.Overall, Alarum (2025) was just as generic and awful as any other straight-to-video low budget action thriller movie I've seen in a while.

reviews.title: The Usual Dreck
reviews.content: Once upon a time Hollywood made a movie where the bad guy gets the drop on the good guy and just plain shoots him.Just kidding! That never happens. Bad guys shoot on sight, just like this poor excuse for a movie. Bad guys shoot on sight at every twitch of the other side until they finally catch the good guy (or in this case, woman) with their pants down (so to speak) and suddenly it's: hands in the air, please. We come in peace.Which of course gives the good woman time for the bad guys to walk right up within arm's reach where she can then wrestle the gun away and shoot them all.Please Hollywood. We're tired of this. Okay, I'm tired of it. Can't speak for the whole world. But come on. And don't forget how the good guys are coming out through a hole in the wall and all the bad guys have their guns trained on that one point of exit, but the good guy just walks out with nobody seeing him and walks up behind a bad guy who obviously got bored trying not to get killed.Can we say ridiculous? Absurd? Comic book level nonsense? Can we say drones that can't hit a jeep and fire machine guns instead of missiles? Can we say bad guys with atrocious aim and good guys who never miss?Why yes we can! If you're making a Hollywood action movie these days, it's an actual requirement. Just like the head bad guy at the end has to make a speech before he kills the good guy so there's time for the last second rescue. And then of course the ending that introduces the sequel because there is nothing original any more, just the same tattered blueprint.

reviews.title: Run Of The Mill
reviews.content: I saw Alarum, starring Scott Eastwood-Suicide Squad, Texas Chainsaw_2013; Sylvester Stallone-Tulsa King_tv, the Guardians of the Galaxy movies; Willa Fitzgerald-Reacher_tv, The Goldfinch and Mike Colter-Evil_tv, Luke Cage_tv.This is a low budget run of the mill spy thriller with some good actors but nothing new, plot wise. Scott works for the C. I. A. And crosses paths with Willa on a job, who works for an organization called Alarum-a group of rogue spies. One thing leads to another and they get married. Scott retires-he just disappears-but Willa keeps working for 5 years when they decide to have a honeymoon in Poland. Mike is with another spy group that looses a hard drive with lots of delicate info on it, near the resort that Scott and Willa are staying at. Everyone is after the hard drive and Sylvester, who works for the C. I. A., is sent in to retrieve the drive and kill Scott, who has been considered to join Alarum with his wife-he hasn't but they don't believe him, since he was missing for 5 years. There are lots of gun fights and martial arts showcased, with Willa having the best fight scenes.It's rated R for violence and language and has a running time of 1 hour & 35 minutes.If you like spy films-I do-it would be alright to stream.

reviews.title: Not even a B rated movie
reviews.content: Acting poor, script was poor. The scenes were very fake from the very beginning. Don't waste your time.With those big named actors I expected so much more.
