reviews.title: An action thriller that was out of breath prematurely...
reviews.content: Of course I opted to sit down and watch the 2025 action thriller "Alarum" from writer Alexander Vesha and director Michael Polish, as I had the opportunity to do so. Sure, I had never heard about it, so I didn't know what I was in for. But I figured an action thriller with the likes of iconic action star Sylvester Stallone and also Scott Eastwood on the cast list couldn't be entirely bad.But I have to say that writer Alexander Vesha seemed to be on thin ice here, because the script was not particularly great. It felt as if the movie never got off of the runway. The movie felt like it was about to speed up and throw a punch or two, but it just never happened. And that made watching "Alarum" a somewhat bland viewing experience. I have to admit that I had expected a tad more from Stallone and Eastwood.Despite the fact that the script was subpar, then the acting in the movie was still fair enough. Not really a noteworthy movie for neither Sylvester Stallone or Scott Eastwood, but a fair enough movie."Alarum" was a disappointing action thriller, as it was lacking in both departments. And while I did manage to sit through the movie in its entire 95 minute playtime, I can honestly say that I am never returning to watch it again, as it jus doesn't have the replay value that many of the older Stallone movies have.The action sequences in the movie certainly made it bearable to sit through the entire movie.My rating of director Michael Polish's 2025 action thriller "Alarum" lands on a four out of ten stars.

reviews.title: Wasted potential
reviews.content: Why, when you've gathered a handful of talented actors, would you choose to cut corners so drastically on the effects that they end up looking completely ridiculous? The visual effects seem like they've been ripped straight out of a low-budget, third-rate video game, which makes it hard to take the movie seriously. It's baffling that such a decision was made, given the quality of the cast. That said, if you can look past the completely immersion-breaking "effects," the movie is still somewhat okay. While the plot isn't particularly innovative or groundbreaking, it's serviceable. The real highlight is the solid performances delivered by most of the cast. Their work manages to inject life into the film despite its other shortcomings. It's a shame, though, that the poor effects detract so much from an experience that otherwise had potential. With just a bit more attention to the visuals, this could have been a much better production.

reviews.title: Film is a flightless bird, that never takes off
reviews.content: Wow I guess I should have said this is a Turkey, or is it a dead Buzzard? The writing and dialogue is stilted, and the plot makes little or no sense. Editing is choppy, and seems amateurish.I have no idea of who their armourer was, but they kept getting details wrong, and doing things that made no sense. A single engine plane goes down, and when he finds pilot, and copilot shot in the back of the head he decides to cut his way into his stomach to retrieve some kind of capsule. All this when he is a spy on the run, yet he waits around for a mercenary team to surround him. When confronted by the mercenary team leader, he stands with his bloody hands behind his back. What mercenary would let someone he doesn't know who may be holding a gun behind his back, and says or does nothing about it? Nothing about what happens to this point or later, makes any sense.The main character grabs a rifle a rifle that had what looks like a 30 round mag and proceeds to fire hundreds of shots. He is initially surrounded, and fights off what seems like several dozen men, by grabbing an automatic weapon, and shooting his way out. They all had weapons pointed at him, and he would have been killed at least a dozen times.There is nothing entertaining, or worth watching in this film. In fact shortly into the movie I walked out in disgust.This is a lesson showing that even with somewhat of a good cast its possible to crap out a turd of a film. Bad writing, indifferent acting, nonsensical action, abysmal direction, poor editing, this has nothing to recommend it, stay away, and save your money folks!

reviews.title: Laugh Out Loud
reviews.content:
In Afrikaans, the is an expression:"Nee vok...."
It translates roughly to "Hell no" in Americanese, "Nah, yeh, Nah... " in Australian, or WTF if you spend time on the internet.Spoiler ahead!The guy determines that the pilots are undercover CIA, because of a distinct tattoo, on his neck, above his collar. Basically CIA field agents are 'labelled'.Then secret assasin (who just poisoned someone), walks down the street carrying a gun.And then how secret are the top secret agents, when so mant secret agents have heard about them...The ruthless mercenary, who killed 1 innocent bystander, and killed 3 of his own men for hesitating, is revealed to be working for the greater good, lol.The real shame is that there are so many very good actors, but the guy who wrote this, did not consider getting a second opinion.Seriously, instead of using your entire budget on explosions, hire 1 or 2 college students for a week and let then tell you why it sucks.

reviews.title: Oh boy, this is a disaster.
reviews.content: Despite having Scott Eastwood and Stallone, this film is ponderous. Eastwood hardly seems enthusiastic, and really doesn't give the impression of having once been a top agent. Stallone is beginning to creak, and he struggles physically with this action picture, which should have been much tighter.Mike Colter deserves a shout out. His villain is cold, calculating and murderousy believable, but he is wasted in this calamity. The shootouts are just not believable, Eastwood seems to be missable at every opportunity and during his first gunfight, he has a machine gun that never needs reloading!Willa Fitzgerald holds it together rather well, but isn't able to rescue this mess.

reviews.title: Why?? Just why??
reviews.content: I've seen some awful B-movies, but this might just take the cake for the worst in this genre I've seen!! Stallones bit was probably shot in 2 days. Eastwood and his assassin wife are on a vacation when a Cessna plane crashes into the forest while Eastwood just happens to be on a sight seeing tour!! Eastwood checks the wreckage to find the pilots have both been shot! As cringe as the acting was up to that point it gets waaaaaaay more cheesy and ridiculous from that point on as he's quickly surrounded by a full squad of "bad guys!" Eastwood and his wife have to fight a never ending army of soldiers with absolutely horrible aim for the rest of the movie! This movie had the chance to be great if they injected a ton of satire humor into it, but playing it straight it just comes off as not funny, not great action, far-fetched and pretty terrible script! OMG and it ends as if they're going to make a sequel to this trash can?? Are you kidding me?? LOLOLOLOL they end it as if they think this is going to be some sort of franchise!! Oh the audacity to end this leading into a sequel is just completely nuts LMFAO!! First time I've given a movie with Stallone a rating under 6 but I have to give this one 2/10.

reviews.title: A ship with no captain
reviews.content:
Pros:
This movie has an all star cast and it apparently had a decent budget. The movie had a lot of action and quite a few times there were interesting things shown on screen.Cons:
The list of cons are long, first despite the all star cast. The movie lacked cohesion. It felt like the movie was choppy and scenes didn't fit together. The camera work was also all over the place with shaky cams in places where the camera should have been on a tripod or at least a steady cam. The actors appeared to all have fun and not take their roles too seriously.Another major con was that the movie was over the top goofy in places, with the script being so silly it felt like a comedy. This wouldn't be a problem if this was a comedy, but the goofy parts didn't fit with the serious tone of the movie. And the supporting actors acted wooden in scenarios where a real person would freak out or at a minimum be expressive. This just didn't happen. An example is there was a plane crash and everyone stood around looking at it like they were waiting on their lines.Summary:
This is a movie that might be okay to watch if you just want to zone out your mind and watch a lot of mindless action. If you are looking for something substantiate, then you might want to skip this one. This is not "Bourne', it is more 'Boring'.

reviews.title: Michael Polish please stop making movies
reviews.content: Horrible!!! I bet even the director himself didn't watch this movie. If he had, he would've stopped it from being released. The script is a mess, the acting is amateurish, and the editing looks like it was done by someone who just discovered video software. The dialogue is cringeworthy, and the pacing makes it unbearable to sit through. Even a 12-year-old with a smartphone could create a better movie. This isn't just a bad film, it's an insult to cinema. Save yourself the time and avoid Alarum at all costs! And my final note to the director: Dear Michael please find yourself another job, this is the proof you are not for this job.

reviews.title: A Missed Opportunity: Alarum's Unfulfilled Potential
reviews.content: Alarum, a 2025 action crime thriller, unfortunately fell far short of my expectations. The most significant flaw lies in its weak script. The plot development lacks logic and coherence; the plot points are simplistic and poorly constructed. Many scenes feel jarring and abrupt, lacking necessary context and explanation. This makes it difficult to understand the characters' motivations and actions, ultimately hindering audience engagement.Furthermore, I was surprised by Sylvester Stallone's limited screen time. Advertised as a key draw, his presence and contribution to the narrative were far less substantial than anticipated, diminishing a major potential highlight of the film. While Scott Eastwood delivered an acceptable performance, it couldn't compensate for the deficiencies in the script and overall plot.While the action sequences were technically well-executed, the sluggish pace and lack of tension rendered them underwhelming. They failed to elevate the viewing experience. In summary, Alarum is a disappointing film. It squandered a talented cast and production resources, resulting in a mediocre, even poor, cinematic experience. I doubt even a director's cut could salvage this film. The special effects also disappointed, appearing rough and dated compared to current standards. The film lacked any memorable or impactful moments.

reviews.title: Don't they preview these things before release?
reviews.content:
Alarum spelt backwards is Murala, which is a village in Pakistan. That factoid is more interesting than this entire convoluted plot. Having lived in Southwest Ohio (Oxford and Hueston Woods filming locations) I visited the set basecamp frequently during filming (as well as the scenes in downtown,) and had hopes for something a little more cohesive and intriguing.Weak script. Bad CGI Not only are some action scenes unrealistic, but the action scene music was even quite bad.SPOILER:
The plane's deceased copilot being gutted by our male protagonist was mildly interesting, even though I am still not certain how he was able to swallow a flash drive, the MacGuffin of the plot? Several other issues, to include; a deus ex machina towards the end, endless ammo in gun mags, slow, low-flying drones, lack of regular villagers getting caught in the crossfire, dude under the bed, probably still there; and the spy agency leaders, who had the most boring office space since they moved Milton's desk (Stephen Root) in "Office Space."
Overall, it is usually nice to see a film made near your hometown to view the places selected. Unfortunately, the only award this film may garnish is a Razzie or two.

reviews.content: Okay, this movie is an absolute blast-a perfect B-movie with great actors and nonstop fun! I'm stunned anyone would skip it; you'd have to be crazy not to see this gem. It's so well-crafted, making it the ultimate Friday night escape. Yet, it's sitting at a measly 3.3 on IMDb, and I'm totally flummoxed. Is it because Scott Eastwood stars and some folks assume he's a Republican? That's a stretch-there's no good reason for the hate. This flick delivers top-tier escapism, brimming with action and cool performances. Honestly, if you don't enjoy it, you're missing out-lame! A must-watch for action fans.

reviews.title: Barbarism works
reviews.content: Joe/Archibald (Scott Eastwood) and Lara (Willa Fitzgerald) are former spies who quit their agencies and are living off the grid very comfortably in Poland. In the opening scene, we see Lara try to kill Joe and then it is 5 years later and they are married. How and why were not fully explained. She is still working for ALARUM, an independent organization that is trying to take down all of the world's spy agencies. The plot starts out bad and gets worse as we discover Lara is guarding a man for some unknown reason. A crashed DEA plane in their backyard gives away Joe's location to his agency. There is a flash drive on the plane that Jow got and everybody wants it. The bad guys (Russians?) are led by a guy with a Nigerian accent. The agency sends Stallone to get the drive and then kill Joe and Lara. Stallone is not trusted so they send assassins after him, and then there was a bad CGI drone. When it was all over, I still have no idea what happened to the drive or the French guy.Guide: F-word. No sex, or nudity.

reviews.title: Wth did I just try to watch?
reviews.content: How can a movie production have all these good actors and still manage to make such a terrible movie. Directors do not get enough credit and this movie proves it. The acting is bad, the fight scenes are terrible you can see them waiting for one another to make a move with poor reactions to getting hit., the stunts are terrible. Maybe Stallone, Eastwood, and Colter owed someone new producer or director a favor? This movie should have a warning label letting viewers know they are going to be severely disappointed. It leaves you very curious as to why they would agree to participate in such a poorly conceived idea.

reviews.title: Disappointment in Low-Budget Action
reviews.content: Alarum leaves a bitter impression with its lackluster story, poor visual effects, and amateurish depiction of combat scenes. The plot is confusing and difficult to follow without clearer context, while the background music further diminishes an already weak experience. The gunfight scenes feel unrealistic, with protagonists defeating entire armies effortlessly, undermining any sense of believability. The acting is average, but the biggest disappointment comes from Sylvester Stallone, who surprisingly agreed to participate in a project of such low quality. All in all, Alarum is a typical example of how low-budget films can fail to deliver on all key elements of good action.

reviews.title: Sylvester going through Nicholas Cage phase
reviews.content: Its clearly visible, considering the type of movies Sylvester Stallone has been picking that he needs some financial support. There is no reason why he should have done this project. It seems it was conceived by a bunch of college dropouts and somehow convinced the producer to a budget of 20 million.This train wreck has a good cast but horrible direction, script and production design. The start of the movie was confusing. Two assassins fall in "love" during a "job". They clearly didn't have time or brain cells to dwell on how to come up with a good opening. The CIA director's office is lit up by desk lamps considering they are offered billions of dollars, in the real world. The action sequence is worst. CGI drone drops which is evident to anyone that has played any first person shooter video game. Even after having an amazing actress like Isis the writer(s) decided to execute her. Viewers are expected to keep their brain and any logic behind them while watching this mess.The only salvageable part of the movie was offered by the amazing Willa, the dashing Scott and Colter. The rest of the "extras" took the movie down by being in it.

reviews.title: So lazy, they couldn't even bother to use squibs
reviews.content: Low budget 'action' films with stars of yesteryear are a dime a dozen. But with names like Stallone and Eastwood (Scott, not Clint) attached, I dared to have a misplaced sliver of hope for Alarum.The dialogue writing during one of the early scenes is decent, but wow does this film ever go downhill.Alarum is a disjointed mess of a movie. After an initially halfway interesting setup, the plot is reduced to "bad guys want a flash drive".There's no connective tissue between the scenes, pacing drags to a halt. And while there is plenty of shooting, all bullet impacts, muzzles and even blood squirts are digital. And laughably badly tracked. The blood squirts are overlays with their own physics and lighting seperate from the rest of the scene.If you can't bother to use squibs for your action movie, then what the hell are you doing?The plot meanders ahead with several double crosses, none of which are interesting, since it's all about nothing. There's one car crash scene that wasn't digital. The soundtrack is awful. It sounds like AI music, like a bad AI remix of the call of duty soundtracks. Some of the action scenes are scored with 90s style breakbeat, others have weird choral passages. It's a mess.Everything about this reeks of laziness, except for Scott Eastwood who at least tries to work with the material. But this is a big step down from his menacing villain in Guy Richie's "Wrath of Man".

reviews.title: Alarum" (2025) - A Tense Spy Thriller with Stallone's Signature Grit
reviews.content: Alarum" (2025) delivers a gripping blend of espionage, action, and survival, with Sylvester Stallone leading the charge in a high-stakes game of cat and mouse. The film follows two rogue spies who, after going off-grid and starting a new life together, find their past catching up to them in the most violent way possible. As intelligence agencies close in on their remote hideaway, the tension escalates into a brutal fight for survival.Stallone brings his trademark intensity to the role, proving once again that he thrives in high-octane action thrillers. The film's pacing keeps viewers engaged, with well-executed action sequences and a constant sense of danger. While the plot leans on familiar espionage tropes, the strong performances and sharp direction make it an entertaining watch."Alarum" may not redefine the genre, but it delivers exactly what fans of spy thrillers and Stallone's action legacy crave-a tense, well-crafted ride filled with intrigue, gunfights, and raw survival instincts.

reviews.title: Mildly entertaining but not worth any money.
reviews.content: This film has the actors move around in such a stiff and strange way, that I had the impression I was watching an animated film. In fact, I am pretty sure that large portions of this film are actually animated.Another fact that strengthened me in that believe is that the actors look at each other in an unnatural way. In real life, when you talk to someone you will look the other person in the eye but not continuously. You alternate between a straight look and looking off to the side. In this film it is only the direct look, which gives a robotic impression for the characters. Again, I really wonder if the whole film is actually CGI, meaning Stallone and Eastwood only lend their faces and voices to this film.Apart from all that, the story is thin. Rogue (ex) agent is double-crossed by his former employer and also chased by a band of bad guys who appear to be Russian (of course). An assassin-turning-ally is also thrown in the pot, which makes the whole extremely clich√©. And realism was mostly absent; the bad guy shoots the two pilots that are flying him; plane crashes without too much damage; bad guy is nowhere to be seen. Later we find out he jumped out using a parachute we never saw, but the plane was flying way to low for that anyway. The partner of the good guy sees thick billowing smoke from the plane crash from a distance, but when we see the actual wreckage, there is hardly any flames and the plane is hardly broken up, let alone burned.In all fairness, it was entertaining enough so I gave it a six. But I definitely am grateful that I was smart enough not buy a box-office ticket or a pay-per-view for this. That would have been a total waste of money.

reviews.title: YOUR TIME IS WORTH MORE THAN THIS
reviews.content: This time, listen to the reviews.This movie is so so bad. There is some good talent wasted.So many scenes do not make sense. Agent Laura has been wearing a dark wig and posing as just an average married couple wife and when she removes the wig and is now blonde and in full killer outfit attire she goes to see Roland and he he acts like nothing is different and just accepts her and takes orders from her. Another example; Scott Eastwood's character comes out of a gaping hole in a building unscathed with no gun even though there is an army of men shooting at him, who only shoot at him AFTER he ducks behind cover. So he walks out of the hole of the front of the building with no gun where all the guys shooting at him suddenly stop, then it cutsto the next scene where he comes from BEHIND those same guys shooting at him and over takes them. Thankfully this is barely 1hour 30minutes, but still too long. If you like the sound of gun fire and cheezy background music this one is for you!

reviews.title: As bad as it gets. Just atrocious.
reviews.content: This movie makes me sick to my stomach. It is just so atrocious in every imaginable way. Fake flashes from guns. Every imaginable clich√© and trope you can imagine. Why would Scott Eastwood and Sylvester Stallone make a movie this atrocious? The answer is because they need money. The plot holes are more than the plot itself. The action is sheer stupidity. The writing is nonsensical. It is in my top 25 movies of the worst movies I have ever seen. I beg of you, don't waste your time watching it! I paid $5.99 to XFINITY to watch this movie. I was able to watch approximately one hour of this movie before I gave up.

reviews.title: This was a terrible movie. The end.
reviews.content: We only watched this because Sylvester Stallone was in it. I mean, I'm all for a guy getting paid, but damn this was a slogfest. It's touted as a spy action movie and it's trying, but this had to be one of the worst movies we've watched in a while. Hell, Stallone's previous movie Armor was better than this and that's saying something.Stallone isn't in this movie for very long maybe 10 minutes, if that and he plays a super-assassin who's supposedly a master of poisons. Sounds cool, right? Wrong. He's terrible at his job in every conceivable way. It's disappointing, to say the least.I'm not even going to talk about the plot because (A) it's terrible, and (B) I'd rather go on a tangent.The bad guys in this movie are some of the most incompetent villains to ever grace the screen.For example, our "heroes" are trapped in a small building with two automatic shotguns. The bad guys? They've got automatic weapons, surround the building, and outnumber them at least 3 to 1. Do they attack? No, because as one genius says, "They have heavy artillery." Seriously? I'm not sure if this was supposed to be a serious action movie or a comedy, but wow.Another gem: the bad guys have the ex-female spy outnumbered and surrounded. Yet somehow, they still manage to lose because they're...well, terrible. I get it, main characters have plot armor, but come on how am I supposed to take this seriously when the villains seem braindead?And don't even get me started on the drones in the last act. That final action scene has to be the stupidest thing ever put on film. I am convinced the technical advisor if there even was one had no clue how military drones actually work.I cannot recommend this one by any means. Not even for Stallone fans. You'll just be highly, HIGHLY disappointed in his role and the acting here. Save yourself the time and just rewatch Demolition Man or Rambo instead. At least those movies are fun and entertaining.I give this 3 out of 10.

reviews.title: A Technical Misfire That Fails to Engage
reviews.content: High Rollers is a film that suffers from numerous technical flaws. First, the screenplay structure is weak and disjointed. As the story progresses, logical errors and inconsistencies become increasingly apparent. The film's framework fails to generate the necessary momentum to captivate the audience. The plot's irregularities and implausible developments distract from the experience, making any attempts at drama feel redundant. In particular, the characters' decision-making processes lack clarity, and their dialogue often feels unnatural.Visually, the film doesn't offer anything particularly original. The cinematography is unremarkable, relying on standard, unadventurous techniques. Camera angles are static and conventional, with no visual flair or artistic emphasis in action or suspense sequences. There are times when the camera lingers unnecessarily, which contributes to a lack of energy in the scenes. Furthermore, the close-ups of characters' emotional moments fail to convey any depth, which prevents the audience from forming an emotional connection.The sound design and music are also significant drawbacks. The music chosen for dramatic or tense moments does not align with the atmosphere of the scenes; instead, it feels as though it is directing the audience rather than enhancing the experience. The musical choices are clich√©d and at times rather artificial. The sound effects also feel overly pronounced and unnatural, detracting from the sense of immersion in the world of the film. This further weakens the connection to the characters and their surroundings.The editing, too, leaves much to be desired. The pacing is uneven, with some scenes unnecessarily drawn out, which results in a rather tedious viewing experience. In contrast, other scenes transition abruptly, breaking the flow and continuity of the narrative. A more fluid and coherent editing approach would have helped maintain the film's overall integrity.Lastly, the performances only serve to highlight the film's technical shortcomings. The acting is flat and unconvincing. The characters' emotions and conflicts are poorly conveyed, and this lack of authenticity makes it difficult to care about the events unfolding on screen. Combined with the film's other technical failings, it becomes clear that High Rollers struggles to engage the viewer on an emotional level.In conclusion, High Rollers holds some potential but ultimately falters due to weaknesses in direction, screenplay, cinematography, and sound design. These issues prevent the film from leaving a lasting impression on the audience.

reviews.title: Sky Force - A Film That Surprised Me
reviews.content:
Sky Force - A Film That Surprised MeI'm the kind of person who watches every trailer and forms an idea about how the film might perform, both commercially and critically. Most of the time, my predictions are spot on. However, Sky Force is one of the rare films that proved me wrong, especially from a critical perspective.While I may still be correct about its commercial success, my critical view turned out to be completely different. The film is superb. The screenplay is highly engaging and keeps you hooked throughout.After watching the trailer, I thought it would be a cheap knockoff of Fighter (a film I found very ordinary). I assumed it would be another mediocre addition to Akshay Kumar's filmography. But to my surprise, Sky Force turned out to be one of his finest films. It's not just another India-Pakistan war movie; it brings a unique perspective and is executed with finesse.What didn't work:
The songs in the first half felt unnecessary and broke the flow of the narrative. Additionally, the overuse of slow-motion sequences, especially in the first half, felt repetitive and diluted their impact. Slow motion should be used sparingly to create a stronger emotional or dramatic effect.Verdict:
Sky Force is a must-watch and stands tall as a remarkable film in its genre. Don't let the trailer mislead you-it's an experience worth having.

reviews.title: Highly Recommended
reviews.content:
Sky Force lands as a respectable Republic Day entertainer, with its ambitious attempt to blend patriotism, history, and drama. Directed by debutants Sandeep Kewlani and Abhishek Anil Kapur, the film draws inspiration from significant events in military history, fictionalizing them to deliver an impactful cinematic experience. The narrative revolves around the Indian Air Force, spotlighting themes of courage, sacrifice, and patriotism. The research into military aircraft dynamics is evident and enhances the film's credibility.For their debut outing, Sandeep Kewlani and Abhishek Anil Kapur deserve praise for choosing an unexplored chapter of military history and presenting it with sincerity. The story has its heart in the right place. While the movie soars high in its second half, a somewhat uneven first half and occasional emotional disconnect hold it back from reaching its full potential. The second half compensates with a gripping investigation into Tabby's disappearance and its compelling buildup. The finale serves as a heartfelt tribute to real-life officers, ending the film on a powerful, patriotic note.Akshay Kumar delivers a commendable performance, shining in both emotional moments and action sequences. He anchors the film with his experience and intensity. Veer Pahariya, making his debut, emerges as the surprise package of the movie. He delivered impressive performance. On the downside, Sara Ali Khan is underutilized. Her character lacks depth, and her chemistry with Pahariya doesn't quite spark. Nimrat Kaur provides a good supporting performance. With limited screentime, Manish Choudhary & Sharad Kelkar delivers a standout performance.The cinematography is a visual treat, capturing air combat sequences with precision and grandeur. The aerial choreography is well-executed. The background score is effective in heightening tension, though Tanishk Bagchi's music is a mixed bag. While the song "Maaye resonates emotionally, the rest of the soundtrack fails to leave a lasting impression.For those looking for a Republic Day watch with a blend of war history, action, and heartfelt moments, Sky Force is a decent pick that ends on a high, uplifting note. The film pays a moving homage to the bravery and sacrifices of Indian Air Force officers.Direction 3.5/5
Acting 3.5/5
Action 4/5
Story 3.5/5
Screenplay 3/5.

reviews.title: Best Movie made on indian air force till now
reviews.content: It's refreshing to come across a film that boldly tells a uniquely Indian story. This movie is a testament to the bravery and selflessness of India's defense forces, and it's a must-watch for anyone with a passion for patriotic tales.The film brings to life the epic true story of an Indian Air Force pilot who was awarded the coveted Mahavir Chakra for his extraordinary valor. Despite his remarkable achievements, this hero was largely forgotten by his own country, leaving his story to be rediscovered and retold through this cinematic masterpiece.What sets this movie apart is its unwavering commitment to authenticity. Rather than relying on Hollywood-style pyrotechnics or melodrama, the filmmakers opt for a grounded, realistic approach that honors the pilot's remarkable story. The attention to detail is impressive, from the meticulously recreated aircraft to the nuanced performances that bring the characters to life.At its core, this film is a powerful exploration of patriotism, duty, and the unwavering dedication of India's defense personnel. The pilot's remarkable bravery in the face of overwhelming odds is inspiring, and his selflessness serves as a poignant reminder of the sacrifices made by those who serve our nation.One of the most striking aspects of the film is its depiction of the pilot's skill and strategic brilliance. Without resorting to jingoistic nationalism or simplistic heroics, the movie showcases the pilot's exceptional abilities, including his daring maneuver that resulted in the downing of a next-generation fighter plane.The film's success lies in its ability to balance action, drama, and patriotism, creating a narrative that's both thrilling and emotionally resonant. The cinematography is breathtaking, with stunning aerial sequences that put the viewer in the cockpit alongside the pilot.In short, this movie is a masterpiece that deserves to be celebrated by audiences nationwide. It's a powerful tribute to India's defense forces, a testament to the bravery and selflessness of our nation's heroes, and a reminder of the sacrifices made by those who serve our country.If you're a fan of defense-themed movies or simply looking for a compelling, patriotic story, this film is an absolute must-watch. It's a cinematic experience that will leave you inspired, proud, and grateful for the bravery and dedication of India's defense personnel.

reviews.title: Not a good flim to watch
reviews.content: "Sky Force," directed by Sandeep Kewlani and Abhishek Anil Kapur, aspires to be a high-flying tribute to the Indian Air Force's valor during the 1965 Indo-Pak war. Unfortunately, it crash-lands due to a combination of preachy dialogues, underdeveloped characters, and a narrative that fails to engage.The film centers on Wing Commander K. O. Ahuja (Akshay Kumar) and his prot√©g√©, T. Krishnan Vijaya, aka Tabby (Veer Pahariya), as they undertake a daring mission against Pakistan's Sargodha airbase. While the premise holds promise, the execution is marred by a script that leans heavily on jingoism and melodrama, diluting the impact of the real-life heroics it seeks to portray.One of the film's most glaring issues is its reliance on clich√©d and overly preachy dialogues. Lines like Ahuja's self-introduction to a Pakistani officer as "Tera Baap, Hindustan" come across as forced and undermine the gravity of the narrative. Such attempts at instilling patriotism feel contrived, detracting from the authenticity of the characters' experiences.Character development is another area where "Sky Force" falters. Sara Ali Khan's portrayal of Geetavijaya, Tabby's pregnant wife, is disappointingly one-dimensional. Her role is largely confined to that of a worried spouse, offering little depth or agency. The chemistry between her and Pahariya's character is virtually non-existent, making it challenging for the audience to invest emotionally in their relationship.The film also misses the mark in showcasing the camaraderie among the squadron members. While the mentor-mentee relationship between Ahuja and Tabby is somewhat fleshed out, the bond between the other pilots is barely explored. This lack of focus on team dynamics results in a narrative that feels disjointed and fails to capture the essence of brotherhood inherent in military life.In terms of performances, Akshay Kumar delivers a competent portrayal of a seasoned Air Force officer. However, his role offers little that we haven't seen in his previous patriotic outings, rendering his performance predictable and lacking in novelty. Veer Pahariya, in his debut, shows potential but is let down by a script that doesn't allow his character to evolve beyond a stereotypical braveheart.The film's pacing is another detriment. The first half is bogged down with expository sequences that do little to advance the plot or develop the characters. When the narrative does pick up in the second half, it shifts into an investigative mode that, while initially intriguing, becomes predictable and fails to deliver a satisfying payoff.Musically, "Sky Force" offers a forgettable soundtrack. The songs feel like obligatory inclusions rather than integral components of the story. A misplaced dance number in the first half is particularly jarring, disrupting the narrative flow and adding little value to the overall film.Visually, while the film attempts to recreate the 1960s era, the production design and special effects fall short. The aerial combat sequences, which should have been the film's highlight, lack the necessary tension and realism, often appearing as subpar CGI spectacles rather than gripping dogfights.In conclusion, "Sky Force" is an earnest attempt to honor the bravery of the Indian Air Force but is undermined by its heavy-handed storytelling, shallow characterizations, and uninspired execution. Instead of soaring to cinematic heights, it remains grounded, offering little more than a cursory glance at a pivotal moment in history. For a film that aims to celebrate heroism, "Sky Force" regrettably fails to take flight.

reviews.title: Misleading Narratives and Historical Inaccuracies
reviews.content: As someone who enjoys action-packed aviation movies, I was initially excited to watch Sky Force. The visuals and the aerial combat sequences were engaging, and the film certainly had a lot of potential. However, the historical inaccuracies and the misrepresentation of real events left a sour taste.The film claims to depict the rivalry between Indian and Pakistani pilots, but it distorts history in ways that seem aimed more at sensationalism than accuracy. The portrayal of Pakistan allegedly shooting down Indian jets appears exaggerated, unsupported by factual evidence, and leans into a narrative designed to vilify rather than inform.It's unfortunate because aviation films can be a powerful medium to showcase the bravery and skill of pilots on both sides, highlighting their human stories rather than indulging in propaganda. A balanced, nuanced approach would have elevated the film, appealing to a broader audience and fostering understanding rather than division.If you're looking for an action movie with dramatic flair, Sky Force delivers in that aspect. But if you value historical authenticity, be prepared to take its claims with a massive grain of salt.

reviews.title: Bad movie, Akshay Kumar holds it together on his own
reviews.content:
Overview:
Don't get it wrong this movie is bad. Interesting true story about a true Indian hero but terrible execution. Akshay Kumar puts in a commendable performance given that his two co-stars, Veer Pahariya and Sara Ali Khan were deadweights in this film. The dialogues were laughably bad.Plot:
A true story about T. Vijaya, otherwise known as Tabby (Veer Pahariya), an Indian fighter pilot who goes missing in action during the 1965 India-Pakistan war. And the subsequent attempts by his commanding officer Captain Ahuja's (Akshay Kumar) search for the truth about what happened which spans 23 years.Generally, the plot was good for a military movie, and with better execution it would have been a good watch.Script:
I don't usually include a script section, but the script for this film was so bad that it merits a mention. I understand that in a military film there needs to be a dose of patriotism, which is good by the way, but the dialogues in this movie were so silly and quite frankly just cringey. It was almost like they tested the script on a group of 10-year-olds to see what would sound cool to an audience.Acting:
The three main actors gave vastly different performance.Akshay Kumar - a strong showing from the veteran but was let down by a terrible script and even worse co-stars.Veer Pahariya - I went into this with an open mind on this fresh face to Hindi cinema. But I came away not very sure what he did in auditions to merit this role. He has no screen presence, which was sorely needed for a fighter pilot. Additionally, his expressions and tone of voice are the same throughout. He has this constipated intense look that does not go away regardless of the scene. Also, his dancing was quite comical. Not very excited to see more of him.Sara Ali Khan - At this point someone needs to have a quiet word with her and maybe tell her that this isn't the profession for her. Her performances are going from bad to worse and it is getting a little embarrassing. This role didn't have a lot of meat on it for sure, but the expectation would have been that we would have nothing to talk about, instead it is another poor showing from this actress.Effects:
Effects were ok but I would have expected better than this. Many scenes were video game like.Music:
Music was generally good and fit the patriotic nature of the film. It added to what was going on on-screen.Conclusion:
There will be a lot of nationalists and paid PR who will give this movie a high rating, but best to not believe them, this movie is bad. If you love Indian military movies, wait for this on OTT. Otherwise, it is best to give this movie a miss.3/10.

reviews.title: Gonna watch the movie for the 3rd time in cinema because the movie is just THAT GOOD!!!!
reviews.content: For me, Sky Force was the rebirth of Bollywood movies. Before this movie, I only had disappointments with Bollywood movies, but Sky Force literally made me fall in love with Bollywood movies again.First of all... Veer Pahariya. Finally! Bollywood should be happy that they got a fresh breath of Veer. The way he portrayed Tabby was just so heartwarming. He made me fall in love with him the moment he came on the big screen. His acting was just a chef's kiss. I seriously believe that there would be no one else who could have given justice like how Veer gave.Because of Veer and the whole story and making of movie, it literally made me cry for them both.Seriously guys, go and watch it.
