reviews.title: Sleeping Pills
reviews.content: Ajith Kumar and Trisha Krishnan's outing, Vidaamuyarchi, is inspired by the Hollywood film Breakdown. The movie doesn't give the usual euphoria Ajith fans expect from their hero, but offers some enjoyable moments in the last one hour. Those who watch road trip thrillers on OTT, or are familiar with the genre, might find the set-up and storyline very predictable. While the first half stays true to Breakdown, the second half has been Kollywoodised to cater to fans and local audience.Arjun (Ajith Kumar) and Kayal (Trisha Krishnan), decide to get married 3 months after meeting each other. Twelve years and a miscarriage later, the couple are clearly not happy. Kayal reveals about her affair with another man, and initiates divorce, but Arjun insists that their relationship is not yet broken beyond repair. When Kayal decides to move to her parents' house in Tbilisi - a 10-hour drive from their house in Baku, Azerbaijan - till the divorce proceedings are settled, Arjun insists that he drop her. The road is long with desert on either side. Arjun loses sight of the road for a second during a serious conversation with Kayal, and almost hits a vehicle. The hooligans in the other car mildly warn Arjun. When stopped for petrol, Kayal encounters truck driver Rakshit (Arjun Sarja) and his wife Deepika (Regina Cassandra), also Tamilians. When Arjun's vehicle gives up mid-way, he sends Kayal with Rakshit and Deepika to drop her at a cafe nearby. When Arjun finally reaches the cafe, he finds out that Kayal has been kidnapped. Can he save her on time or will he lose her forever?Vidaamuyarchi starts off very slow, with Sawadeeka song - which starts as soon as the movie begins - being the only high point throughout the first half. The first half, which covers the couple's relationship drama, flashback sequences and the incidents that lead to Kayal's kidnap, is slow and dull. It reaches an interesting point at the interval, only to be bogged down by a quick revelation about Arjun Sarja and Regina's backgrounds. Had the director Magizh Thirumeni placed this part towards the climax, the film would have become an intriguing thriller. But the revelation about the couple's psychosis ends up being a spoiler for the supposedly thrilling second half, thus making it very predictable. The half-hour leading up to the interval feels repetitive. The film comes together in the last one hour, but the closure is utterly disappointing as it feels like a convenient wrap up.Vidaamuyarchi is not the usual Ajith outing and marks a departure from his typical mass masala films with an entry song and lengthy dialogues. While there are two ways to see this, the movie might be disappointing for Ajith fans expecting mass moments. Ajith wields a white flag from the beginning and stays away from putting up a fight until heavily provoked. He gets beaten up more than he can ever give back. The action sequences are ordinary and natural, and don't suit the tone of the film. Vidaamuyarchi lacks the stand-out moment fans eagerly look forward to. Ajith is stoic as a man who is caught unaware of why Kayal is divorcing him. Throughout the film, he puts up a class act as the film focuses on content over style. Trisha appears prominently in the first half, and has very little to do in the second half as she goes missing. Arjun and Regina's roles required a little more depth. While adapting from the core of Breakdown, the filmmaker fails to provide details about why Arjun and Regina are the way they are. They have performed their roles with ease.Om Prakash's cinematography offers some good frames as he captures the deserted roads of Azerbaijan in true tone. His camera work enhances the visual appeal of the film. Anirudh Ravichander is in top form, but shows off his excellence in the last few minutes. As expected, Sawadeeka stands out, and the rest of the songs are blended into the story.Vidaamuyarchi might find its space with some niche audience, but a racy screenplay, especially considering the genre, could have made the movie dearer to all.

reviews.title: No amount of style can make up for a lack of substance
reviews.content: Ajith's latest film, Vidaamuyarchi, is definitely leagues above the trash he's been in over the last few years. Good scripts seem to be this guy's kryptonite because there hasn't been a single decent Ajith movie since Yennai Arindhaal-a whole decade ago! And no, Nerkonda Paarvai was a disaster; cope harder.However, when the first trailer for Vidaamuyarchi dropped a couple of weeks ago, it felt like this movie could actually be pretty decent if executed well. Watching it in cinemas reinforced that the execution is what ultimately holds it back from being a truly good film. The plot itself wasn't terrible, but the writing surrounding it felt completely unaware of the mess it was creating. Those flashback sequences and everything in the third act? A testament to that chaos.The first half of the movie was surprisingly good, albeit a tad slow. It set up a few intriguing narratives that made us curious about where it was headed. But then, around 15 minutes into the second half, it nosedived into a predictable mess. You could practically see the rest of the movie unfolding: our hero takes down the villains, and you're just left waiting to see how quickly you can get home. Toss in a few unintentionally comedic moments, and you've got a film that squanders its potential as an action thriller.Still, it's not a movie I'd outright advise against watching. While it's not a masterpiece, it's definitely not bad. Technically, it's very sound, featuring gorgeous cinematography and serviceable action choreography that will at least keep your attention. And as far as Ajith movies go, that's a win in itself. Let's just hope the next one is even better!

reviews.title: A boring stroll through India
reviews.content: Some movies take you on a journey. VidaaMuyarchi takes you on a really long walk... with a gym bag. That's it. That's the movie.The film follows an unnamed man (played with remarkable endurance by a very tired-looking actor) as he lugs a gym bag across various terrains. He walks through streets, deserts, forests, and at one point, a shopping mall, always gripping the bag like it contains the meaning of life. The audience, however, is left wondering: what's in the bag? Why is he carrying it so far? Does he even know where he's going?For two and a half grueling hours, the film drags on with minimal dialogue. Occasionally, strangers ask him what's in the bag, to which he either ignores them or mutters something vague like, "I have to keep going." There are no action sequences, no emotional breakthroughs-just a man and his stubborn determination to carry that bag. The cinematography is decent, but after the fiftieth shot of him walking, it loses its charm.

reviews.title: Ajith & Trisha's Action Thriller is Lost in Romance
reviews.content:
Vidaamuyarchi (2025) :
Movie Review -Ajith and Trisha team up for Vidaamuyarchi, directed by Magizh Thirumeni. The film begins as a romantic drama centered around a husband and wife, but then transforms into a thriller. By the time you settle into this new premise, the film shifts its focus to a suspenseful drama based on a racket. Before you can start to consume that, it turns out to be a mass action flick. Tell me, how can a film be so diverse every half hour and end up becoming a mess of multiple genres?Vidaamuyarchi starts off with a happily married couple, Arjun (Ajith Kumar) and his wife, Kayal (Trisha Krishnan). Twelve years after the marriage, the two begin to create distance between them, and Kayal asks for a divorce. Arjun accepts and requests one final drive with her as she prepares to move to her parents' house. During the ride, Kayal is kidnapped by a gang. When Arjun finds the culprits, he is told that it was all orchestrated by his wife. The gang leader gives Arjun a second chance and demands he arrange Rs. 8 crore for his life, and ultimately, his wife's life as well. Will Arjun be able to escape this trap?Based on Jonathan Mostow's Breakdown, this adaptation also has issues with the screenplay. The emotional connection with the characters is missing, as they fail to evoke sympathy in your hearts. Kayal is having an extramarital affair, so it doesn't really matter if she reconciles with Arjun again; and even if she does, why should Arjun take her back? He didn't engage in any illicit activity, so just for the sake of love...? Wait, that sounds too generous and feminist. Arjun was a simple common man; then how did he suddenly become so violent and skilled in combat? Just half of Deepika's face is burned with acid, and she dies the next minute-really? The cops working for villains have become a regular joke nowadays. It is not about how many times the film attempts to transition into a new genre; it's about how messy and confused it appears during those momentsThis isn't a performance-driven film, so better not expect anything that good from the leading duo or the other cast members. Ajith, trying to portray a poor, helpless guy, isn't suitable for his image, and when he starts banging baddies, it looks forced. The performance is fairly decent, but nothing notable. Trisha is the same married woman we have seen portray before, so there is no variety from her side either. Regina Cassandra is too attractive to suit a cruel villain; Arjun Sarja's looks work and nothing else. Arav, Nikhil Nair, Ganesh Saravanan, and Dasarathi walk out without much effort on display. There is not much for the rest of the supporting cast, so let's skip mentioning them.Vidaamuyarchi's first half takes too long to set the plot. The second half is faster-paced and more engaging, with action scenes serving as a saving grace. That action block inside the car is the major highlight. Om Prakash's cinematography is strictly okay, while Srikanth's editing should have been more effective in the first half. The production design was much better than other mindless South masala films. Coming to Magizh Thirumeni's direction, this is where the film faltered the most. It seems to be lost in its own mess of whether to become a niche romantic drama-thriller or a massy action-thriller. Magizh wraps things up in a hurry toward the end, which is an indication of an incompetent vision. Overall, Vidaamuyarchi has a few moments of standard heroism for Ajith's fans, but for that, they have to endure the rest of the poor show.RATING - 4/10*

reviews.title: Way better than AK's last few outings, but that's not enough. [+60%]
reviews.content: Magizh Thirumeni reimagines Breakdown for Indian audiences, but given the film is completely shot abroad (in Azerbaijan & Thailand), the Indianness is restricted to the lead characters. This itself can lead to a disconnect between the characters and the audience, but Magizh gives it just about enough flavour and seasoning to keep the film engrossing. When I say flavour and seasoning, I don't mean it in the "masala movie" sense. Breakdown was a clean and crisp action thriller centered around a kidnapping, with a fantastic Kurt Russell spearheading the proceedings. Vidaamuyarchi takes the core of the aforementioned flick and adds some layers, characters, songs, and subplots. Do these extra fittings bode well for the film overall? Not really.For instance, Ajith Kumar takes a long while to become the Batman to Arjun's Joker and Regina's Harley Quinn when it could have been executed sooner and with greater impact. The first 20-30 minutes set up the characters of AK and Trisha in the style of a yesteryear GVM romance, though nothing is noteworthy in this section except for both the leads looking dashing. Right from the get-go, this doesn't feel like a film made for fans of Ajith, as the cinema hall went silent for the entirety of the first half.When the thriller bit got going, the film had me hooked. Most of Breakdown's first act takes place in this film's pre-interval portions. The Azerbaijan terrain looks amazing on screen, and DoP Om Prakash has captured both the locales and characters in a terrific fashion. The Azerbaijani actors, as expected, aren't great and falter especially in the second half. An entire (domestic abuse) subplot regarding an Azerbaijani family plays out in front of us with absolutely no effect. The side villains (Aarav Kizar and a few others) are also poorly enacted, making them AK's beat-em-up fodder in the second half. Supreme Sundar is behind the stunts-that Thallumaala car fight gets an encore here.AK looks and moves considerably slower in the film compared to Thunivu, and while that works in not portraying him as an invincible beast, I feel some of the action choreography could've been executed with greater finesse, especially in the climactic showdowns (including avoiding the typical, dilapidated factory-like location). Also, the writing goes kinda haywire with the villain origin stories and the previously mentioned useless subplot, extending the runtime further. The worst (and most confused) writing treatment is meted out to Trisha, whose character is used as a red herring at one point. Some needless twists further water down the narrative.I think Breakdown has a more powerful (way more thrilling + practically difficult) action-packed final act compared to Vidaamuyarchi, which is very straightforward 2020s-Tamil-cinema-esque. Anirudh once again delivers spectacularly when it comes to the background score, and among the songs, Pathikichu is an absolute treat to listen to in Dolby Atmos. On the whole, I feel Vidaamuyarchi worked better than most of AK's recent outings for me, yet is not a patch on the much superior Breakdown.P. S. Arjun scores over AK in their dialogue-heavy scenes.P. P. S. Regina Cassandra, as a femme fatale, is HOTüî•, and the prosthetic work in her final scene is well done.

reviews.title: this is so bad i had to reconsider my life choices
reviews.content: I have seen bad movies before, start to finish, and it is not often that I actually consider stopping before it ends.The sheer number of deadly blows and stabs that the main character receives, yet still continues 'figthing' with speed and strength - not to mention surviving - has made this worse that some of the worse cartoons ever.I used to think that even the worst movie can teach me something, but this one here changed that idea forever. There were so many ways in which they could have saved this from being an absolute pile of ridiculousness that I am thinking of actually starting making movies myself, and even if I get hid in the head by a horse and I lose my brain's ability to maintain bodily functions i'm sure i would still do a better job than this.

reviews.title: John without the Wick
reviews.content: I really wanted to like this. First 15-20 minutes made me feel like it could be inspired by a mix of John Wick and The Crow (original). They raised the stakes by what happened to the protagonist but we never really get the payoff from the build up. He is inexplicably invincible, even when he wants you to believe he's hurt and sadly the villains never really die. Speaking of which, they are evil to the core but then they have little back stories to make it seem like they have some sort of honour. There are some cool action sequences, and performance around the Samurai culture but overall I found this movie weird and ultimately disappointing. I had to watch John Wick after to scratch the vengeance itch it gave me.

reviews.title: Good
reviews.content:
"Demon City 2025" is a live-action film adaptation that has generated considerable anticipation, particularly among fans of the original "Oni-Goroshi" manga. The film, set to premiere on Netflix, promises a gritty and intense cinematic experience, delving into themes of revenge, corruption, and the dark underbelly of urban society.Here's a breakdown of what makes "Demon City 2025" noteworthy:
* Source Material:
* The film is based on the popular manga "Oni-Goroshi," known for its raw and violent portrayal of a city overrun by criminal elements. This foundation provides the film with a rich and compelling narrative, ripe for cinematic adaptation.* Narrative Focus:
* The story centers on Shuhei Sakata, an ex-hitman driven by a thirst for vengeance after being framed for his family's murder and left for dead. This revenge plot provides a classic and compelling narrative arc, allowing for intense action sequences and emotional depth.* The backdrop of "Shinjo," the titular "Demon City," serves as a character in itself, portraying a city steeped in corruption and controlled by masked "demons."
* Production and Direction:
* Directed by Seiji Tanaka, known for his nuanced filmmaking, "Demon City 2025" aims to capture the dark and gritty essence of the manga. Tanaka's previous work, which blends various genres, suggests a film that will offer more than just mindless action.* The music composed by Tomoyasu Hotei, adds to the films atmosphere.* Cast and Performance:
* Toma Ikuta takes on the lead role of Shuhei Sakata, bringing his acting talents to a character that demands both physical prowess and emotional depth. The supporting cast adds to the feeling of a very rich and dangerous city.* Genre and Themes:
* "Demon City 2025" falls within the action-thriller genre, but it also delves into themes of crime, corruption, and the human desire for revenge. The film's dark and violent tone reflects the themes explored in the manga, promising a visceral and impactful viewing experience.* Netflix Distribution:
* The fact that Netflix is distributing the film, means that it will be available to a very large audience.In essence, "Demon City 2025" has the potential to be a standout action film, combining a compelling narrative, strong performances, and skilled direction. By staying true to the spirit of the source material, the film aims to deliver a dark and thrilling cinematic experience.

reviews.title: Only for Action Fans...
reviews.content: "Demon City," is a Japanese revenge thriller directed by Seiji Tanaka and based on Masamichi Kawabe's manga "Oni Goroshi." The film follows Sakata (Toma Ikuta), a hitman who, after surviving an attack that killed his family, embarks on a relentless quest for vengeance against the gang responsible.The movie delivers on its promise of intense martial arts sequences, gravity-defying stunts, and choreographed fight scenes that keep viewers interested. Even for those accustomed to the over-the-top action of Indian cinema, "Demon City" offers a familiar experience, but nothing beyond that.Even the background score, composed by Tomoyasu Hotei, known for his work on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill," was not as intense, though the music complements the film's tone. The cinematography is noteworthy, with clear visuals that don't strain the eyes-a common issue in many modern action flicks.However, the film's foundation feels somewhat weak. The antagonist's character development is limited, and the plot contains noticeable holes. Addressing these issues could have elevated the film to a higher standard.In conclusion, "Demon City" is a high-octane action film that delivers thrilling sequences and strong performances. While it has its shortcomings in narrative depth, it remains an engaging watch for fans of the genre.

reviews.title: Proof that not every asian MA film is good...
reviews.content:

reviews.title: Poorly written attempt that gives this genre a bad name
reviews.content: I don't know if this is an adaptation from a video game, anime, or manga. But it gives this brand of shows and movies that's increasing growing in popularity a bad name. A bunch of ninjas in mask and Du-rags, yes i said Du-rags) wearing bulletproof vest that die from every bullet. Or a Martha Stewart cleverer kitchen knife that struggles to slice through humans but can slice through and kill said bulletproof vest and suddenly can break a sword. The reviews about it being bloody are correct. But entertaining is a big stretch , unless you have low standards. Suddenly the guy that has so much skill that he sliced off his arm with ease leans into the whole "he's a demon" bit, and without some impressive move , power up, or clever tactic goes down after stabbing him, cutting off his arm, then stabbing him again. So he can barely stand, but I'm guessing the demon gives him extra strength and speed that we can't see. This movie is an insult to our senses and intelligence.

reviews.title: Barmy bloodfest
reviews.content: So Sakata - a hitman - takes out a rival bunch of thugs and gives in his notice before returning home to his wife and child and his new career of being a family guy.Hmm - Halloween comes early and a bunch of guys in grotesque masks kill his wife and shoot his daughter Ryo.Then just to make things even they shoot him too. But a shot in the head don't equal dead - it only puts him in a coma for twelve years - it is decided minus any evidence of course - that he killed his wife and daughter and then turned the gun on himself. Nevertheless he is released from a medical prison, in a wheelchair, dribbling - eating mush.But hang on - is that a finger I see twitching. It sure is - and when a bad guy tries to kill him he falls out of his hospital bed and enters into a fight with the bad guy which he wins - then he exits the hospital on his own two legs which still work after twelve years of muscle wastage - within a few scenes he is back to fighting fit and doesn't he fight. What follows is him taking on endless numbers of armed thugs and winning - in fights that never seem to end. Then he is told that his daughter is still alive and in the care of the thug who killed her mother. Oh gosh - more bloodletting until he has a fight with the major villain who chops off his arm - but oddly the stump doesn't bleed.I guess if you turn your brain off and just bathe in the endless blood you will be happy - I wasn't.

reviews.title: This Didn't Make Much Sense But I Kinda Dug It
reviews.content: In a down-on-its-luck port city the world's most skillful assassin does one last job before retiring to an idyllic life of ... just kidding, obviously; within 30 minutes of his retirement some bad guys set him on the path to a decade-spanning vendetta. The story is pretty goofy. The script can't seem to decide whether or not it wants to be taken seriously and/or how overt or illusory to make its supernatural implications. Important plot points are just retconned into existence via expositional dialogue or cutaway flashbacks.But at least there's lots of violent bloody action and the antagonists rock some decent Oni masks. It's all style and no substance but enjoyable as over-the-top fun.

reviews.title: Came for the Action, Stayed for the Chaos (Also, Is That Brett Yang?)
reviews.content: Watched this with zero prior knowledge-no trailers, no comics, just vibes. And honestly, had a blast. Sure, the plot had its fair share of questionable moments (let's just say 'suspension of disbelief' is working overtime), but who cares when the violence is stylish? Think Kill Bill meets a particularly chaotic anime fight scene, with some gorgeous one-take shots that made my inner film nerd very happy.Special shoutout to Takuma Otoo and Miou Tanaka, who absolutely stole the show. Meanwhile, I spent half the movie wondering why the lead looked so much like Brett Yang from TwoSet Violin. Just me? Anyone?Overall, ridiculous but ridiculously fun. Would recommend.

reviews.title: Great Action (lot of blood)
reviews.content: This is a pure action movie. If you're a fan of high-octane, adrenaline-fueled films-especially those in the vein of John Wick-this is the one for you.From the very first scene, the film wastes no time in delivering a nonstop, visceral experience that's all about the action. The focus isn't on a convoluted storyline or intricate character arcs; instead, every minute is dedicated to over-the-top, meticulously choreographed fight scenes that will keep you on the edge of your seat.The acting in this film is intentionally exaggerated, embracing an overacting style that is a trademark of many JP movie productions. In this case, the performances are even more pronounced than usual, adding a heightened sense of drama and intensity to every encounter. The leads seem to operate on a different level of physical and emotional commitment, as if every punch, every fall, and every moment of defiance is played out with a kind of comic book bravado. This overacting isn't a flaw-it's a deliberate choice that heightens the film's larger-than-life appeal and pays homage to the hyperbolic style seen in many classic action flicks.One of the standout features of this film is its action scenes, which are nothing short of superb. The film is packed with an array of action set-pieces that span from close combat and even some gravity-defying stunts that defy logic. There's an authenticity to the mayhem-each scene is saturated with raw energy and intensity that brings the audience directly into the chaos.A notable aspect is the film's unabashed use of blood and violence. The director doesn't shy away from showing the gritty consequences of every conflict; in fact, the splashes of blood add to the raw, unfiltered realism of the action sequences.If you're tired of movies that overcomplicate their narratives and just want a straightforward, heart-pounding ride, this movie delivers exactly that. It's the kind of film you can watch purely for the spectacle, the choreography, and the bold, unabashed portrayal of violence and heroism.In summary, this movie is a must-see for any action aficionado. If you love the visceral thrills of John Wick and enjoy the heightened style of overacting typical of JP movies, then prepare yourself for a film that's bursting with energy, blood, and excitement from start to finish.

reviews.title: Horrible.
reviews.content: I know that when you watch movies, you have to suspend disbelief to some extent. I completely understand that. However, this particular movie doesn't just ask you to suspend disbelief-it expects you to abandon all concepts of reality entirely. The main character has been completely brain-dead for 12 years, which means his muscles would have atrophied to the point of uselessness. There's absolutely no way he would be able to move, let alone function normally. And yet, the moment he sees someone significant, he magically wakes up as if nothing ever happened. On top of that, he gets shot, beaten in the head, and even stabbed-injuries that would instantly kill a normal person-but somehow, he just keeps going without any real consequences. The pacing of the movie is also painfully slow, with long, drawn-out sections of meaningless filler between the action scenes. I've never felt compelled to write a review before, but this movie was so unbelievably bad that I couldn't let it go without saying something.

reviews.title: Not so cool movie

Like the hospital fight was something.. the one in the rubbish plant was also something... but compared to other movie - like the korean's ballerina, it just fall short.I just think Japanese cinema could do better. I haven't been wowed much recently.

reviews.title: Yakuza Demon
reviews.content: Demon City: Based on manga series "Oni Goroshi" by Masamichi Kawabe this is mainly a Yakuza/Revenge film but does enter the slipstream of horror. Sakata (T√¥ma Ikuta) is a hitman (on one last job), he carries out a contract to basically wipe out a Yakuza clan but is himself betrayed by the new Yakuza lords of Shinjo City, his family killed and left for dead. After 12 years in a prison hospital he is released to the care of a friend, though he is still brain damaged and largely immobile. Attempts on his life result in his resuscitation and he is soon slaughtering his enemies. He is more than just an Asian John Wick though, he seems to survive increasingly fatal wounds along with slaying hordes of his foes. There is a legend that every 50 years a Demon will arise in Shinjo City to go on an unstoppable killing spree, the Demon mask wearing Yakuzas fear that Sakata is that Demon. Political and police corruption along with people trafficking, drug dealing and extreme gore and violence combine to make Demon City into a disturbing film. The fights are wonderfully choreographed though, exceeding even the John Wick series with the attention to detail: there are so many different ways to decapitate a man. While it might be derivative it's well worth watching. It has a few interesting plot twists. Directed by Seiji Tanaka, Written by Tanaka and Masamichi Kawabe. On Netflix. 7.5/10.

reviews.title: Not good enough
reviews.content: I was expecting a decent movie, but the reason this one didn't meet my expectations is because it is too unrealistic and inconsistent. You can't wake up from 12 years of coma and go straight into physical contest (fight), nor be able to stand on your feet and this lasts for months. The main characters goes even further - he has so much blood, he can never die from blood loss (which can be said about both "The Raid" movies, but the thing is everything there is made less excessive than this movie and just better), but in one moment he can barely stand on his feet, the next he is acting like John Wick on PEDs. Don't get me wrong, everything is filmed good enough, the actors are good enough, it is just the entire concept that is poorly represented.

reviews.title: What a glorious blood fest
reviews.content: Oh, the plot is fairly basic and been done dozens of times of times before. But the dad being possessed by an avenging demon is a fresh and freaky twist. And, wow, the glorious and bloody fight sequences with such a high body count!!! What a fun and ridiculous romp! The masks for each of the villains was a nice touch. And then the "hero" loosing an arm AND prevailing to the heroic ending just makes me smile at the audacity of such a ludicrous tale. Oh, and blood on par with anime is to be applauded. They knew their audience - those who love Die Hard but wanted more bloody gore. Way to go, guys!

reviews.title: I seen better, i seen worst, but story make little sense
reviews.content: It had been a while since i watched a Japanese martial art movie, so as i saw this on Netflix and with the French dubbing nontheless, i sure gave it a shot.The first issue i had was that the plot is barebone. The old classic of retiring hitman have to be taken out by former boss has been seen a million time sure, but normally you at least are given a reason to care for the character. Sure his familly is murdered but outside of that, you see so little of that guy and he pretty much have the personnality of a broom, so its hard to care.As for the rest, well sure there is some decent action with no refrain on blood and violence, but its like the movie never decide what it want to be. Is he supernatural or just a man? Is this a serious revenge flick or its supose to be goofy (despite the violence). It never decide.You really have to turn your brain off to enjoy it even middly. Personally i was never "bored" per say, but i rolled my eyes a few times. I would say its a 5.4 out of 10. So it get a 5 ultimately. Its average. Watchable, but its not one i will revisit.

reviews.title: Tiny flashes of competence, overall a fail
reviews.content: As dumb and as low budget this movie feels, there are actually small moments during the fight choreography in the middle and latter parts that actually do look cool and with a better director this movie could have really shined, but ultimately was fumbled BIG TIME. For every tiny flash of competence in choreography come many more terrible effects and camerawork that make the action look cheap. The factory fight had glimpses of promise as well as the staircase scene, but far too many terrible effects were present for it to really shine.The entire movie feels like it was filmed with a handheld Sony camera on a tripod. None of the scenes feel natural and all the awkward acting had me wondering if everyone on set hated each other. The main character has ZERO personality and doesn't feel like he belongs in his role. Everyone speaks like robots and delivers their lines like they are reading them for the first time.Final fight was terrible, main character just withering in pain entire time and seemingly immortal to all the mortal wounds suffered.The only things I liked were the demon masks, the very few glimpses of actual good choreography there were..... and that's pretty much it. Do not recommend it.

reviews.title: Action-packed Japanese Movie
reviews.content: I liked the Theme of this movie. In some plots of the movie is feel like, Jonh Wick Japanese version. But story was deferent theme. This movie shows the Japanese gangster culture very well. The action sequence and bgm also good.Over all i liked the storyof this movie. I wish it was a web- series.Netflix never disappoint me.The Cinematography is also good.Well design Action sequence. This Movie was engaging.In my point of view, i have a soft corner of japanese movie or web series.I really like to know about japanese culture. Also want to know about japan. This movie engaged me with that elements japan culture.

reviews.title: A super fast action, stupid yet creative and enjoyable movie
reviews.content: I can finish this review in two sentences. The action of this movie is creative. But it is paced like it was made by Daniel LaBelle. If you want a more dense review then read the rest.This movie was really mid from the beginning. The first scene was the typical yakuza getting hunted type of scene. The difference is, all the enemies are dumb. They jump on the MC like they don't have some fire arms. They work separately instead of taking ground and spraying at him. Ok maybe I except it for the yakuza as they work like gangsters. But when they enter one of the cars and the driver was dead. So they decided to hide the leader in a closed house while the MC kept killing for a couple of minutes until he reached them, instead of throwing the dead carcass and drive the car. Like come on.The scene were the demon mask gang jumped on the MC home and killed his family even though he retired just to clean the city from demons (this is one of the biggest stupidest baloneys I have ever heard). Tried to kill the MC but somehow he survived and got paralyzed. They kept him alive. None on this make sense. But I will forgive them.This movie housed a lot of problems. One of them is the enemies always jumping on him. The big plot armor for the MC. The ending was meh but I will count it as a problem. Last and not least the noradrenaline of the devil. He got hit hundred and hundred of times. Yet he stands up and fights like a monster or a demon (the whole point of the movie). There is a limit to "ok I will allow it" as he kept swinging like a beast and driving a car and losing a lot of blood. Still he kept going.But the action had some creative and lovely scenes. Like the time he hit a fire distinguished. Got it stuck in the blade and used it to throw it on them and gain the upper hand. The cool cutting scenes. It almost felt like he was cutting through the screen. I really liked it. The blood spraying all over the place in a good gentle yet chaotic touch. These the reasons that kept the movie alive and gave it a better rating than what I should have gave it.

reviews.title: ABOVE DECENT TBH
reviews.content:
Rating: 7/10Demon City was above decent, but it had its flaws. The writing felt weak, with dialogue that often lacked depth, making some scenes feel pointless. The acting was mid-none of the performances stood out. Several scenes made no sense at all, pulling me out of the experience. The plot twist was predictable, offering no real surprise. However, the action sequences were entertaining and well-executed, making up for some of the film's shortcomings. If you're here for the fights, it delivers. Just don't expect a deep or compelling story.Pros:

reviews.title: The plot doesn't make sense
reviews.content: I initially gave this a seven because the action scenes were pretty good. However, at times he did have supernatural strength, which was cool to watch, but not believable. I ended up giving it a six and after writing this review, I might actually go down further. First off, I just wanna talk about the blooper before I forget to mention it. There was a scene where they were fighting in the living room. Out of nowhere, someone wearing blue jeans and a blue sweater gets off of the couch and runs to the right with their head down. I don't know how this was allowed to be in the final edit. Why didn't the director just re-shoot after the crew-member was caught by the camera? I watched it like seven times and shake my head every time.OK, let's get to it! Why kill this man to begin with? He did a job for you through an intermediate. There was no loose end. If the issue was a loose end, the one to kill would be the intermediate. Also, if the hitman was the main target, why wait until he got home and kill his whole family? When they were in his house, they said that they wanted to stop this demon who comes out every 50 years to go on a killing spree. How are they in the saving lives business? That's clearly not who they are. They are a criminal enterprise that hired a hitman to kill their competition. So why are they taking it upon themselves to stop a demon before he arises in order to save others?There needs to be more details as to why they feel as though this particular man is the man that they are looking for. Why is he the one to become this demon? Also, if that guy is supposed to be the demon, why do you feel the need to kill his innocent wife and very young child? Also, after they realized that they did not kill him. Why was the order not to finish the job? Are they trying to stop this demon or create this demon? This man was also catatonic for 12 years. They had ample time to stop this demon if they really wanted to.Also, what happened to the last demon? What are the details surrounding that? Who was this demon? What did they do? How was it received by the city? Who is telling this myth and what does this criminal enterprise have to do with it? It would make sense that the twin brothers lost their grandparents because the last demon killed them. So they were trained in martial arts by their parents and also trained somehow of finding the next demon so that they could stop them. That would make more sense. Also, one brother could have been very vocal about killing the demon while the other brother was always intrigued by the fantasy of fighting the demon one on one to test his skills and see if he was better than him because he always strived to be the best. Then the movie could have focused a lot more on the brothers and how they loved each other, but didn't see eye to eye. This also would've made more sense at the end of the movie where one brother assumed the identity of the other one because he was never in the spotlight because of his brother. That would've been a more well rounded movie. It would've showed him getting what he wanted at the end right before being struck down by his own hubris. It could've been that he was the one that saved the daughter just for her to strike him down because he became the monster he always thought his brother was and them realizing this in his last moments.Getting back to the timeline, when they approach the house and killed the family, was this 50 years after the last demon? Because the events of this movie don't start until 12 years after the initial scene. And if that's the case, this would be 62 years after not 50. And if it was less say 38 years then they were way early. Also, if he is now retired, why would he become this demon they are trying to stop?Also, would like to know the main character's background. How was he so good? How did he know his handler and for how long? That would've made a bittersweet moment when he killed him to know that they were childhood friends and also the kid's godfather. Also, why did he give them up to begin with? What was he getting out of it? Why was this the main character's last job? Was his wife not comfortable with this? Did she just find out and demanded that he stop? Did he just come to the realization after experiencing a life-changing event that made him want to no longer continue? How good was the money after being this elite assassin for I'm guessing a long time? Do they know him in this community? Does he have a military background? Was he a street kid? How was he trained? Why does he prefer blades? Is there a specific reasoning behind this? In almost 15 years no one has found his weapon stash? If that was a space he was paying for, he was no longer making those payments. How is that still there? If he was not paying for that space then it runs the risk of anyone going in there, taking the weapons, taking the car, taking whatever else he might have there. So by the time he came back 12 years later, there should be nothing left. I don't know. Maybe he owned it out right. Also, when he took the car to go to his last job, the door never closed. I was waiting for it to close and it never did. I don't have much to say about that. I just thought it was weird that you wouldn't just click the garage door button and close the door.Also, shouldn't he be in jail after being framed with the killing of his family? Let's also get into how the reporter said he killed them both. How Sway!? The daughter was fine.OK, and I know I'm leaving a lot of stuff out, but I think I'm just gonna stop now. The action was cool but the movie left me with a lot of questions that were unanswered and after writing this, I'm dropping it down to a five. I knew that would happen.

reviews.title: A bland violent revenge tale.
reviews.content: Sakata is an near invincible hitman who wants to quit after a big hit. Things take an ugly turn when a group of masked men attack him and his family, leaving him for dead. 12 years later, he is out of coma and hungry for revenge so Sakata gets on with his impending massacre as he doesn't find it hard to go after the masked men. A big reveal almost shook him but he remains focused in getting all the men responsible. How does he exact his revenge on everybody and how bloody the killings are, makes rest of the film.The problem with this Manga adaptation is that it has nothing new to offer. It's a bland revenge tale which relies on the bloodied action sequences which also doesn't stand out. After the initial scenes, the film continues to be extremely monotonous and tested my patience throughout. The man is invincible so no amount of bullets or stab wounds can stop him. The big reveal too doesn't contribute anything as there is no emotional build up for that kind of narrative. Similarly that other reveal about the main villain too appears out of nowhere and I couldn't understand why would the audience care for such an information.

reviews.title: This was being compared to John Wick? Seriously?
reviews.content: Why? How? In what universe does this even compare to John Wick? Man gets arm chopped off and it doesn't even bleed. Man gets shot in the HEAD but survives? Gets shot, stabbed, falls from a window and loses a ton of blood and yet wins? What? If there was a story being told here, I'm lost. So the last masked thug was Ryo's step brother? How did the politician guy survive a fatal cleaver blow to the head? How did he develop burn scars on his face? Despite typing the literal story apparently there's still a minimum word limit of 70 left. No wait. It's decreasing now. Almost done. There we go. All done.

reviews.title: Crow Bill Wick
reviews.content: The obvious comparisons between this, the Crow, John Wick, and Kill Bill are already out there. Unfortunately, this movie doesn't come close to matching the style, action, or storytelling of those it apes. It starts off reasonably well with the tried and tested tale of an assassin double-crossed, and put out of action by an evil gang of criminal with a plan. Sadly, the comeback of our hero takes a little too long and doesn't really make much sense. Once he's up and running though, it's a non-stop rollercoaster of retribution. Unfortunately, the rollercoaster is a bit wonky and silly. Such as the unbelievably poor aim of the bad guys who are often are running towards the hero with a gun only to be whacked with his weapon of choice, a machete. He can shoot too, and when he does he hits every target perfectly. Which raises the question, why wouldn't he just use a gun all the time! Obviously the machete is his gimmick, but it's a silly one, and makes little sense. Then there's the music. It's bad. Insufferable in places. Think along the lines of John Woo, where the music is supposed to elevate a scene, but it comes across silly and cringe. There's constant twangs from a guitar that may well be part of The Crow influence, but it doesn't fit at all with this story, and it sounds amateurish. The acting is fine and there are some okay action sequences, but overall it can't keep up with its ambitions and falls flat because of its failings. There's far worse action movies, but there's also far better.

reviews.title: Utter stupidity
reviews.content: I really wanted to like this, but man, do these directors and writers think we're stupid? Or was this movie made for 10-year-olds? What a load of crap. Completely unbelievable and utterly ridiculous. I thought John Wick was over the top, but this movie makes it look like a masterpiece in comparison.Maybe it's the writing. Maybe it's the main actor, who failed miserably at making me believe a person could pull off what he did. Whatever the explanation for him being untouchable was, it was poorly executed on screen.I never thought I'd be this disappointed in an Asian action flick. Netflix really needs to just leave them alone-they do a far better job telling their own stories without all this nonsense.And to top it off with the worst ending in movie history. Classic.

reviews.title: A poor man's "Man From Nowhere"
reviews.content: This was a standard predictable revenge flick with some action. The plot didn't make much sense - at one point I thought I was watching a flashback scene but as the movie progressed, it turns out it wasn't a flashback after all!I hoped at least the action would be good as in recent times. Japanese movies have really upped their action quality (for example the live action The Fable movies, Yu Yu Hakusho, Rurouni Kenshin). However the zombie-style fights and gunplay were lazy choreographed. I'd rather watch Man From Nowhere again just to get this movie out of my mind. If you've seen this type of movie already then I'd reccomend to skip it.Also, it is unrelated to the anime "Demon City Shinjuku"

reviews.title: Accept the terms and conditions
reviews.content: Whenever you set out to watch a movie like this one, you need to sign an implicit contract with the filmmaker. You accept the terms of the movie beforehand, which means you don't question them later.We always do that when watching animated, science fiction or fantasy movies. So this one is no different. It is as far fetched as you could possibly imagine, but if you have accepted the T&C beforehand, then you can sit back, relax and enjoy some really fun entertainment.This is a Japanese, hardcore version of John Wick. It is bloody, and even though it is shot in hyper-realistic mode, its storyline isn't meant to be realistic, nor even plausible. It's a stage for the numerous action sequences, which are very well choreographed and filmed, with gallons of blood flowing, and bad guys that are REALLY bad and won't balk at killing anyone - and I mean ANYONE - that's in their path.The title already tells you that this city has at least one demon, and while the bad guys are all obviously impersonating demons, you get to a point where you start wondering if the "good" guy (who's a ruthless killer himself) isn't an actual demon. That would explain why he manages to survive some of the most unlikely - and nasty - wounds. Yet, he is never portrayed as a demon... but you get to wondering nonetheless.As I already stated, the action sequences are well made, well lit, accompanied by music that's appropriately angst-ridden to support them. The carnage, however improbable it gets at some point, is never boring.I really enjoyed this one. It's the kind of stuff that would make Tarantino proud.

reviews.title: Incredible
reviews.content: Dyer is back in this hard-hitting movie from Nick Lowe. However, you will be on a high when you walk out of the cinema. No one messes with East Ender Danny-the most lethal thing to come out of the East End since that black plague.It has a good soundtrack and believable characters, plus the fun joke about what Marching powder is. So put that all together you get a really great British movie that will make you proud to be a Brit.As for DD, he is the same likeable rogue he was in Nick Lowe's other movie (with DD in them). Mostly it is good to not see him play his role that he does in East Enders.

reviews.title: Awful
reviews.content: The main reason this gets a 1 is. That there is no point. Usually a film has a beginning and an end and the characters have been on some sort of journey whether this leads to a positive or negative change. Nope, nothing. Life carries on the same. With racism and mental health terminology that is so outdated, why is this normalised to get a laugh? The funniest line in the film was a one liner about building a cathedral. It could have been so much more. Felt like they got to the end and the script writers thought, nah can't be bothered! My advise would be not to bother at all which is a shame as was really looking forward to it.

reviews.title: Cockney's
reviews.content:
True Londoner movie . Have to back our danny dyer, i grew up in the 80's 90's in the true londoners decade .......
Surprisingly, no immigrants, not one was at this movie ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£ and not enough original cockney's. His acting has definitely got better its a shame we couldn't bring back all the old skool boys from the factory for this one would of been puka mate. This sort of movie well only draws a sort of crowd originals, basically. Very funny English humour you definitely gotta be from the UK to have a laugh with this one. It's not for faint . Hearted for sure its a proper worth a watch back our boy danny Dyer.

reviews.title: Really shockingly bad
reviews.content: I have seldom seen such garbage.I got the impression that we were supposed to be finding something funny about a sad loser who's apparently never had a job but somehow manages to buy endless amounts of cocaine and booze and travel regularly to away football matches to engage in drunken violence. He also has a young son who he exposes to drugs and pornography. I even got the idea that maybe we were supposed to empathise with him.I'll admit that it got quite a few laughs from others when I went but that seemed to be because they thought the above, along with saying 'c***' a lot and witty lines like 'smashing the missus's back doors in' as well as smashing bottles over people and exposing a child to gunfire were hilarious.At the outset there's an idea that our hero is on a possible road to redemption but that ends up coming to nothing.They obviously didn't bother getting a technical advisor on the law because every aspect of court procedure is portrayed wrongly, as anyone who has actually lived that life would spot.There's just nothing to be said in favour of this film.

reviews.title: If you didn't like this movie it's your fault
reviews.content: Anyone paying to watch this movie should be very aware of 1. What type of movies the director has previously put out, and 2. What type of movies Danny Dyer has put out. If you are keen on the rough, close to the bone language and violence, you will enjoy this movie. It's akin to football factory but with a better, more grown up storyline. If you're rating Marching Powder low, then the mistake is on your part. It's exactly what you should expect, and was very enjoyable.The supporting characters are all spot on and add to the Essex gangster no nonsense script.Danny Dyer, legend of the Dickie.

reviews.title: Meh but the football crowd will like it
reviews.content: Proper British film that shows the hooligan football lifestyle and I'm sure many brits will love it.It's a pretty funny film that makes a few cracks at various things and goes risky with its comedy at times which I can admire as most films are too scared to do that. The whole story about this piss head and smack head not being able to get his life together is fun to watch with all the chaos but overall it's about his journey to change, it never has enough depth for this change to be shown or his romance with his wife. He doesn't really change much by the end of it and falls into the same pattern so story wasn't very rewarding or believable due to not enough depth especially with how easily his wife runs back to his bad behaviour. All this was to me is some pretty funny moments but story needed to be better.Dialogue was very British but relied way too much on the C word.Danny Dyer was a pleasure to see at the premiere and the director and they were solid with an entertaining performance and a creative quirky film.A movie made for the British football crowd who this story is about.

reviews.title: Danny Dyer Shines in a Fun Yet Poignant Dive into Forgotten British Culture
reviews.content: Dyer stars as Jack Jones, a middle-aged football hooligan hooked on "marching powder" (cocaine slang), clashing with his father-in-law (Geoff Bell) and straining his marriage to Dani (Stephanie Leonidas). Given six weeks to clean up or face jail, Jack's chaos unfolds with wit and grit. Dyer's in top form, breaking the fourth wall with cheeky asides that inject playful energy-his cockney charm and comedic timing make Jack a mess you can't help but root for. Love's script takes a fun stab at British politics, mixing satire with serious undertones about a fading subculture (or is it just suppressed by media?). It's nostalgic yet critical, mourning a generation left behind. The cast shines: Leonidas balances exasperation and warmth, Bell oozes menace, and Calum MacNab's wild Kenny Boy steals scenes. Love directs with flair, capturing gritty pubs and brutal brawls-scored by Alfie Godfrey's pulsing beats. Dialogue crackles with profanity-laced zingers, and quiet moments, like Jack with his son (Arty Dyer), add surprising depth. It's not perfect-pacing dips, some jokes push boundaries-but its unapologetic spirit, led by Dyer's swagger, makes Marching Powder wildly fun.

reviews.title: A rather dark comedy
reviews.content: Marching Powder: A laugh a minute serious comedy, the serious elements are rather dark. Jack (Danny Dyer) is 45, a cokehead, heavy drinker, still into getting into fights with rival football firms. His mates really lead him astray, so he claims. He is arrested, up before the beak who gives him 6 weeks to clean his act up or it's prison time. Jack still loves his wife Dani and his son but it's hard to stay straight. Especially when his father in law wants him to look after his crazed brother in law who has a habit of attacking and robbing drug dealers. Dani also wants more from life and goes back to Art College. An extremely violent, foulmouthed film, a romcom, a dark comedy, just a comedy anyway at times. The backstory really demands for Jack and Dani to be 35 for it to make sense but even the great Danny Dyer can't pass for 35 without CGI. Still, it's worth watching. Written and Directed by Nick Love. 6.5/10.

reviews.title: Funny and rough
reviews.content: Jack is a diamond geezer, off with his mates for drinking, frequent football punch-ups and, especially, cocaine. He loves his wife and son, but he loves cocaine just that little bit more. But when, following a football brawl, a judge gives him 6 weeks to sort himself out or face 5 years, in prison, he figures he ought to make the effort - after all, he is 45. But all the temptations are still there. Plus, as quid pro quo for their rent-free home, father-in-law has tasked him with looking out for his wife's brother Kenny Boy, who happens to be schizophrenic, with a tendency to attack people.Danny Dyer plays Jack in a film which has vast amounts of profanity (including more use of the C-word than I have ever encountered before - I read 45), not to mention the drug use and violence. I have mixed feelings on bad language - it has its place but often adds little - and I don't regard drugs and violence as things which make life more worthwhile. Yet I really enjoyed this film.Why?First it's very funny. The humour is coarse, and often fairly savage, but I laughed out loud a number of times, and that doesn't happen very often. Second, Jack recognises that the cocaine and fighting will destroy his marriage, family, security, and everything else that matters in his life. He's trying to fight, but the things which tempt him are still there. I can identify: I didn't give up smoking at the first attempt. Or the tenth. Third, there's something about most of the characters which couples awfulness with likability. Even the problematic Kenny Boy acknowledges his issues and wishes he didn't have them.Danny Dyer does well here. It's a part which suits his established persona, to be sure, but his line delivery works, especially when he is making sly, confidential asides directly to camera.This film has heart - tentative, awkward, and tied together at the ankles - and a bit of social awareness.

reviews.title: Street Fighting Man.
reviews.content: I'm sort of glad that "Marching Powder" has been released just so I don't have to see the trailer anymore. For a British film, this has to be one of the more heavily advertised films I've ever seen - so much so that I almost didn't feel the need to actually see it, I'm so familiar with it's comedy beats.Jack (Danny Dyer) has enjoyed a life of drugs, lager, porn and football violence for most of his life. Arrested following a fight in Grimsby, he avoids jail on the understanding that he'll start to turn his life around. Truth be told, Jack is starting to consider that perhaps he's getting too old for this life anyway. He's relationship with wife Dani (Stephanie Leonidas) is struggling due to emotional absence and his lack of libido. His father-in-law (Geoff Bell) hates him, and his son (Arty Dyer) is starting to show worrying signs of following in his father's footsteps. But will his friends, and his own anger issues, allow him to change?The familiarity of the film perhaps extends beyond the oft repeated trailer. Both Dyer and Nick Love have been making films and TV in this South London; casuals; drugs and violence genre for years, with neither perhaps finding the respect they are due for continuing to work, if nothing else. "Marching Powder" is a little different because, despite how the adverts have mocked romantic comedies, that's what the film really is. It hinges not on whether he will avoid prison, but can he save his marriage. There are sub-plots though, some of which contain some genuinely disturbing moments that work alongside the comedy.Dyer is quite good in this. Admittedly he's playing an aging out 'wide boy', whilst at the same time aging out of playing 'wide boys'. But it's a gutsy performance that exposes himself quite a bit.Ultimately, like a lot of Love's films I've felt, it doesn't really add up to all that much. It hinges on a moment of violence that should, perhaps, be the final push that Jack needs but, ultimately, we do leave him pretty much as we found him. There are a few laughs along the way though.

reviews.title: A rom com with edge
reviews.content: Marching Powder is a lot of fun as it nobly tries to be a romantic comedy with a darker edge due to its subject matter. There's no mistaking what you're going to get here and the opening sequence (both animated and live action) ensures you know exactly what the next 90 minutes are going to be like. It covers quite a bit within that shorter run time and always remains engaging even if it's undoubtedly frustrating to watch the cycle repeating itself so many times.Danny Dyer's character doesn't make a strong case for any potential redemption or forgiveness so his natural charms are working overtime to keep him likeable which is the sole reason he remains a watchable presence. Every time he breaks the fourth wall it works and his self deprecating nature is also a big help. Stephanie Leonidas is the sole heart of the film as she gives Dyer too many second chances without being naive about the chances of success.Nick Love's direction manages to maintain the playful nature throughout, starting strong with an animated fairytale opening and then finding various ways to include equally fantastical flourishes. It's a hard tone to balance, moving back and forth between brutal gang violence and more lighthearted relationship shenanigans but it does a pretty good job of handling the tonal shifts. Simon Stolland's cinematography definitely helps by employing chaotic camerawork for the fights.

reviews.title: Quite literally dreadful
reviews.content: This film is so bad that I felt compelled to create an account just to leave my very first film review. From start to finish, it offers absolutely nothing of value. The storyline is incredibly pointless and lacks any depth or substance, leaving you wondering why it even exists in the first place. It's not funny, not controversial, and certainly not "kitsch" in any meaningful way. In fact, it doesn't even manage to entertain or engage the audience in the slightest. I was left frustrated and disappointed throughout. It's truly a complete waste of 90 minutes, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. This film feels like a missed opportunity and serves no real purpose other than to take up space in the cinematic world.

reviews.title: BEST FILM I HAVE SEEN IN A LONG TIME !!!
reviews.content: Absolute perfect follow-up to original Football factory as times gone on! So true to life , funny, little bit of romance just how life gets when you get old trying to recover from the old Football sniffing fun days . Danny Dyer was absolutely brilliant in it and I love the fact his son Arty played his son in it absolutely great ! Loved all the old references to the original Football factory loved the CP and the stone island clothes , bring back memories from the old days. Also love the fact they added relative mental health issues into the film with his sisters stepbrother, honestly thought it was 10 out of 10. Can't wait to watch it again to be honest.!

reviews.title: Toxic masculinity on overdrive. Fabulous film.
reviews.content: Toxic masculinity on overdrive. A fabulous film which will keep you glued to the screen throughout. Not as simplistic as it sounds, the film is well made and created in an unusual way, with filmmaking methods not seen very often. Opens as a cartoon with a character backgrounder! That sounds stupid, but it's well done and fits well with the film's slightly crazy feel.The toxic masculinity is not the woman-hating kind, far from it, this is men in self-destruct mode, alienated from a society they don't seem to understand anymore. How do they cope? Football tribalism, violence, substance abuse, outrageous banter and a total lack of restraint. Some are trapped in their lifestyle no doubt, and the central character played by Danny Dyer has a number of redeeming characteristics. He loves his wife with a passion, he gives to the homeless, he looks after a troublesome relative, he wants to improve himself.Very fast-paced film, you won't be bored, you will be shocked, you will be entertained. This film will endure long after it's cinema release and may reach cult status simply because it's refreshingly different and asks a lot of questions about men and society.On another note, would be curious to know which 'lower league' football team their team is based on. The Fox pub which is their base is actually the Admiral Vernon pub in Dagenham, but of course it's just used as as set rather than indicating where they are supposed to be based in the film narrative.

reviews.title: I'll have a pear juice geezer.....
reviews.content: Jack Jones is a man who spends his weekends getting into trouble and coked up, until an arrest forces him to confront his life.He has to make a choice between his old ways and a path towards redemption, all while dealing with his troubled brother-in-law Kenny Boy.....You either love Danny Dyer, or you hate him. But, when he makes a film with Nick Love, it's usually quite the watch. He hasn't made a film with him since the quite brilliant Outlaw, and EastEnders didn't really help his cause, but they are both back doing what they do best, making a film with lots of violence, swearing, and lots of abhorrent people you would not want to be involved with.Jack isn't a nice man, and his friends are just as bad. They spend the majority of their time starting fights, and taking drugs. But Jack has it all on a plate, and he doesn't realise it. He has a wonderful, tolerant wife, a free house, but he just doesn't see it, and the annoying thing about the film is that he doesn't see it until the last two minutes of the film.So to say he tries is a little bit of an anti climax. He spends the majority of the film taking drugs, fighting, and then saying never again, and repeat. And this guy is the protagonist.....But the majority of the people going to see this won't care about story or narrative, they want to see fighting, and remembering what it's like to be 'one of the lads', not knowing that Love is just taking the right royal liberty out of them, and in this sense, it works, but people who will love this film, just won't realise that they are being ridiculed for their immature ways, wearing silly designer clothes, trying to stay in their twenties, even though they are well past it.It's a sly Mickey take on people who are way past it, and have missed their calling on life, because they want to look like the big man.But these people just won't get the fact that they are being ridiculed.It's hilarious....

reviews.title: Meh...
reviews.content: I'm probably the demographic that this film is aimed at, middle aged male who loves the match, dressing in good clobber and has enjoyed his fair share of lads nights out and away days.But... Marching Powder is a deceiving film. The lad culture in the film feels very shoe horned in (because it's a Nick Love film it's got to have that I suppose) it didn't add anything ti the film itself other than to give them a reason to have the main character in court - which they could've done a thousand different ways. Not Dyer or Love's greatest, but maybe that was the point. The character was too old for all that bollocks. It's time to grow up.

reviews.title: Epic high octane film, with a relentless pace and outrageous black humour.
reviews.content: Epic high octane film, with a relentless pace and outrageous black humour. Lots of alternative narrative techniques to tell the story from animation to "breaking the fourth wall" (look it up!) which is reminiscent of the UK TV series Lovejoy for instance. I suspect film students would enjoy studying this film, it has a unique feel.Dark, witty humour, but drama too, sometimes quite painful but offset by the humour. Some fabulous characters, some lovable rogues and some not so lovable! It's a Rom-Com too but mainly it's about male angst, excessive testosterone trying to fit into a changing society, and failing spectacularly! Some of the scenes and dialogue are quite risqu√© to put it mildly, and that was after cuts were forced on the film.It will upset some people and that I suspect is the reason for some of the low ratings, in a nutshell the film is 'offensive' by the standards of 2025, and some will see it as a bit 'Andrew Tate', but I don't think it is. The main character is a man who loves women, i.e his long suffering wife. He does not hate women at all, he just finds it hard to relate or express himself. As a follower of 'lower league football' myself I see lots of reality in the football scenes although that kind of hooliganism is very rare now, although I don't doubt it still exists and I can see the types, obsessive people perhaps more hooked on the away travel, drinking and whatever else than the actual football itself!In summary, how not to live your life, but a fascinating study of people living the only life they know with few inhibitions or restraint. Great film, could be watched more than once, it will go under the radar at the cinema because of the cinema demographic but may be become a classic or even a cult film in the future. Lots of younger males may relate to aspects of the film but they won't go to the cinema to see it. Once it streams it will find a bigger and more appreciative audience...

reviews.title: Solid Brit Flick!
reviews.content: So, upon seeing the trailer for this back late last year, I knew this would be good somewhat given Danny Dyer was in it! The film is reminiscent of hard-hitting, brutal & raw British films like the Rise Of The Footsoldier Films!Middle-aged Jack, arrested for drugs, strives in 6 weeks to repair marriage, curb bullying in-law, & guide stepbrother Kenny Boy, but his efforts fail as life spirals out of control!I found the film to be pretty good! I knew I would like it, though I wouldn't exactly say it was amazing either! Though I will say it's above average for definitely & one you'll laugh & cry at as the main man tries to clear up his football hooligan, thuggish, drink & drug taking life-style!The film is pretty engaging & has great characters played by great actors (including the man himself) & has plenty funny one-liners, jokes, scenes & dialogue in general, especially the narration & fourth wall breaking moments!The plenty of F & C words & blinding in this film, along with some strong drug use, sex, eye candy, adult humoured moments & raw violence! So, it's pretty full on & intense stuff! Just the way I like it to be honest!The films story may not be unique, but it's good stuff all round & has a decent ending to say the least! The runtime is 1 hour & 31 minutes (91 minutes) & has some good pacing too!Overall, it's a great British Drama film you'll enjoy!8/10.

reviews.title: Dark comedy is the best description, excellent film.
reviews.content: Although Dark comedy is the best overall description for this film it is also difficult to neatly categorise. There is love, tragedy, tolerance, powerlessness, addiction and redemption there too. Some sadness must also be mentioned.The characters are real, often tragic, caught up in a life they seem unable to escape from. You can care about some of the characters despite their flaws. The awkward moments are made more palatable by the often laugh out loud dark comedy.Overall I would recommend this film, it could be watched more than once, it may even become a memorable film because it has a slightly unique feel to it. Enjoy!

reviews.title: Don't let the trailer put you off.
reviews.content: Marching Powder starts off strong with a captivating animated opening that effectively sets up its backstory with vibrant visuals and a hint of humor, providing a foundation for the rest of the film.However, the tone shifts abruptly with a rapid-cut, handheld fight scene that becomes uncomfortable to watch, especially on the big screen. The frantic pacing and shaky camera work is disorientating, pulling you out of the otherwise immersive experience.Despite what the trailer might suggest, there's much more to this film than meets the eye, and a large part of its emotional depth comes from the character of Dani, the wife. Her story and emotional journey add a layer of nuance to the narrative, making the film more than just a spectacle. Her strength and resilience give the movie a heart that might otherwise be lost amidst the chaotic scenes.In summary, Marching Powder is an unexpected gem with a unique opening, jarring but necessary fight sequences, and a powerful emotional core thanks to Dani's character. Don't let the trailer fool you-there's a compelling story here beneath the surface.

reviews.title: I do believe that the cons outweigh the pros.
reviews.content: 'Marching Powder' is exactly what one would expect from a Danny Dyer (and Nick Love) movie. I'm a little split on how I feel about it though. Most of the comedy is quite lazy and forced, though a couple of jokes did get a chuckle out of me; e.g. Dagenham.The fourth wall breaking is questionable, it kinda works for a few moments but is mostly ill-fitting and cringey. On the other hand, there is surprisingly one touching scene; it involves Kenny Boy on the blower, I genuinely felt it in the feels - very unexpected for a movie of this sort.As for the cast, Dyer is mostly good in the lead role; far from perfect, but he gives largely what you'd anticipate. Stephanie Leonidas does well, while Calum MacNab is initially iffy as the aforementioned Kenny but ends up being one of the better aspects of this 2025 release.All things considered, I think I do have to file this one under 'average' - rather than 'good'. It's somewhat of a close call granted, but I do believe that the cons outweigh the pros. The deciding factor is the plot, which basically finishes as it starts; barely any progress is made.

reviews.title: Maybe Danny Dyer should stick to Celebrity Gogglebox
reviews.content: Powered by copious amounts of lager and cocaine, Marching Powder will do little to quell the stereotyping of middle-aged football hooligans but does admittedly provide the occasional laugh amidst the gratuitous violence and drunken punch-ups. In some regards, it feels like it's harkening back to the early days of Guy Ritchie, however, not even Danny Dyer's boyish charm and undeniable screen presence - when he does manage to recapture the raw intensity that made him a star in the first place - can redeem Director Nick Love's script. Maybe one day I'll actually bring myself to watch his remake of The Sweeney if only for the car chase the Top Gear lads directed. For all the foul-mouthed aggro, the predominant tone is one of mollycoddled smugness, aiming to shock by reviving taboo language and jokes about sitting on Gary Glitter's lap, it's more toothless than dangerous but I can't deny I still had a degree of fun watching Marching Powder. It's awful, don't get me wrong, but in that oh-so-special way that makes it endearingly crap than outright crap but maybe Danny Dyer should stick to popping up on Celebrity Gogglebox now and then.

reviews.title: Messy but worthwhile Dyer/Love reunion
reviews.content: STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * AwfulJack (Danny Dyer) is a middle aged dad of one, whose only outlet remains through organised ruckuses at football matches. After getting caught up in his latest scrap, a judge orders him to get his life back in order to avoid a prison sentence. Over the coming weeks, he attempts to reconcile with his childhood love, Dani (Stephanie Leonidas), secure a construction job with Dani's dodgy dad (Geoff Bell), and reconnect with his son, whose hit double figures. But his connection with the psychotic Kenny Boy (Callum McNab) threatens to derail it all."Back in the good old days, when men had a c**k and women had a s**g..." From the off-set, it's clear that the first collaboration between Danny Dyer and director Nick Love in well over a decade, somewhat unsurprisingly, isn't going to concern itself with any sense of political correctness. After all, who are either of them to disappoint their fan base, even in what are surely more sensitive, understanding times? But then, the film is an examination of a man whom time has passed by, and so it's all the more fitting.The reunion of the directing/starring pair feels framed as a follow up to their signature piece, The Football Factory, despite featuring completely different characters in a completely new setting. In contrast to TFF's flashy, frenetic approach to its characters, Marching Powder portrays an older, more beaten down man, more honestly shown as a desperate loser with little else in his life. The tone uneasily shifts between tongue in cheek humour and heavy, more reflective drama, without the most focused plot to keep you following to the end, but somehow it does.It's a throwback reunion of old faces of the British crime genre, in front of the camera and behind it, rebelliously non-PC, messy and incoherent, but funny and wild, pleasing to those it's aimed at. ***

reviews.title: Enjoyable - but also a parable for our society.
reviews.content: So you know what to expect with Danny Dyer - and you certainly get it with this film, but you also get an added depth, insight and commentary.This film is about an old football hooligan. It reminded me of some of my life in south London. - the characters felt familiar, although the drugs weren't as prevalent. Having said that, it's about an underbelly of society "geezers" that's can't snap out of their youth and, in effect, their identity and self image created when they were young. It's about a lifetime of self destruction.The film also has another, softer side, with insight in to relationships, and to a degree, mental health.The acting (some of it just felt like people being themselves) was ok, with Dyer and Leonidis doing a decent job as a dysfunctional couple. A number of character cliches were successfully skewered - especially middle class and trendy types.This is a film about middle aged men escaping (or failing to) their youth and the collateral impact on those they love. It's almost a parable for one of the main challenges in western society at the moment.Worth a watch - but not for the sensitive!

reviews.title: Marching Powder
reviews.content: Hats off to Danny Dyer for at least putting his heart and soul into this, but as a piece of cinema it's poor, stereotypical and derivative of just about every other film he has been in - and a few that he hasn't. "Jack" is having a bit of a mid-life crisis as he realises that he's nearer the end than the beginning and hasn't much to show for it. His wife "Dani" (Stephanie Leonidas) reckons he's a waste of space and his daily regimen of lager and sniff isn't likely to change that anytime soon. A bit of routine football hooliganism sees him in front of a magistrate who gives him six weeks to get himself sorted out, else he is going to prison. Can he wean himself off his old habits and try to be a better person/husband/dad? Maybe Nick Love thinks that a constant stream of expletives makes for a good watch, but this was just puerile. There's not an hint of subtlety, no depth to the characterisation and without a doubt, the best bits are in the trails. "Jack" is a thug with few likeable qualities, and the strength of the drama between him and his wife is thrown completely under the bus when an incident with their son (Arty Dyer) should have put an end to the whole thing, but somehow just gets forgotten as what passes for a plot marches on. The whole thing has a 1980s look to it - attitudinally and aesthetically, and the occasional witty asides to the camera soon wear thin as we are presented with a slew of folks you'd cross the road to avoid. There is some humour in the script, but nowhere near enough to sustain this for what seemed like a lot longer than 90 minutes. A definite victory for hype over substance, powdery or otherwise. Sorry.

reviews.title: Edgy Rude Beligerant and Danny Dyertastic
reviews.content: Marching Powder is a wild, unapologetic ride that showcases Danny Dyer at his absolute best.
