reviews.title: A gripping and intriguing tale.
reviews.content: A crime lord seeks help from his ex-henchman to save his son from an encounter.The story starts from the first second of the movie. So, don't miss the first few minutes. The writer put his main character in a difficult situation and how he is going to escape from it was a great plot.This type of plot is not new to us but the way the writer handled the story in the screenplay was excellent.The screenplay kicked into top gear early on and kept going at almost the same pace until the climax, but the gears wore out in the last few minutes.I haven't seen any film in recent times that accurately evokes the tension created by the scenes in this film.We have to appreciate the writer for writing this adrenaline rush screenplay.Nothing is 100% perfect in this world we live in. If there is, then we could name it as a mystery.Similarly, this film can easily be criticized for its screenplay knots and one or two typical commercial cinema elements, but it cannot be labeled as an unwatchable film.All of them who acted in this film gave their extraordinary performances. From Vikram, Dhushara, and Suraj venjaramoodu to small character artists. Perfectly blended characterization and artist selection were written and selected as pitch-perfect.G. V. Prakash's background score was another main pillar after the screenplay. His work was fantastic, to be frank. This one was one of his career-best works.Cinematography has been handled fair. There are a few single-shot scenes, which were captured flawlessly. The fight choreography was decent.The art department has delivered excellent work from them as it suits this story world. Costume department work also stands out as the perfect costume sense were given as per the economic background of the characters.As whole, the best thrilling ride!

reviews.title: Well written Action Thriller
reviews.content: The movie starts with the conflict and told in an very engaging way. The audience can feel the tension throughout the movie. Great performances from the entire cast particularly loved the performances of Vikram & S. J. SuryahThere are many wow moments for the action movie lovers. The stunts are very realistic and music is very apt to the genre.Loved the cinematography of the movie. The mass moments have worked so well. Especially the police station sequence was well written and brilliantly staged by the director.Kilangu scene, pre climax portion, pre interval portion are the major highlightsOverall an fully satisfied movie from director SuArunKumar.

reviews.title: A Gripping Action Drama That Masterfully Balances Family, Ego, and Survival
reviews.content: Veera Dheera Sooran: Part 2 is a well-thought-out action gangster drama that includes all the right elements of a content-driven commercial film.The film's biggest strength lies in director S. U. Arun Kumar's ability to flesh out relatable, well-written characters and weave them into a compelling narrative that speaks volumes about human actions, their consequences, and, above all, survival instincts and it's effect on the element of family.While the film's premise might seem all too familiar as a template often seen in Tamil cinema- a hardcore guy who leaves behind a violent life is unexpectedly called upon to revisit his past to fulfill a favor for his 'ex-boss', where Arun excels as a writer is in his staging and world-building. We get all the expected commercial film tropes, but they come with depth, layers, and a portrayal of real-world issues faced by the highly convincing protagonist, Chiyaan Vikram, aka Kaali.Whether it's Kaali's helplessness, his love for his wife and family, his boiling rage, or his calm and collected nature, this is the Vikram fans have been waiting for. Unlike his previous roles where he physically transformed and embraced multiple avatars, Vikram here stays true to his strongest suit: portraying a common man facing uncommon problems.The actor is unstoppable. This is most evident in a brilliant single-shot sequence, where Kaali and Kannan (Suraj Venjaramoodu) are held captive, manage to flee from police custody, and ultimately find SP Arunagiri (SJ Suryah) wounded and hiding under a bridge, all ending with a crashing jeep that is up in flames. This entire sequence is masterfully shot, and Vikram's ability to emote - showcasing despair, helplessness, and subtle heroism - in the face of overwhelming circumstances is a testament to his talent.The film unfolds like a massive jungle filled with hungry 'animals,' relying heavily on its core characters' respective agendas. Each one is convincing in their respective roles, from the selfish 'Periyavar' (Prudhvi Raj) and the reckless son, Kannan, to the blindly loyal and malleable Venkat, and even Kannan's doting younger sister. The family dynamics and nature of each individual is crafted exceptionally well.On the flip side, though not much of a complaint, both Dushara Vijayan as Kalaivaani and SJ Suryah as SP Arunagiri, don't quite surprise us in their respective roles. They do justice to their characters, but perhaps their previous performances have set high benchmarks.That said, nearly everything that works for VDS: Part 2 can be credited to the strong screenwriting and the complementary cinematography. Despite nearly 80% of the film taking place at night in the dark, we never feel like we're missing anything visually.While not directly comparable, the film strongly evokes the feel of movies like director Suseenthiran's Paandiya Naadu (2013), Naan Mahaan Alla (2010), or even Pandiraj's Kathakali (2016), where intense and engaging events unfold around unassuming protagonists who are forced into a world of blood, violence, and survival to protect their families.The conflicts faced by our lead character and his family are well established throughout the movie. Whether it's the shift in Kaali's once cheerful family, the naming of his second child 'Dilip' in memory of his fallen friend, or the muscle memory that pushes the family to flee once again towards the end, it is clear that the 'scars of the past' still haunt them.And at the heart of it all is family - the glue that holds everything together. Every action taken by these ego-driven, rage-fueled men comes with a price, often paid by the family and women. Periyavar, for instance, says, "Pulla usura vida maanam onnum perusu illai" (Prestige counts for nothing when compared to your child's life). Even the selfish Kannan, in a moment of vulnerability, pleads with SJ Suryah's cop character, claiming he is a family man and can't die for that reason.Our protagonist, Kaali, too, repeatedly emphasizes safeguarding his family first amidst the chaos. These small but powerful moments highlight director Arun's writing prowess and his emphasis on the theme of family. The film is full of setups that pay off like a blast (no pun intended) in the end, most notably the tension surrounding the code worded 'kezhangu,' which is teased upon from the beginning.The director opens the movie with a note saying, "Based on true events," and the deeper meaning of those words is reflected well. The film explores the idea that, beneath the violence, male ego, and gangsterism, the drive for revenge, blood, and payback often comes down to protecting one's family. What begins with a scene of a helpless wife searching for her husband, ends with a helpless husband/father searching for a new life for his family. The narrative's progression is convincingly conveyed through the writing.Overall, Veera Dheera Sooran: Part 2 is definitely a must-watch, as it balances the commercial appeal of a theater-worthy experience with a commitment to redefining what it means for a Tamil film to be hero-driven.While the necessity of a Veera Dheera Sooran: Part 1 prequel remains questionable, given the oversharing done in the flashback portions of the current movie, the existing 'Part 2' itself already does enough to successfully represent a drama-filled action entertainer.

reviews.title: Fantastic actors and director give a dull output far from expectations
reviews.content: What started as a nice plot which pricked the audience to wait for a nice twist and turn ended a dud movie with more predictable turns and finally killing everyone..what is disappointing is about the story plot which made the audience wait for a flashback which ends in a weak story plot and extending the same in a more predictable screenplay making at a point the movie to end .... The movie finally ends as expected and not probing in a continuing story for next part but this itself is part 2 ... Not sure about any interesting story for a part 1... What is good about the movie is VIKRAM who has toned down for his age and definitely looks handsome and believable.... Rest of the cast was interesting but in a way I call them wasted with no strong plots around them... Overall a more dull and serious watch lengthy as well.... The director did better in his first movie Sethupathi with a very good plot and also in chithha... This is a disappointing outing for him..

reviews.title: Good one for Vikram's hard work.
reviews.content: The film boasts a captivating screenplay filled with intense, gripping scenes and powerful dialogues that leave a lasting impact. The stellar performances of actors like Vikram, SJ Surya, Sukumaran, and Prudhvirajan add depth and authenticity to their respective roles, showcasing their versatility and talent. Balaji's portrayal of the character Venkat stands out for its natural and effortless execution, making the character relatable and believable. The background score plays a crucial role in enhancing the emotional weight of the film, seamlessly complementing the narrative and taking the cinematic experience to a whole new level. Director Arunkumar deserves special recognition for crafting a compelling story, skillfully directing the cast, and ensuring that every character is portrayed with precision and without any flaws, resulting in a truly remarkable film.

reviews.title: Worth it üëå
reviews.content: Vikram delivers a career-defining performance in this year's standout action-entertainer. The film seamlessly blends thrilling action sequences with compelling narrative, ensuring a captivating cinematic experience. Each scene is meticulously crafted, showcasing Vikram's versatility and intensity. The supporting cast complements his brilliance, contributing to the film's overall impact. reviews.title: Vikram's best movie in years
reviews.content: Ven though the story itself is not anything new, the screenplay brilliantly makes it feel fresh. The way, the film shows the events of one night slowly giving the audience information piece by piece and letting us solve the puzzle for the most part while keeping the tension alive was so fun. The rawness of everything around was elevated by the great performances, obviously expected from Vikram but also most of the other cast. The flashback portion in the middle felt a little bit unnecessary and slowed down the film but the way it ended was satisfactory. The drama and the rawness were strong points of the film but the action itself was mostly just okay when everything surrounding it was really great. The action scene near the end was a bit of a mess. Narratively, it makes sense because how even at that point the characters are revealing their intents and character by their actions but it was shot in a weird way. The way a lot of small, small things are connected to the main story, a reveal at the very end which shows how everything happened because of coincidences that were meant to be and connected to each other way more than we thought was very interesting as well as giving a bit of levity after all the brutality.The decision to call this Part 2 still feels a bit gimmicky and just a promotion tactic. There's not really much need for a part 1 but if they make it, they better make it worthy of this.I am happy to finally watch a Vikram film from the theater and be satisfied. The screenplay was brilliant but there were a few compromises without which this could've been truly great.

reviews.title: A High-Intensity Ride with Unanswered Questions
reviews.content: From the very first scene, Veera Soora Dhreeran feels intense and keeps the audience hooked. Suraj, on the other hand, looks completely different from his past roles, which is a nice surprise. The movie also features many Malayalam actors, which is interesting to see in a Tamil film.Vikram's physique is just amazing! He looks powerful, and his action scenes are fantastic. The second half of the movie starts with emotional moments, which is a good change. However, some of the emotions felt confusing, and I couldn't fully connect with them. The actress's acting felt too much in many scenes, making it hard to enjoy certain moments.Towards the climax, the movie starts to feel a bit slow and confusing. From the beginning, the film drops hints that make us think everything will be explained in the end. But by the time the movie finishes, some things are still unclear. This might be because the movie is in two parts, and we may get answers in the next one.Overall, Veera Soora Dhreeran is an intense action drama with strong performances. But some emotional scenes feel disconnected and the ending leaves many questions unanswered. If you enjoy action-packed films, it's worth watching in theatres.

reviews.title: "A Gripping Spectacle: Veer Dheera Sooran's Explosive Impact"
reviews.content: "Veer Dheera Sooran" explodes onto the screen with a ferocity that leaves you breathless. Director Arun Kumar delivers a relentless action spectacle, a cinematic adrenaline rush that demands to be experienced on the grandest canvas possible. From the opening scene, the film grips you with its sheer intensity, promising a ride that's as thrilling as it is visceral.Vikram, in a performance that can only be described as volcanic, unleashes a raw, untamed energy. Every muscle, every glance, every roar is imbued with a primal power. He doesn't just play the character; he embodies him, becoming a force of nature. Scenes showcasing his physical prowess and emotional depth are nothing short of iconic. Dusheera Vijayan delivers a solid performance that complements Vikram's intensity, adding a layer of depth to the narrative.But it's SJ Surya who truly steals the show. His portrayal of the police officer is a masterclass in controlled intensity. He elevates every scene with his nuanced performance, showcasing a depth and maturity that cements his place as one of Tamil cinema's finest. This is a performance destined for national recognition, a testament to his consistent evolution as an actor. And then there's Sooraj, a revelation from Malayalam cinema. His villainous debut is nothing short of menacing. He commands the screen with a chilling presence, signaling the arrival of a formidable new antagonist in Tamil cinema.GV Prakash Kumar's music is the film's beating heart. The background score is a symphony of raw emotion, amplifying every pulse-pounding moment. It's reminiscent of his iconic works like "Ayirathil Oruvan," "Veyil," "Raja Rani," "Aadukalam," and "Polladavan," but with a new level of intensity. The sound mixing is impeccable, further enhancing the film's immersive quality. This is, without a doubt, a score that deserves serious consideration for a National Award. The stunt sequences are a visual feast, pushing the boundaries of action choreography. They are "out of the box", innovative and perfectly executed, adding to the high energy feel of the movie.Arun Kumar's direction is sharp and focused. He navigates the film's scale with confidence, delivering a tightly paced narrative that never loses its grip. The film's "grippy" nature, its ability to hold your attention from start to finish, is a testament to his directorial prowess."Veer Dheera Sooran" is more than just an action film; it's an experience. It's a cinematic blitz that leaves you exhilarated and wanting more. With stellar performances, a breathtaking score, and groundbreaking action sequences, this film is a must-watch for any fan of high-octane cinema. Don't miss this one in theaters.

reviews.title: A Family Thriller with an Edge
reviews.content: Veera Dheera Sooran is a unique take on the thriller genre, with all the right ingredients to keep you on the edge of your seat. Though branded as an action thriller, it surprises by blending family drama with intense suspense. It's rare for a film to keep you hooked without relying on action in the first half, yet this one does just that, cleverly using restraint to build tension and make the eventual action feel earned.The film takes its time to establish the characters, the atmosphere, and the world they inhabit, and it does so wonderfully. Even without grand action sequences initially, Veera Dheera Sooran remains engrossing, with the first half maintaining a forward momentum that keeps you invested.Vikram is on fire, delivering one standout performance after another in recent years-Mahaan, PS1 and PS2, Thangalaan. In Veera Dheera Sooran, he adds incredible depth to a genre often dominated by spectacle. His performance grounds the film, and his chemistry with the effervescent Dushara brings an emotional authenticity to their relationship. Together, with the Mom character and the two kids, they create a powerful family dynamic that keeps you deeply invested in their journey, balancing both the tension and drama effortlessly.SJ Suryah adds yet another dimension to his acting repertoire. From Iravi and Jackie Pandian to his cunning portrayal of Arunagiri in VDS, his range is remarkable. Suraj Venjaramoodu delivers a fantastic Tamil debut, conveying so much through his eyes, while Prudhviraj's character arc adds a sinister, multi-layered complexity. Another standout performance is from Venkat, who holds his own brilliantly against Vikram in key scenes. Two moments in particular highlight his strength-first, the intense landmine (Kizhangu) sequence, and second, the gripping climax where Vikram confronts, chases, and ultimately kills him.The film's pacing and buildup are intricately woven through the relationships between these characters, especially the constant push and pull between loyalty, trust, and betrayal. From the lead to the supporting cast, every character has a well-developed arc that adds layers to the story.What stands out in Veera Dheera Sooran is how it subverts genre expectations. While it fits within the action-thriller mold, it doesn't rely on the usual mass tropes we often associate with such films. Instead, it's far more grounded and layered, blending family dynamics with crime and suspense in a thoughtful, nuanced way. The attention to detail is what makes it so rewarding, and the screenplay doesn't hold your hand-mysteries and small details unfold naturally, keeping you engaged in a way that few thrillers manage to do.SU Arun Kumar has truly redeemed himself since Chittha. With VDS, he has elevated his craft to the next level. He's one of the new-age directors who knows how to scale up from smaller films to larger ones while keeping the storytelling grounded and realistic.That said, the film's final payoff, while impactful, doesn't entirely deliver the emotional release that it seems to be building toward. It's like having a delicious full-course meal where the dessert, though tasty, doesn't quite live up to the expectations set by the main course. The buildup was compelling enough that the ending felt a little bit like it could have used a bit more punch. But that's a minor quibble in an otherwise well-executed movie.In conclusion, VDS is a film that deserves to be experienced in theatres. It's an ambitious and refreshing take on the thriller genre, one that skillfully mixes family drama with crime thriller elements, keeping you engaged throughout. Despite a slightly underwhelming payoff, the film has more than enough to offer in terms of performances, tension, and world-building. If you're looking for a movie that keeps you hooked from start to finish, this is a must-watch in theatres.

reviews.title: Glad I wasn't disappointed.
reviews.content: Henry Danger: The Movie.First of all, I am very glad that this didn't turn out to be such a disappointment like The Thundermans. The CGI is really impressive than I'd expected. And I love how the story sort of leans on how Henry was made to learn how it was like "being Jasper" - the Unappreciated Sidekick, test and renew their friendship, it's superb. The makeup and the clothing/costumes? Amazing!. Unlike The Thundermans, which seemed geared toward a younger audience despite its older fan base, Henry Danger: The Movie feels like it matured alongside its viewers. It balances nostalgia with fresh, engaging content, making it enjoyable for longtime fans and new viewers alike. And the actors are all amazing, I liked piper as the Vampire and love Jasper's maturity (I did not really like his 'super power' thoüíÄ) and I'd have loved to see Charlotte in this. reviews.title: Better than expected!
reviews.content:
This was a great movie all around. The story has depth and emotion, the action sequences were well put together, the original character's chemistry was all still there, and they managed to make it funny.Spoilers Below!Pros:
My favorite part was seeing Jasper recognized as the good friend he has always been. He is more mature and not just the goofy friend anymore. Love that for his character. Henry has always had a big heart but everyone can lose their way sometimes and his character growth was very heart warming. I love they gave Henry a sidekick and the two were very funny together...it reminded me of Henry and Ray. Having a kid sidekick (and her character creating the plot) was really what made this a kids movie, everything else more mature...which was great. The comedy was there but not forced, they did a great job of keeping it in without it being stupid comedy. I laughed hard at a few parts. It felt a lot like the musical. They hated being in a musical and they hated being stuck in a kid's fan fiction stories. It was a great idea to create that story line. The last action sequence got a little intense which I wasn't expecting, but it was good. To top off an already good movie...they left it with a unexpected cliffhanger, which was awesome.Cons:
Of course, we all missed Charlotte. Everyone always wanted to see Henry and Charlotte as a couple (especially since they are adults now), but that wouldn't have fit in this story. There was just too much already going on to go into depth with that too.Overall, this is a solid and entertaining movie for fans of the show.

reviews.title: Did NOT Disappoint!
reviews.content: I was a little skeptical as it started. The storyline and the unexpected difference in Henry's personality at the beginning. It felt lacking outside of the entire cast and setting of the tv show, but as the movie unfolded it was very enjoyable to watch Henry learn his lesson and form new relationships. WE LOVE FRANKINI!!Jasper and Henry's friendship is special and it was perfect that it took center stage for this production.The ending was unexpected and... awesome... it was like being wrapped in a big hug! My daughter's and I have been longtime fans and hope that there will be further developments very quickly to continue the story!

reviews.title: Nostalgic Comeback That Feels Good
reviews.content: This is the long awaited film about Henry Danger and I feel it is worth the hype. The series has been a staple of my childhood and it's good that it actually got a feature length film. The end of the original show has left plenty of room for Henry's story to continue and this definitely was the continuation we deserved. It focuses on Henry's journey now in Dystopia and getting entangled with a super fan. It does have some feel of the original but a little more serious. Seems to have matured with those who grew up with the original series (like I did). Thundermans Return had the feel of the original Thundermans series but doesn't feel like it matured with those who grew up with the original series. Henry Danger the Movie does seem to be emotionally tense at times and leaves you sitting at the edge of your seat, feeling like a couple two parter episodes of the original show. It does have some multiversal themes to it as we see a couple versions of the characters that aren't like what we've come to know. It does seem to tease a future installment. I like to see another film or two with more of the original cast of the original Henry Danger returning with everything we saw in this. This comeback does feel good!

reviews.title: Oh boy!
reviews.content:
I'm going to start off by saying that I'm not a fan of the Henry Danger Show that aired on Nickelodeon. I did like it as a kid, but it is one of those kids show that hasn't aged well for obvious reasons, so when I heard about this movie, I knew it was going to be bad. Well, I just finished watching the movie and it was just as bad as I expected it to be.Positives for Henry Danger: The Movie (2025):
I can see fans of the show having some dumb fun with the movie. That's all I have to say for the positives.Negatives for Henry Danger: The Movie (2025):
The main plot of the movie is really dumb to where it felt like someone from Paramount was scrolling on the internet, found someone's dumb fanfiction and decided to convert it to a movie. The characters are just as stupid and nonsensical as they were in the show. The villains are laughably terrible where I could beat them with a single punch. The dialogue is cringe worthy and feels like a first draft. And finally, the movie ends on a note that teases a sequel or new tv show that will be just as stupid as this movie.Overall, Henry Danger: The Movie (2025) was clearly not made for me especially since I hate the original show and while I understand that it was made for kids, I've seen kids movies and tv shows that scan be for adults and kids.

reviews.title: It was nice
reviews.content: Henry Danger: The Movie was surprisingly solid-way better than I expected for a Nickelodeon movie. Honestly, it felt like they finally gave this series the treatment it deserved. The humor? On point. The action? Actually impressive. And the characters? They brought their A-game.Jace Norman as Henry didn't miss a beat. It's like he never left the role, and his chemistry with the rest of the cast was perfect. Even the new addition, Missy, fit right in without feeling forced. The stakes were bigger, the visuals were slicker, and you could tell they had a real budget this time. It wasn't just some over-the-top kids' movie-they found a way to keep it fun without losing the charm of the original show.It's not perfect, obviously. Some moments were predictable, but honestly? It didn't even matter. I was laughing, I was invested, and I walked out of the theater thinking, "That was actually really good." For what it is-a movie based on a Nickelodeon show-it's an absolute win. Fans of Henry Danger are going to love it, but even if you're just there for a good time, it won't disappoint.

reviews.title: Best movie it helped relive my childhood üòÖüòÖ
reviews.content: The Henry Danger movie is definitely a 10/10, and here's why. As someone who watched the show, the movie brought back everything fans loved but made it even bigger and better. It had action, comedy, and emotional moments that made it fun for everyone, whether you were a fan of the show or not. First of all, the movie stayed true to the show while also giving us something new. The show was always funny, exciting, and full of great characters, and the movie gave us even more of that. Captain Man and Kid Danger were as amazing as ever. Their jokes and teamwork were so fun to watch, and their bond felt stronger than ever. It reminded fans why they loved these characters so much, but it also showed them growing and facing bigger challenges. It felt like we were seeing a new side of them, which made it special. The story of the movie was another reason it was so great. It didn't feel like just a longer version of an episode-it felt like a real adventure. The stakes were higher, the danger was bigger, and the villain was actually really interesting. The action scenes were exciting, but there were also some twists that kept things surprising. The movie also had emotional moments that made you care about the characters even more. The pacing was just right, so there was never a boring moment, and it kept you hooked the whole time. One of the best things about the movie was how it worked for everyone. Fans of the show got to see their favorite characters and fun Easter eggs, but new viewers could enjoy it too because the story stood on its own. It was the perfect mix of old and new, which is really hard to do, but they nailed it. In the end, the Henry Danger movie was everything fans could've wanted. It was funny, action-packed, and even emotional at times. It showed how much effort was put into making something that would make fans happy, and it's a movie that will stick with them for a long time. It's easy to see why so many people loved it-because it was just that good.

reviews.title: Somewhat Effective Nostalgia Bait
reviews.content: *SPOILER ALERT* It was pretty cool to see Henry grown up fighting crime where we left off with him. I thought the main plot point of Jasper living in Henry's shadow was interesting, but I feel like it doesn't work. Henry spent years in Captain Man's shadow and we saw how it got to Henry sometimes, so I feel that he should understand Jasper's frustration being in his shadow and not getting enough credit better since he was once there. Just seems a bit out of character for Henry. As for his adventure with Missy, it was entertaining. I feel like there were better directions to take this movie, for example the conflict between Henry and Jasper could've been something they worked through as they fought Blackout throughout the movie, not just at the beginning and end. Blackout was much more intriguing than the other villains. Missy's character wasn't unlikable, but not very interesting. Jumping from different worlds wasn't as fun as you think it would be. It was cool to see Henry see different versions of Jasper and realize that they're always there for him no matter what world, but the rest of it wasn't too interesting. I guess they are supposed to be 2D villains, but the vampire Piper and coach villains were lame. And Frankini felt very shoehorned into the movie. He was in it for an uncomfortable amount and his presence outside of his own weird club felt very unnatural. His musical number went on for too long as well, it wasn't good regardless. I feels like Nick is continuing to push their gay character down our throats to convince us they're inclusive. There wasn't too much action, but Jasper kicking butt and holding his own against the vampires and coach was cool to see, which was the most action we saw. It felt like the movie purposely avoided mild violence, which the show never strayed from. Like Henry is a trained fighter, he shouldn't have an issue holding his own instead of hesitating against a mean version of his sister. The two things that made me fall in love with the original show was the action and humor. This movie doesn't have much action, and I can't recall a single instance when I smirk or scoffed because the humor is nonexistent. Henry Danger is a light-hearted show. I get Henry is older, but without any humor this movie feels very foreign compared to even Danger Force. Anyways the best parts of the movie were the five minutes at the end and beginning. The main part of the movie struggled to keep me invested. It was cool to see Henry and the other legacy characters, but they weren't as interesting as in the show. I wish they would've left the Henry Danger show as it is, this movie isn't necessary and doesn't add much to where we left off. It looks like another movie or show is coming, which is disappointing. In the end Jasper did get credit from Henry, which was cool, but again it felt like the tension between them was out of character for both of them. But I will admit I did smirk at the end when Captain Man appeared. Overall this movie isn't unwatchable, just boring. It didn't go in with high expectations anyways. There was better ways to go about this movie.

reviews.title: Feels Bad!
reviews.content: I'm only providing spoilers for a certain cameo at the end. The rest of the review will remain as spoiler-free as possible.If "Danger Force" wasn't the first IMDb review I've ever done, I would've skipped this made-for-TV and streaming film. After seeing it, I wish I didn't watch it altogether. The fact that this is the first 2025 movie I'm seeing makes it hurt worse.Though Dan Schnieder is a degenerate who should be in jail by now, he unfortunately was vital in most people's childhoods through shows like "Henry Danger." I used to love that show, but its spinoff, "Danger Force," was so awful that it made me lose complete faith in both the "Henry Danger" franchise and Nickelodeon. I haven't even watched SpongeBob for four years. However, curiosity led to me seeing this film. Do I regret seeing it? Yes, but it's worth writing a review about.Let's start with the positives. Jace Norman remains likable as Henry Hart, while the rest of the actors did skillfully as their respective characters.I found the very brief action to be solid. I understand it's TV-PG and made for kids, which is the target demographic of "Henry Danger," but considering they wanted to make a film and the IMDb plot synopsis describes this as a theatrical movie at the time of writing, I expected more action. I'll still give the action credit as a positive, as minimal as it may be.I also thought there were two scenes, the Syrup Wars story and the ending, where Christopher Charles Kempinski's cinematography was stellar. The rest of the cinematography was unmemorable and generic, but again, I'm discussing the positives.Finally, a cameo at the end made me happy, but it played into the negatives.Screw it; let's get into why this film is trash! First, the narrative is woefully dumb. It amounts to a Kid Danger fan bringing Henry into a multiverse of fan fiction to fight crime alongside her. In a world where multiverse stories are either universally unwanted or starting to become less interesting, "Henry Danger: The Movie" does nothing new. Most of the universes feature the same antagonists - intentionally so, I know - so it's only the settings they're in that are changing. It eventually becomes a rinse-and-repeat formula that doesn't make sense. They enter different worlds, yet I believe that the vampire version of Piper remains the same. I'm struggling to find ways to describe how stupid the plot is. I'll guarantee you'll see how truly absurd this film is once you see it. Depending on who you are, don't.Outside of one joke, the humor is child's play. I know this is for children, but if you're making a movie based on a show I liked, I'll watch it. Most of the jokes feel juvenile and feel as if they lack that "Henry Danger" writing. I'm not asking Dan Schnieder to make this thing because he shouldn't be allowed back in Hollywood, let alone work with kids. It's a noticeable difference, but if Schnieder was responsible for the show's humor, keep the film's jokes as they are. There's more that makes this movie wrong to talk about that doesn't revolve around its differences compared to the show, but man, they're just some dumb lines that I want you to hear:"Help, I'm being crimed!""Care to join Bite Club? It's to die for!""Ironically, I'm about to black out."Have you ever wanted to hear no less than five dad-vibe mustache jokes that make zero sense? If you answered no, too bad, because they're in here!I felt the absence of Cooper Barnes' Captain Man. He only shows up at the end as a cameo appearance. Captain Man being a central character would've made this movie feel more worthy of the "Henry Danger" name. As is, it feels like a desperate setup for another film. I guess I'll watch it when it comes out, but it reeks of missed potential, and that's what this film is. It's a movie that caters exclusively to kids, rarely matures with its 2010s audience, and has no lasting impact on the franchise outside of its ending sequence. It's a side quest with characters who don't deserve to be present in said adventure.That's perhaps a sad thing about growing up. Things you may have loved as a kid have aged for the worse, and you can't help but see nothing but negatives from it. I bet if I watched "Henry Danger" today, its humor would have aged, and that's without the dark Schnieder context. Knowing he was involved with a project will make it worse, so that's more reason not to rewatch it.Overall, I didn't enjoy "Henry Danger: The Movie." It may work for you, but this was a poor choice for my first 2025 film. I may check out its potential sequel, but it reminds me why I stopped watching Nickelodeon. This stuff isn't for me anymore, and that's okay, but I have to judge this as a film.Technically, it's okay. There's nothing objectively wrong with the film, only this time, it seems to have a much larger budget than the TV projects that came before it. The acting, the directing, and (some) perfect cinematography make for a 5/10 technical score.For the enjoyment score, 3/10. Once more, this franchise is no longer for me. You may have a different enjoyment score, and that's okay. However, I felt I would've gained nothing from this experience if I didn't write a review. If you stopped watching Nickelodeon half a decade ago, you likely won't have a good time. Otherwise, the chances of you having an entertaining time are higher!I hope that Jace Norman finds work outside of Nickelodeon. He's an actor who I feel has the potential to do more with his talents. I grew up watching his show and many of the Nickelodeon movies he made, such as "Splitting Adam," "Rufus," "Rufus 2," "Blurt," and "Bixler High Private Eye." Norman's acting credits are almost nothing but programs related to Nickelodeon. If he loves working for the network and wants to continue, I respect his decision. I'm only saying if A24 or Neon were to cast him in one of their projects, it'd be the perfect opportunity for Norman to become more than what he became popular for. I know I may have done almost nothing but tear apart this movie, but it's important to note that none of the negatives are the fault of any of the actors. Norman, if you're reading this, thank you for making my childhood. I hope you continue doing great things; you'll always be one of my childhood heroes.

reviews.title: Was great for nostalgia but not the best
reviews.content: While I was never quite into the original Henry Danger/Danger Force as it aired after I was aged out of the target demographic, I did watch a decent amount of episodes of each to understand/appreciate each enough and like other movies based on TV shows that have come out in recent years, I feel this one was done right with what the show covered.The other 2 movies that immediately come to mind are Thundermans Return and Teen Wolf: The Movie (based on the MTV show). With Thundermans Return, it more or less is the sequel to the series revisiting the universe of the original show. With Teen Wolf, it felt similar to the Henry Danger Movie. While it did explore what key characters were doing and expanding on the original show (and continuing the continuity they had at the end) it wasn't the movie the fans would have wanted since it continued a plot line already dealt with.While this isn't the same as that, it was a good mix between the two. It continued the continuity but also expanded the universe/characters without having to revist Swellview locations or bringing back all the familiar characters from the original show. There are some reviews that say "it wasn't based on the original series" or "they needed Captain Man in it" but not having both of those made it better. For one, at the end of Danger Force, Captain Man retired so the 30 second cameo we got at the end will be well explored in a (hopeful) sequel since it will be interesting to see what would cause him to come out of said retirement. Also, we already knew what happened to Henry during Danger Force so it was interesting to see that side of it explored a bit more.Another review mentioned about Henry not recognizing that Jasper was living in the shadow, but it also made sense since even though he himself was a sidekick, he never felt like he was in a shadow, just that he didn't live his own life.Overall, the movie had hits and misses and I only wish that they explored how Missy was able to figure out the identies a bit more.

reviews.title: Loved it
reviews.content: I absolutely loved *The Henry Danger Movie* for several reasons. First, it brought back all the iconic characters from the show, and seeing them in an exciting, action-packed movie format was incredible. The plot was fun and engaging, with a perfect blend of humor, suspense, and heartwarming moments. The special effects and action scenes were impressive, keeping me on the edge of my seat. I also appreciated how the movie stayed true to the spirit of the original series, while also delivering new, fresh content. reviews.title: Henry Danger: The Movie
reviews.content: Anyone else think that if Justin Timberlake and Brendan Fraser had conceived a love child, it'd be Jace Norman? Well that's all that really preoccupied me as this otherwise unremarkable and messy teen drama took us on its own version of colourful time travel. That's because the hero manages to lose his powers to his malevolent sister (Ella Anderson) thanks to the enthusiastic interference of new fan "Missy" (Glee Dango) and to his fed up cohort "Jasper" (Sean Ryan Fox) who is fed up doing all the work whilst his handsome buddy takes all the glory. Well in this alternative world, it's "Jasper" who kicks ass and it means that "Henry" is going to have to eat loads of humble pie if he is to convince his "new" friends to help him go back to the old days! Personally, I think I'd have told him to take an hike but this is Nickelodeon remember so even the nasties are fairly nice as all that is missing is a custard pie fight. Indeed, it only narrowly avoids becoming an human version of a "Ninja Turtles" movie. I'm not the demographic, so I'm not really the man to say - but I suspect this is only for die-hard fans of the television series and/or the all-American Norman.

reviews.title: Jongli Review: Siam Ahmed's Most Transformative Role Yet
reviews.content: In the ever-evolving landscape of Bangladeshi cinema, Jongli (2025) emerges as a bold and visceral film that breaks away from conventional formulas. Released during Eid-ul-Fitr, the movie showcases a gritty, emotionally charged narrative led by Siam Ahmed in one of his most transformative performances to date. Directed by M Raahim, Jongli dives deep into primal human instincts, exploring survival, alienation, and redemption with a level of intensity rarely seen in mainstream Dhallywood productions.At the heart of Jongli is the story of a man disconnected from society and tormented by the scars of his past. Though the film doesn't rely on a highly structured or traditional plotline, it focuses instead on the emotional and psychological journey of its central character. Siam Ahmed plays a man wrestling with his identity, purpose, and relationships, particularly those tied to his broken family and a world that never quite accepted him. The narrative is raw, unfolding in a grim and often unforgiving setting that mirrors the protagonist's internal struggles.Siam Ahmed delivers a powerhouse performance that is both physically and emotionally taxing. Known for his charming boy-next-door persona in earlier roles, Ahmed completely shatters that image in Jongli. He committed himself to the character long before the cameras rolled, spending over six months in preparation. This included a dramatic physical transformation-growing out his hair and beard, toning down his physique, and embracing a more rugged appearance. But more impressive than the physical change is the emotional depth he brings to the role. He portrays his character's pain, rage, and isolation with subtlety and conviction, making every expression and silence speak volumes. It's a haunting performance that lingers with the viewer long after the film ends.Director M Raahim deserves credit for constructing a cinematic experience that is both atmospheric and grounded. His approach to storytelling prioritizes emotional authenticity over spectacle. The film's pacing is deliberate, allowing scenes to breathe and emotions to simmer. The cinematography is stark and evocative, using a muted color palette and natural lighting to emphasize the bleakness of the protagonist's world. Every frame feels intentional, from wide shots of desolate landscapes to intimate close-ups that capture the slightest shifts in expression. Raahim doesn't shy away from discomfort-in fact, he leans into it, forcing the audience to confront the same harsh realities the characters face.One of the film's strengths lies in its supporting performances, particularly from Shobnom Bubly. As the female lead, she brings warmth and complexity to a role that could have easily been one-dimensional. Her character serves not as a romantic interest in the traditional sense, but as a mirror to the protagonist's fractured humanity. Their chemistry on screen is understated but emotionally charged, and their interactions add depth to the broader themes of trust, forgiveness, and reconnection. The supporting cast is strong across the board, grounding the film in realism and reinforcing the weight of the protagonist's journey.The music and sound design in Jongli play an essential role in building the film's atmosphere. Rather than dominating the scenes, the soundtrack subtly underscores emotional beats, enhancing the audience's immersion. Ambient sounds, such as the rustle of trees or distant calls in the wilderness, are used to great effect, creating a soundscape that feels organic and intense. One of the standout musical moments is the song "Ami To Jongli," which encapsulates the core of the character's internal chaos while also serving as a thematic anchor.Audience reception to Jongli has been overwhelmingly positive. Viewers have praised the film not only for its cinematic quality but also for its emotional resonance. Many have commented on how the themes of father-son relationships, estrangement, and mental health touched a chord, particularly in a cultural context where such topics are often avoided. The film's release was met with sold-out shows and extended screenings, as word of mouth helped it build a loyal and emotionally invested audience. Siam Ahmed himself noted in interviews that the film "didn't just find an audience, it built one," underscoring the impact Jongli had on viewers willing to engage with more challenging narratives.Ultimately, Jongli is more than just a film-it's a cinematic experience that dares to be different. It strips away the gloss and glamour often associated with Eid releases, opting instead for a raw, introspective tale about the parts of ourselves we often try to hide. Siam Ahmed's commitment to his role, coupled with M Raahim's vision and a solid ensemble cast, results in a film that is deeply affecting, visually arresting, and narratively daring. It sets a new benchmark for character-driven storytelling in Bangladeshi cinema and proves that the industry is capable of producing work that is both artistically ambitious and emotionally truthful. For audiences looking for substance, Jongli is not to be missed.

reviews.title: Courageous but failed attempt
reviews.content: Jacqueline Fernandez and Sonu Sood's latest collaboration is an unfortunate misstep, plagued by weak performances and poor direction. At its core, the film attempts to weave a story of love, redemption, and sacrifice. However, the lack of chemistry between the leads and an unconvincing execution prevents the story from resonating.Jacqueline plays a woman caught between her tragic past and an uncertain future, but her performance does little to bring this emotional journey to life. Her portrayal feels flat, with minimal effort to convey the depth of her character's struggles. This isn't surprising, as Jacqueline's acting has consistently been limited, lacking the ability to immerse audiences in her roles. This film is no exception-her inability to evoke genuine emotion weakens pivotal scenes.Sonu Sood, who also directs, plays a heroic figure determined to help her overcome her challenges. His character has moments that could have been compelling, but his performance is overly theatrical at times and devoid of nuance. As a director, his inexperience is evident. The film suffers from uneven pacing, clunky transitions, and poorly choreographed action sequences that feel more like filler than meaningful additions to the plot.The story, which had the potential to explore themes of healing and hope, ends up feeling superficial. The screenplay fails to dig deep into the characters' motivations or relationships, leaving the audience disconnected from their journey. The climax, meant to be emotional and uplifting, feels rushed and hollow due to the lack of buildup.In the end, this film highlights Jacqueline's consistent shortcomings as an actor and Sonu's growing pains as a director. Both need to reconsider their approach to projects like this. Stronger storytelling, better character development, and more authentic performances could have saved this film from being so forgettable. Overall, this film fails to leave a lasting impression, weighed down by Jacqueline Fernandez's lackluster acting and Sonu Sood's uneven direction. While it might hold some appeal for Bollywood audiences accustomed to melodramatic storytelling, even within that context, it falls short of delivering anything memorable. On an international level, the film barely scrapes by with a 3/10, reflecting its weak performances, clich√©d plot, and amateur execution. For Bollywood standards, it might merit a slightly more generous 5/10, as it aligns with some of the industry's formulaic offerings. However, it ultimately lacks the substance and finesse to stand out in either context.

reviews.title: A Promising Start That Fizzles Out Into Mindless Action
reviews.content: I went in with decent expectations, especially considering its premise. The film quickly devolves into nothing more than a series of mindless gunfights, to the point where it felt like I was watching someone play a third-person shooter video game. It was eventually clear that the filmmakers were heavily inspired by the action sequences in Animal, but unlike that film, Fateh failed to make those scenes anything more than repetitive and tiring.The forced attempts at comedy during action scenes didn't land at all. In fact, they felt out of place and just awkward. As for the performances, Jacqueline Fernandez struggled to even deliver her lines correctly, with half of them sounding as mumbles. On the other hand, Naseeruddin Shah, was sadly underutilized and didn't get much to work with. Vijay Raaz, too, was just doing the same old stuff we've seen from him in previous films-no new ground broken here.Overall, Fateh starts off with a solid premise and some decent buildup, but it completely fizzles out in the second half. The action and forced humor couldn't save it. If you're looking for something fresh or even just well-executed, this one's pretty much avoidable.

reviews.title: A Gripping Action Thriller with a Strong Message
reviews.content: Fateh is an action thriller film that marks the directorial debut of Sonu Sood, who also stars in the lead role. The cast includes notable actors like Jacqueline Fernandez, Vijay Raaz, Naseeruddin Shah, and Dibyendu Bhattacharya. The story follows a former secret agent who, after leaving a covert agency that operates without any identification or records, settles into a quiet life running a dairy farm in a village. However, he soon finds himself drawn back into the dangerous world of cybercrime, where he takes on a powerful cyber mafia. The film features intense action sequences, including a breathtaking opening fight and a gripping climax, all set against a backdrop of real locations. With a compelling narrative that highlights the issues of online fraud and cybercrime, the film delivers a strong message without any romantic or comedic elements. I particularly enjoyed the character of Fateh, portrayed by Sonu Sood, who exhibits OCD, adding depth to his persona. The fight scenes are expertly choreographed, making it one of the standout action thrillers in Indian cinema. The movie carries vibes reminiscent of both John Wick and James Bond. Overall, Fateh is a must-watch, showcasing Sonu Sood's impressive directorial skills. While I believe he should continue to create more films like this, a sequel may not be necessary.

reviews.title: Remake of Equalizer
reviews.content: This movie serves as an intriguing Indian adaptation of The Equalizer, with an added layer of cultural depth that brings a fresh perspective to the original concept. The story is engaging and has been written thoughtfully, blending elements of action, drama, and subtle emotional undertones.Sonu Sood, stepping into the shoes of a lone vigilante, delivers a commendable performance. He perfectly captures the essence of a one-man army-a hero who stands tall against injustice. His portrayal is convincing, intense, and, at times, heartfelt. He brings his own charm and gravitas to the character, making it relatable to Indian audiences while maintaining the spirit of the original inspiration.However, I found myself wishing for a slightly faster-paced storyline. While the narrative is well-crafted, it could have benefitted from a tighter screenplay, especially in the first half. A bit more adrenaline-pumping action sequences, similar to those seen in the Equalizer series, would have elevated the experience. Given that the protagonist is set up as a larger-than-life action hero, the audience naturally expects high-octane action scenes, and while there are moments that deliver, they are somewhat sparse.The supporting cast does a decent job, but the focus firmly remains on Sonu Sood, and rightly so. The direction ensures the film's tone remains consistent, with a mix of suspense and grit, but a few scenes felt predictable. Despite this, the film keeps you hooked with its emotional core and moral dilemmas, something Indian cinema often excels at.One of the standout aspects is how the movie manages to weave in an Indian cultural essence, making it more than just a direct remake. The themes of community, family, and justice are deeply rooted in the Indian context, giving the film a distinct identity. This adaptation respects the source material while making it relevant to a new audience.The cinematography and background score deserve a special mention. They enhance the tension and atmosphere, adding weight to the protagonist's journey. The action choreography, while effective, could have been a bit more stylized to leave a lasting impact.The ending leaves room for a sequel, and I, for one, am eagerly anticipating the next chapter. With three installments in the Equalizer franchise, this Indian remake certainly has the potential to explore more. If a sequel is on the cards, I hope the makers will bring in more gripping action sequences and a slightly faster narrative pace to satisfy the audience's expectations.In conclusion, this film is a solid attempt at reimagining The Equalizer with an Indian twist. Sonu Sood shines in his role, and while there's room for improvement, it's an enjoyable watch for fans of action dramas. With the promise of a sequel, this could very well turn into a memorable franchise in Indian cinema.

reviews.title: Fateh: A Masterpiece of Action Cinema
reviews.content: "Fateh" sets a new benchmark in Bollywood action films with its flawless direction, gripping story, masterful screenplay, and breathtaking action sequences. From the first frame to the last, the film keeps you hooked, leaving no room for a pause. It's an exhilarating experience that pulls you in and doesn't let go until the end credits roll.The music score, crafted by the legendary Hans Zimmer, elevates "Fateh" to unparalleled heights. Known for his iconic compositions in classics like *The Last Samurai*, *Pirates of the Caribbean*, *The Dark Knight*, *Inception*, *Man of Steel*, and *Interstellar*, Zimmer brings his magic once again. His powerful score seamlessly blends emotion and intensity, amplifying every moment of the film and ensuring it resonates long after you leave the theater.With its stellar combination of edge-of-the-seat action, a compelling narrative, and Hans Zimmer's unforgettable music, *Fateh* is a cinematic spectacle that redefines the action genre in Bollywood. Don't miss this masterpiece!

reviews.content: FATEH is a film that takes a fairly good idea, but dumb it down due to simplistic execution. Thankfully, the film isn't selling itself on the strength of its story, as the focus is clearly on its brutal R-rated action. It's a good thing that the action delivers, although it too suffers from some minor issues like excessive use of shaky cam, firing limitless amount of bullets from a single gun, villains conveniently not having guns or not choosing to shoot from long distance when hero is unarmed etc. For a first timer director, Sonu Sood does an admiring job, and he excels physically too in the lead role as the mysterious assassin. While watching this film, I got reminded of BEEKEEPER. The best thing that I liked about this film is that right from the beginning, there were no dull moments, and even though the film turned farfetched in many parts, it remained engaging throughout.If the story was given a little more care, this could have turned into something really great. Alas! It wasn't meant to be.A big shoutout to Vijay Raaz, the man totally chewed the scenery whenever he was on the screen. Although I was very disappointed by Naseer Sahab; not sure what went wrong, but he wasn't even a tiny bit menacing as the main antagonist. Jacqueline is meh (as always), and the decision to make his relationship with Fateh as a romantic one was clearly a mistake.Overall, FATEH is a decent film that works due to its admirable idea and good action, although it would have worked even better had the screenplay been not so basic and improbable, and the core idea not so oversimplified.

reviews.title: The movie is a waste of time and money.
reviews.content: Review of FatehFateh is a film that arrives with considerable hype, but it quickly becomes apparent that it fails to deliver on almost every front. While its IMDb rating might suggest a decent or even exceptional experience, a closer look at the reviews reveals a pattern of suspiciously glowing feedback. The reality of watching the film, however, is a far cry from the ratings, leaving one to wonder if they are the result of an orchestrated effort to inflate its perceived quality.At its core, Fateh is a film without identity or direction. The plot is lackluster and uninspired, failing to grab the viewer's attention or provide any real stakes. Whatever premise the filmmakers were aiming for is poorly executed, with the story feeling more like an extended advertisement than a coherent narrative. It lacks depth, originality, and emotional resonance, leaving the audience disengaged throughout its runtime.The characters fare no better. From the protagonist to the supporting cast, no one stands out as memorable or compelling. The performances across the board are mediocre at best, with even the lead actor struggling to inject life into a script that offers no room for development or intrigue. Dialogues are stale and clich√©d, making it impossible to invest in the characters or their journey. Instead of portraying relatable or interesting figures, the film delivers flat caricatures that fail to evoke any empathy or interest.One of the most glaring issues with Fateh is how blatantly commercial it feels. Rather than focusing on crafting a meaningful story, the film constantly bombards the audience with product placements and promotional undertones. It's as if the filmmakers were more interested in turning the movie into a marketing tool than providing an entertaining experience. This overemphasis on commercial elements not only undermines the narrative but also alienates the audience, who are left feeling as though they've paid to watch a long advertisement.Visually, the film is equally disappointing. The cinematography is unremarkable, offering nothing that elevates the storytelling or adds to the viewing experience. Action sequences, which could have been a redeeming factor, are poorly choreographed and unimaginative. There is no sense of excitement or thrill in these scenes, which feel more like obligations than genuine attempts to engage the audience. Even the production design, which could have added some visual appeal, is generic and forgettable.The soundtrack, a vital component of any engaging film, is another area where Fateh falls short. The music is uninspiring, with songs that feel like they've been added as an afterthought rather than integral parts of the story. None of the tracks leave a lasting impression, and they fail to enhance the emotional or narrative beats of the film.The pacing is perhaps one of the most frustrating aspects of Fateh. At just over two hours, the film feels unnecessarily long, dragging from one uninspired scene to the next. There is no sense of urgency or momentum, with scenes lingering far longer than they should. This lack of tight editing and direction only adds to the overall sense of boredom and frustration.Another major issue with Fateh is its lack of clarity about its audience. The film tries to cater to multiple demographics but fails to resonate with any. It lacks a clear vision or purpose, resulting in a disjointed and incoherent experience. Instead of focusing on a single theme or genre, the film meanders aimlessly, leaving viewers confused and disengaged.In conclusion, Fateh is a movie that falls short in nearly every department. Its plot is uninspired, its characters are forgettable, and its execution is riddled with commercialism and lack of creativity. While its IMDb rating may suggest otherwise, the film offers little of value and feels more like a waste of time and money. If you're looking for an engaging or meaningful cinematic experience, Fateh is not the movie for you. Avoid it, and spend your time on something more worthwhile.

What starts like a slick James Bond movie turns out to be a maniac killing spree with pseudo-hightech projections. High on adrenaline but low on cyber logic & general usefulness to the public. That is what hooked me into the story. Then his junior joins the team and the relationship between them makes the premise even stronger as they share the same dream, the dream that Hibino had given up on.When Hibino becomes a kaiju himself (by questionable means) things get even more interesting.But the thing that surprised me most about this film is that it's very funny. I wasn't expecting it and it was a great surprise to have all the jokes peppered in, without taking away from the emotional arcs of the characters.And the characters do have arcs! reviews.title: Season 1 Compresses into a Movie
reviews.content: Kafka had given up on his dream of joining the defense force until a new colleague convinced him otherwise. Determined to catch up to his childhood friend, he sets out to achieve his goal while hiding his secret.This anime movie is the first season streamlined and compressed into a one-hour and fifty-minute runtime. The story is excellent, taking a fresh take on Kaijus. The anime has great action sequences, comedy, and a great cast of characters. The movie has a short sequence that is not part of season one and gives more time to the supporting cast but does not do much to change the story's trajectory. This movie is superb for those wanting to get into it. This movie will be an excellent refresher or boring for those who have already seen season one.

reviews.title: A Breath of Fresh Air in Comedy: A Review of Dhoom Dhaam
reviews.content: In a cinematic landscape often dominated by tired tropes and predictable punchlines, Dhoom Dhaam emerges as a delightful surprise, a refreshing dose of genuine humor that leaves you in stitches while also offering moments of heartwarming connection. This isn't your run-of-the-mill comedy; it's a film that dares to be quirky, to embrace the absurd, and to deliver jokes that you haven't heard a million times before.At the heart of this comedic gem lies the undeniable chemistry between Pratik Gandhi and Yami Gautam. Gandhi, known for his impeccable comic timing, shines in a role that seems tailor-made for him. He embodies his character with a perfect blend of naivety and wit, drawing laughs with every line and every exaggerated expression. Gautam, as always, is a force to be reckoned with. Her comedic prowess is on full display, and she effortlessly complements Gandhi's energy, creating a dynamic duo that crackles with on-screen magic.But what truly sets the film apart is its commitment to originality. The jokes are fresh, the situations are unexpected, and the humor is often delightfully offbeat. It's a film that doesn't rely on cheap gags or overused comedic devices. Instead, it finds humor in the everyday, in the awkwardness of human interactions, and in the absurdity of life itself.The film's strength also lies in its ability to balance the comedic with the heartfelt. Amidst the laughter, there are moments of genuine emotion, moments that resonate with the audience and add depth to the story. It's a reminder that even in the most hilarious situations, there's always a human element, a connection that transcends the laughter.The movie is an example to the power of original storytelling and the importance of taking risks in comedy. It's a film that proves that you don't have to rely on tired formulas to make people laugh. Sometimes, all it takes is a fresh perspective, a willingness to be different, and a cast that understands the nuances of comedic timing.In a world where comedy often feels stale and predictable, is a breath of fresh air. It's a reminder that laughter can be intelligent, that humor can be original, and that cinema can still surprise and delight us. This is the kind of film that deserves to be celebrated, the kind of film that leaves you wanting more.If you're looking for a comedy that will tickle your funny bone and leave you with a smile on your face, look no further than the film. It's a cinematic experience that's too good to miss, a refreshing reminder of the power of laughter, and a testament to the brilliance of its cast and creators.

reviews.title: A Thrilling Blend of Romance, Comedy, and Action"
reviews.content: "Dhoom Dhaam" is an entertaining mix of romance, comedy, and action, with outstanding performances by Yami Gautam and Pratik Gandhi. The story takes an exciting turn when a newlywed couple's wedding night turns into an unexpected adventure due to mistaken identity. Yami impresses with her strong, confident character, while Pratik's transition from a timid husband to an unlikely hero adds charm. The screenplay is crisp, with well-timed humor and thrilling twists. The cinematography and background score enhance the film's appeal. Overall, "Dhoom Dhaam" is a refreshing and engaging watch, perfect for those who enjoy fast-paced romantic thrillers.

reviews.title: What a mess!!
reviews.content: "Dhoom Dhaam" (2025) aspires to be a high-octane blend of action and comedy but falters due to its derivative nature and lackluster execution.The film's narrative-a newlywed couple entangled in a chaotic adventure on their wedding night-feels like a rehash of numerous Western rom-com action flicks. Instead of offering a fresh perspective, it recycles familiar tropes without adding any unique flair, making the storyline predictable and uninspired. The attempts to emulate the style and substance of successful Western movies come across as desperate and unconvincing, lacking the cultural nuance and originality that could have set it apart.Yami Gautam Dhar and Pratik Gandhi, both talented actors, struggle to breathe life into their poorly sketched characters. Their on-screen chemistry is tepid, and their performances are marred by over-the-top expressions and forced humor that seldom lands. Director Rishab Seth fails to harness the potential of his cast, delivering a film that lacks cohesive vision and depth. The pacing is uneven, and the comedic elements feel contrived, further detracting from the overall experience.The screenplay is riddled with dialogues that attempt to be witty but end up being cringeworthy. A notable example is a monologue delivered by Yami Gautam's character, intended to address societal issues, which feels out of place and disrupts the narrative flow. Such instances highlight the film's struggle to balance humor with meaningful commentary, resulting in awkward and unengaging scenes."Dhoom Dhaam" is a lackluster attempt at recreating the charm of Western action-comedies within a Bollywood framework. Its reliance on clich√©d plot devices, uninspired performances, and misguided direction culminate in a forgettable cinematic experience. The film serves as a reminder that successful storytelling requires more than mimicking established formulas; it demands originality, cultural authenticity, and a genuine connection with the audience.

reviews.title: A Refreshing Blend of Comedy, Action & Thrill
reviews.content: Dhoom Dhaam (2025) is an action-comedy that follows Veer Khurana (Pratik Gandhi) and Koyal Chadda (Yami Gautam), a mismatched couple who enter into an arranged marriage. On their wedding night, a case of mistaken identity forces them to go on the run, leading to a series of thrilling and humorous escapades as they search for the mysterious "Charlie."The film offers a fresh take on the action-comedy genre, steering away from typical Bollywood formulas. The screenplay is tight, ensuring there's never a dull moment. Yami Gautam and Pratik Gandhi deliver commendable performances, adding authenticity and charm to their roles. The humor is well-placed, making the film an entertaining watch without feeling forced.The cinematography and visuals are top-notch, capturing the essence of the story beautifully. The background score and songs complement the film well, though the music isn't its strongest suit. However, the overall execution makes up for it. If you're looking for a Bollywood movie that feels new and exciting rather than repetitive, Dhoom Dhaam is a must-watch. It's a perfect blend of comedy, action, and emotion, making it a complete entertainer.

The emphasis on how difficult life is for women and that is why it is ok for them to lie to their partners did not really make a lot of sense. The film begins with Koyal and Veer (Pratik Gandhi) who get have an arranged marriage without really knowing each other. On their wedding night they are accosted in their hotel room by two henchmen looking for "Charlie" which we later find out is an object. The rest of the film follows them evading the henchman while trying to locate Charlie.Acting:
The acting is fine but nothing special. Yami Gautum puts in a very capable performance byt Pratik Gandhi was not very convincing. Overall it was fine for this sort of a role.Conclusion:
There is a space for female led action movies but the hard handed way this film was handled was frankly silly. This was more of an agenda fueled movie rather than trying to tell an authentic story. Would give this one a miss, it isn't really worth your time and there is a lot of better content out there.4/10.

reviews.title: A deporable Celebration of Infidelity
reviews.content: Once again, Hollywood indulges in a dangerous trend by glorifying adulterous behavior and normalizing wayward characters. This film is nothing more than the latest installment in a long line of movies that trivialize betrayal and the real-life consequences of broken trust. Instead of offering a thoughtful exploration of complex relationships, it panders to a shallow, hedonistic impulse that undermines the values of commitment and integrity.The narrative not only misleads impressionable viewers-especially teenagers and those lacking maturity-but also contributes to a broader cultural erosion where deceit is celebrated as a form of rebellion. Rather than inspiring audiences with nuanced, responsible storytelling, this film reduces serious moral dilemmas to mere entertainment fodder, packaged for maximum commercial appeal at the expense of substance and decency.It is disheartening to see cinema, which has the power to shape societal norms, being used to promote such damaging ideals. This movie is a disgrace to both the art of filmmaking and to society at large.

reviews.title: An unpredictable lot of fun
reviews.content: I saw this pop up on Netflix and it looked like it might be fun.I'm really glad I watched it - it IS a lot of fun. Best described as an action/romance, the married couple of an arranged marriage have their first night together go very wrong when people come to their hotel room door and demand - with menace - "something" that they have no idea what is.They spend the next 24-hours escaping bad guys, breaking their stereotypes...of each other...getting to the bottom of the problem and more importantly getting to know each other, finally, and falling for each other.I don't watch many Indian films (so, sorry if I'm ignorant of mega stars here) but it seemed way less predictable than the normal "Hollywood" films that have been heavily promoted on Netflix - the main characters weren't cardboard cutouts, and the lead actress managed to squeeze in an awesome feminist speech too while leading the action too. It was a sweet film that I smiled my way through.It's not a work of art, but you'll not regret watching it and having fun in the process.

reviews.title: An entertaining cocktail of comedy, action, music and romance
reviews.content: If you are looking for some entertainment where you can settle down with popcorn and enjoy for sometime then you won't be disappointed. Yami Gautam and Pratik Gandhi play a newly married couple who get the shock of their lives on their wedding night when two goons break into their home and desperately threaten to shoot them while asking for the whereabouts of "Charlie". The couple promptly escapes and then starts the roller coaster run chase at night through the town. Both Yami playing Koyal and Pratik playing Veer are opposites in every sense. He is a phobia filled Gujarati vet ( I am a vegetarian, I can't eat my patients!). She is a full blooded fiesty Pujabi girl who gulps whiskey and shoots with enthusiasm. Together they make a terrific quirky couple.Director Rishab Seth fills the movie with an engrossing cocktail of comedy, action, slapstick, romance, music more than enough to keep you entertained. There are twists and turns with shady cops, a botched up robbery, kidnapping, a mysterious pen drive, unfaithful boyfriend etc etc all happening in a wild ride at a crazy pace at night. These misadventures are all presented in a humorous vein and it is light hearted fun all the way. The sitcom has lots of suspense filled action with surprises. Both actors have fully immersed themselves in their cranky roles. ( Watch Yami delivering the monologue and belting out expletives and Pratik doing the pole dance among other amusing scenes.)

reviews.title: Whacky, fun and entertaining but don't try and poke holes in the story and you'll enjoy it
reviews.content: Comedy is often the most difficult genre, apart from horror, to tackle. Many directors have their own styles of delivering the best comedic offering.Rishab Seth has done a great job with this light hearted offering which is high on comedic moments and he is ably supported by a great cast and apt writing.The movie is not complex or deliver nuances or twists or thrills of any kind. But in a way, that is the key to the success of the movie as it is a no frills delivery which succeeds in all it sets out to do.Yami is the star here with a spot on performance which highlights why she is probably one of the most under rated actresses. Her comedic timing, spot on dialogue delivery and overall presence drive the movie and it's story line.Pratik Gandhi is probably the weak link not because he is not capable but somehow not in the same league as Yami when it comes to the demands of the role. He has no doubt delivered a par performance but maybe a better actor in the comedy arena, would have made it a more complete package.The support cast has little to do in most scenes but the overall combo is wrapped up perfectly and makes for a viewing experience which is fun, fast paced and exciting. There are a lit of people who step in an out in different scenes and each does their part perfectly. Key mentions -- Prateik Babbar, Eijaz Khan.The movie does not really have any dull moments and is a laugh riot. Definitely not to be missed.

reviews.title: Mind refresh movie
reviews.content: Pratik Gandhi and Yami Gautam, two actors known for their captivating screen presence, deliver thoroughly entertaining performances in this refreshing and comedic film. Their on-screen chemistry is palpable, and their comedic timing is impeccable, making for a truly enjoyable cinematic experience. The film itself offers a welcome respite from the everyday, providing a much-needed escape and a chance to unwind and have a good laugh. It's the perfect antidote to a stressful day or week. If you're looking for a feel-good movie that will leave you smiling and help you clear your mind, this one is definitely worth checking out. Fans of both Gandhi and Gautam will find plenty to appreciate, as they both seem to be having a blast in their roles. The plot, while light and breezy, offers enough twists and turns to keep you engaged, and the supporting cast adds to the overall charm of the film. It's not just a comedy; it's a feel-good movie with heart, and a perfect choice for a relaxing evening.

reviews.title: Same things time and time again!

Please bring some originality for cinema's sake!

reviews.title: Best clean comedy movie of the year.
reviews.content: Excellent movie with lot of humour. Clean comedy movie. I would say best Sitcom movie of the year. I would have loved it to watch it in theatre. Kudos to director for presenting it so clean. No vulgar. Now a days, it's very difficult to find a comedy show or movie without vulgarity but this movie succeeds without vulgarity. Kudos on that part. This is for the people who loves clean comedy with new taste. Nobody would have expected such a movie in recent times.

reviews.title: Unnecessary plot
