reviews.title: Disappointing mess - couldn't tolerate beyond 30 mins
reviews.content: "This movie doesn't even deserve a single star. The writing is filled with absurd choices-calling a pen drive 'Charlie' for no reason, leaving a gun on a hotel room floor while running away from goons, and making characters act unbelievably foolish just to create artificial tension. My last watched scene was outside the club, where the protagonist rants about feminism which was forced and out of place. While I appreciate the effort that goes into making a film, a bad movie is simply a bad movie. Weak storytelling, poor character decisions, and exaggerated performances make this one a frustrating watch."

reviews.title: One time watch but should watch

However, the real standout in this film was Yami Gautam, who delivered a superb performance. She portrayed her character beautifully.So, grab some popcorn and enjoy it over the weekend. reviews.title: Must watch full on comedy love this movie
reviews.content: If you're looking for a film that guarantees laughter, entertainment, and a great time, Dhoom Dham is the perfect pick! From the very first scene, this movie grabs your attention and takes you on a rollercoaster ride of fun, humor, and brilliant performances.What sets Dhoom Dham apart is its flawless blend of comedy, engaging moments, and an energetic vibe that keeps you entertained throughout. There's never a dull moment-each scene is packed with humor, and the movie delivers on its promise of pure entertainment.Performances That Steal the ShowThe film boasts a stellar cast, and every actor has delivered an incredible performance. Each character feels natural, and the chemistry between the actors adds to the overall charm of the movie.The lead actors shine with their impeccable comic timing, expressive dialogues, and engaging screen presence. Their interactions are fun to watch, and they bring out the humor effortlessly. The supporting cast is just as impressive, adding an extra layer of comedy and making every moment even more entertaining.It's refreshing to see actors who don't just act but completely immerse themselves in their roles. Their expressions, delivery, and body language make the humor even more enjoyable.Comedy That Hits the Right SpotThe biggest strength of Dhoom Dham is its humor. The jokes are well-written, the timing is perfect, and there are plenty of laugh-out-loud moments that will leave you in stitches. The film doesn't rely on forced or over-the-top comedy.

reviews.title: An entertaining wild ride!

reviews.title: "Comedy That Will Hold Your Laughter"? Accurate. In the Sense of "Hostage Situation."
reviews.content: Three stars for "Dhoom Dhaam"? Aap ki marzi! Bless your generous soul. The original review claims "comedy that will hold your laughter throughout movie." And in a way, they're not wrong. Your laughter will be held. Hostage. Giraftar, bound and gagged in the trunk of a car driven by a clown who's never taken a driving lesson. This film operates on a plane of logic aisi waisi nahin, so advanced, so utterly detached from earthly reason, that aap hairan ho jaoge if the writers even briefly glanced at a script before filming. Things "happening out of nowhere"? Honey, in "Dhoom Dhaam," sab kuch happens out of nowhere. Characters materialize from the hawa, plot points sprout like rogue mushrooms after a barsaat, and the laws of physics are treated as mere mazak for overly cautious filmmakers. ** janab! The crucial negotiation scene where the villain reveals his evil plan. His earth-shattering monologue? "The thingamajig will... uh... do the... you know... the thing! Unless... maybe... hmm... bananas!" Qasam se! That's actual dialogue. And the hero's brilliant counter-move? He just... leaves. Chala jata hai! No fight, no witty retort, just ambles off screen. Kya aqal mandi hai! Genius.** If you're deeply committed to experiencing cinema in its purest, most unfiltered, and gloriously nonsensical form, then "Dhoom Dhaam" is... well, it's kuch tou hai. Just maybe lower your expectations to zameen se bhi neeche first.

reviews.title: A Fun One-Time Watch with Good Performances & Simple Humor
reviews.content:
Dhoom Dham is a lighthearted comedy that delivers a fun and engaging experience for a casual movie night. The film keeps things simple yet effective, with humor that doesn't feel forced and a well-paced narrative.What Works:
Strong Performances: Yami Gautam and Pratik Gandhi are well-suited for their roles, bringing charm and depth to their characters. The supporting cast also does a great job.Simple Yet Enjoyable Humor: The comedy is subtle and natural, making it an easy watch.Story Build-Up & Twists: The flashback sequences and narrative flow keep the movie engaging without unnecessary distractions.What Could Have Been Better:

reviews.title: A good Indian comedy after a long time.
reviews.content: Dhoom Dhaam is a delightful action-comedy that masterfully blends humor, romance, and thrills. The film follows the unconventional journey of Veer Khurana and Koyal Chadda, portrayed by Pratik Gandhi and Yami Gautam, respectively, as they navigate an arranged marriage that takes unexpected turns. Their on-screen chemistry brings depth to their characters, making their adventures both engaging and heartwarming. Director Rishab Seth infuses the narrative with a unique quirkiness, delivering fresh and unpredictable humor that sets the film apart from typical comedies. The storyline is both absurd and endearing, keeping audiences entertained throughout. Overall, "Dhoom Dhaam" is a refreshing cinematic experience that offers a perfect blend of laughter, action, and romance. Must watch for the fans of Dhamaal, Bol Bachchan and the likes.

reviews.title: Yami Gautam Shines Bright in a Delightful Blend of Charm and Comedy"

Pratik Gandhi, with his impeccable comic timing and expressive acting, complements Yami perfectly, making their scenes together an absolute delight to watch.Overall, itw is an enjoyable watch, thanks to its strong performances, particularly by Yami Gautam and Pratik Gandhi, and its entertaining mix of suspense and comedy. While the second half may not surprise you, the film's humor and chemistry between the leads make it a worthwhile experience. If you're looking for a light-hearted yet gripping movie, this one's definitely worth a watch.

reviews.title: An Entertaining Ride
reviews.content: "Dhoom Dhaam" (2025) is a quirky and entertaining action-comedy that takes you on a wild ride through the streets of Mumbai. This film, while not without its flaws, offers a refreshing take on the genre with its unconventional characters and unpredictable plot.The film follows the chaotic wedding night of Veer and Koyal, a mismatched couple who find themselves entangled in a series of hilarious and thrilling escapades. Yami Gautam Dhar delivers a captivating performance as Koyal, a feisty and independent woman who breaks free from societal expectations. Pratik Gandhi is equally charming as Veer, a timid and phobic man who gets swept up in the whirlwind of events.The film's narrative is fast-paced and unpredictable, keeping you guessing with its twists and turns. The humor is quirky and often laugh-out-loud funny, with the lead actors' comedic timing perfectly complementing each other. The action sequences, while not overly stylized, are well-executed and add to the film's overall entertainment value.While the film's plot may not be groundbreaking, its unconventional characters and refreshing approach to storytelling make it a standout. The film's exploration of gender dynamics and societal expectations adds a layer of depth to the narrative, while its lighthearted tone and comedic elements make it an enjoyable watch for audiences of all ages.Overall, "Dhoom Dhaam" is a fun and entertaining film that offers a refreshing take on the action-comedy genre. Its captivating performances, quirky humor, and unpredictable plot make it a worthwhile watch for those seeking a lighthearted and engaging cinematic experience.

It's worth a watch.

reviews.title: The Witcher series' writers did it again, and it isn't a compliment.
reviews.content: I understand the reservations people have with The Witcher: Nightmare of the Wolf - which I really liked, but that isn't the case -, but this production is by far a worst production than that animation. I wish I could brush it off by saying "what else could you expect from the same two writers that also wrote the Netflix series?" however this was proved wrong with the before mentioned animation, also written by one of the writers of the show - even though Beau DeMayo wrote another great show in the X-Men '97 adaptation - or maybe he is an exception and it is not wrong to assume that re-hiring writers from the Netflix series is a bad idea.However, something is clear, even for the people that have not read the books, you can clearly tell what comes from the books (Sword of Destiny) and what was adapted from Netflix writers. There is even this part from the books that shows how witty Essi in their investigation, but she was robbed to create a "cool scene".Overall, this adaptation of the short story "A Little Sacrifice" does way more harm than Vesemir's prequel did.As a side note, why is the voice acting from Essi so weird?

reviews.title: Netflix still doesn't understand what Witcher is even about
reviews.content: As books and games fan I have to say. Netflix still doesn't understand what Witcher is even about. They made it another Hollywood movie with lot's of fights and very little amount of dialogue. Everything that made the short story so emotional and beautiful in the book is gone here. Also, for the most part I was just bored and that's because Geralt is so overpowered here. He literally has all human-sized monsters on one hit. He killed at least 30 of the vodniks. We simply aren't worried for the main characters. As its own thing this is just another generic animated movie with a generic plot. As a Witcher adaptation, it's just poor.

reviews.title: Definitely worth the wait
reviews.content: This was so good. I will admit I have never read the books, but this animated film stays true to both the Netflix show and the games. It's definitely better than "Blood Origin", and I would even go so far as to say better than "Nightmare of the Wolf". If you're a Witcher fan, you'll enjoy this. It was kind of cool how they tied the song Ciri sings in the show to what Jaskier sings at the end of this movie, and ties it all together. I'm a fan of watching Geralt throwing Witcher signs left and right like he does in the games, and you see that more here than the regular show. Plus it was good to hear Doug Cockle voicing Geralt.

reviews.title: Story's not the best but still good
reviews.content: I like the idea of an animated Witcher series I feel there's an element to animation you don't get from the live action and it was nice to hear Geralts voice actor (from the game) being brought back for his character. Overall the movie was okay I felt it was a bit rushed but still overall quite refreshing and brought that feel of adventure like how the first season of the live action Witcher series felt. If your watching it hoping it's gonna be a story from the books it most likely isn't but if you like the Witcher you'll most likely find enjoyment from this short movie it's nice to see Geralts character back in action since the 3rd season and upcoming season of the live action series felt dull and boring.

reviews.title: Disappointed..
reviews.content: To be honest, I feel disappointed... I was waiting for this movie for months, hoping for something that would truly capture the essence of The Witcher, but it turned out to be mediocre at best.The Japanese anime style, -excessive backflips and triple flips especially- just doesn't feel like our Geralt.Another issue for me was the blonde girl's voice acting. She spoke way too fast and mumbled at times.That said, the return of Doug Cockle as Geralt's voice was a highlight. Hearing the iconic voice from the games brought some nostalgia and familiarity, but unfortunately, it wasn't enough to save the movie.

reviews.title: I will never forgive Netflix for ruining my favorite Witcher Story
reviews.content: I admit, I am biased. Spoiled by the excellent writing and story of the books, I expect more and more from the series. Not everything has to be perfect, or even royal. But it HAS TO captivate the same soul.It has to....This show does not.I am furious, how they decapitated the story. It had love, determination, conflict, understanding, regret.. This is the story I recommend to my friends if I want them to get into the Witcher universe or even fantasy fiction. I don't remember how many times I've read that story from the books, and cried.I love crying, when it is over beauty. Yes, drama can be art.This one isn't.It is silly, unprofessional, absurd, shallow, ugly and most importantly, soulless.I can understand what you did to the show.I can understand why you did a silly spin-off.But this animation is like drawing a mustache to Mona Lisa.

reviews.title: Another great addition to the Witcher franchise
reviews.content:
The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep (2025) is another animated spin-off of the Witcher (2019-) and it was another fantastic anime movie.Positives for The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep (2025):
The movie's animation looks fantastic. The voice acting from the cast are all very good. The way how the Sirens are brought into this movie was amazing. The action sequences are very good. And finally, the movie has amazing pacing.Negatives for The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep (2025):
The story wasn't always very compelling. I'm also on a bit of downer with the Witcher franchise. And finally, the movie doesn't do anything that I found to be amazing.Overall, The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep (2025) is a step in the right direction for this franchise after The Witcher Season 3 and Blood Origin, but I still need something for the franchise to win me back on their side.

reviews.title: Missable
reviews.content: Some laughable storytelling choices, including one that the writers had the nerve to play like a twist ending despite it being as inevitable as the rising sun. Voice acting does have a "pulled off the street" quality for some of the characters, but the performers from the Witcher show and the video games do a pretty good job.Also, this is Netflix Witcher so you know going into it that Geralt is the 3rd or 4th lead. But for those who are unaware of how Netflix has managed this franchise, that's worth keeping in mind.The action is actually pretty slick, although the last sequence tends to drag on a bit.Altogether, this is a totally missable offering unless animated gore really gets you out of bed in the morning.

reviews.title: It's ok but deviates from the source material
reviews.content: As a fan of the books I was curious to see how they were going to do this story. I didn't look much into it except that I knew the voice actor who voices Geralt in the Witcher 3 game was coming back for this. Yes, there are parallels to the little mermaid but in the world of the witcher. But the changes made to the story from the books were more of a distraction for me and made it difficult to enjoy. Perhaps those who haven't read the books will get more enjoyment.The animation style was fun and allowed for more acrobatic fight scenes. But adding a sea witch who turns into a kraken was a little too Little Mermaid. And of course, they couldn't stop with just that change. Adding characters that don't exist in the book, changing characters from the books roll and the outcome of the whole story was too much and yet still somehow predictable.

reviews.title: Good animation , great voice acting , horrible story
reviews.content: The writers of The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep missed the point that in The Witcher world, there is no true (good) only evil or the lesser evil. A happy ending where the real bad guy dies at the end doesn't fit-this is not a Disney story.In addition, the story was not that good or solid. The games had side quests that were better than this, especially if you don't want to use the books' material. They could have at least created an original plot that lived up to the franchise's standards. Instead, what we got felt weak and uninspired.My rating is 5/10. Doug Cockle and Joey did a great job. The fight scenes were excellent-I really enjoyed them.The story is a disappointment.

reviews.title: A good addition to the Witcher series
reviews.content: There were several hit and misses when it comes to the Witcher series. With Henry Cavill departing from the series the future of the series looked uncertain. Eventhough there were many entries that attempted to capture true essence of the Witcher story line none were successful. Witcher season 3 was lackluster addition to the series. The Witcher blood origin is mess without any purpose.However, Sirens of the deep is a step towards the correct path. It might not be the best in the series but it is a worth contender. The Witcher wild hunt voice actor has returned to provide his signature voice to Geralt which is a highlight through of the movie. Combined with some good looking action scenes, the Sirens of the deep manages provide passable piace of entertainment.

reviews.title: Little Mermaid in the Witcher universe, and it's Sapkowski's fault
reviews.content: If you are watching this and are disappointed by the story, watching what is basically The Little Mermaid, but with the Witcher thrown in, plus some other characters that bring nothing to the table, blame Sapkowski and his short story A Little Sacrifice. Almost everything, except the saccharine ending, comes from there.But to be fair, making a full feature film from a short story, animating it like it's Castlevania and changing the mood and ending to feel so much like a Disney story it's totally Netflix's fault. Hey, but at least they did something based on original material, right?Poles, don't kill me, but the books were not good and everybody who actually loves The Witcher outside Poland does it because they liked the games. To prove my point, The Witcher: Nightmare of the Wolf was way better than this.

reviews.title: Watchable
reviews.content: I am a fan of the character so my review is a bit biased. That is I enjoy following Gerald's adventures in any medium (played the games and watched Netflix series and Nightmares of Wolves. As much as I enjoyed this one, it is clearly not on par with the rest. And how could it, when the stori draws heavily from "little mermaid"?Uninspired story, paper thin characters but stunning and beautifully choreographed action scenes. To the producers, pls fire the writers. For God's sake, who in their mind would have humans attack mermaids commanding great white sharks and more, on ships in the sea, when all the latter should do is sink the ships? And yet it happens...

reviews.title: Way, way, WAY better than Nightmare of the Wolf
reviews.content: I didn't care much for Nightmare of the Wolf. But this? This actually felt like a big quest one could be playing in Witcher 3.I can totally see it. A quest called "the little mermaid".Really good. Much better than expected. I know they get a lot of criticism for not staying true to the books. (Haven't read them). However I have been immersed in Witcher 3 several times throughout the years and it's been 450 hours in total.I find this film to be balanced between the existing and elaborate universe and being creative and free with it.I love Anya as Yennefer. Always have, always will. Anya is better at Yennefering than Yennefer from the witcher 3 in my humble opinion.Using THE Geralt voice actor from the games? The cheapest points ever scored, but that's the BEST choice and that simple fact is maybe worth 4 stars alone.I love the little hint in the end of where we are in the storyline and that reference to the live action show.There was also a little Disney moment where I felt like I was watching the little mermaid.Overall. I really enjoyed it. Would watch again.

reviews.title: Decent animation
reviews.content: Comparing to recent Witcher works, this one's more coherent and complete. Not that it really follows the original (which it doesn't), but it doesn't follow it in a sequential way - meaning that it's reasonably straightforward in its choices.Voice acting is good too, it's nice to hear the Witcher game voice again. And animation quality is quite decent as well - though not entirely, some scenes feel like 3D models were thrown in just to fill the space. Didn't look great at those moment's but otherwise good.Overall it's a decent animation following a short story in the Witcher story. Not great, but not bad either.

reviews.title: Poor Writing and a Flaky Understanding of The Witcher
reviews.content: I had high hopes for this. Thinking back on the damage they've done to The Witcher IP, this was naive. I re-read the short story that gives the movie its inspiration, and found myself, again, in awe of Sapokski's writing and characterization. In my opinion, it's one of Sapkowski's best short stories. Now, I don't want to be one of those people who harps on about an adaptation not being faithful to the original, but Netflix had so much to work with here. Sapkowski's writing is full of nuance and depth and pathos - everything this adaptation is lacking. The movie goes for cheap, surface-level fantasy action and vandalizes the unique creative depth and character-work that makes Sapkowski's writing, at its best, exceptional. At its best, Netflix has been able to capture some of this - I think back to Renfri from the first episode of The Witcher. But in large part, Netflix has failed to capture what makes the IP special. This is just the latest example.

reviews.title: The voice actor from the Witcher games carried this
reviews.content: I haven't read the books, but I've watched anything Witcher related out there and I'm a big fan of the games. Although the fighting scenes with Geralt are perfect and entertaining, I feel like the entire thing lacked the emotion I'm used to with the games. The music in the background was barely audible, which took away a lot of the tension and feeling it usually creates. What you can hear the most is the sword slashing and voice acting (including breathing and whatnot), or other times just complete silence (which is usually used to create a certain atmosphere) that seems out of place. The story is pretty predictable and too much Little Mermaid like. The reasoning behind the characters' actions is too simple, in a way that makes you think "that's all there is to it?".I think it had potential to be something good, even with the story being written as it was, if the rest of it managed to pull your heart into it by creating that Witcher feel. As it stands, it felt a bit disconnected or lacking at times. It was kinda boring because it completely missed the mark to be honest...

reviews.title: Exccentric
reviews.content: Look, I'm a casual Witcher fan, and for the first third of this movie this plays out like a usual Witcher film/game/series/book/whatever. Geralt is stoic and principled, Jaskier is the comic relief (with an admitely sympathetic backstory here), there's a random love interest and there's plenty of gore, but then half-way through it hits you with a musical number and I'm like, what?This movie is quite self indulgence in its quite stereotypical plot of humans vs mermaids, down to the aforementioned Disney reference, and I'm not quite sure if that's a good or bad thing.If you're looking for a Witcher story being unconventional, this might hook you up.

reviews.title: O Siren you've bewitched me.
reviews.content: A lovely animated feature. They added a lot more to the original story which is understanding for the medium they were adapting, and I actually think it works really well. The animation was engaging and the voice acting really well done (maybe except for one unfortunate character). It was lovely to see Anya and Joey as their animated selves, and Doug brought a gorgeous depth to Geralt's performance. It was lovely to see Geralt who's more mature emotionally, and who visibly cares more about his interpersonal relationships. The emotional beats between the new characters were great, and hit very well for me, I especially enjoyed the themes of family vs chosen family. The dialogue was sometimes a tad too modern for my liking, but otherwise it's a great animated film and a lovely way to pass the time, will definitely be rewatching!

reviews.title: The worst mistakes on repeat
reviews.content: I had such high hopes for this and feel like I was taken for a ride. I wished I had checked who the writers were before starting to watch, I wouldn't have bothered. This has everything that made me hate the last season of The Witcher on Netflix and made me stop watching after ep3. The dialogue is horrendous, predictable, and plain embarrassing. But the worst, and I cannot stress this enough, the absolute worst thing in the movie, is Jaskier. And to add insult to injury, voiced by the same actor as the series. I fail to understand why these people think that this quippy character is funny. He's not funny and I detest every single line and moment he's in a scene. He's the comic relief that's completely unnecessary and his modernisms just take me right out of it. And the singing...Oh God, it's just so awful, it literally put me in a bad mood. Having just watched Castlevania Nocturne, I was very disappointed by the animation, as well. At times, it looked like a 90s Disney animated film and that's just a shame. Clearly, Netflix and the team who's in charge of this IP have learned absolutely NOTHING from the backlash after the last season and it's a shame because getting the original voice actor from the games was a welcome surprise but after the first fight, the movie goes quickly downhill and it's soooooo bad that we turned it off around the 50 min mark. If I never hear Jaskier or see his character ever again, it'll still be too soon.

reviews.title: I'm in too deep
reviews.content: Like many fans, I've been missing *The Witcher* since Henry Cavill's departure, so I was eager to see what this animated film had to offer.Having not read the books-especially the one this film is based on-I approached it with an open mind. The story revolves around a classic forbidden romance: a prince and a mermaid, caught in a love that their families vehemently oppose. Meanwhile, a string of mysterious deaths raises the stakes, and Geralt is hired by the king to put an end to the romance while uncovering the truth behind the killings.The voice cast is impressive, featuring familiar names from the live-action series such as Anya Chalotra (Yennefer) and Joey Batey (Jaskier). Additionally, Doug Cockle, the iconic voice of Geralt from *The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt*, lends his talents here, alongside the talented Emily Carey as Sh'eenaz.Visually, the animation is fluid and well-crafted, capturing the dark, gritty essence of *The Witcher* universe. The storyline feels authentic to the franchise, balancing action, humor, and an intriguing mystery. While I did predict the twist before the reveal, it didn't take away from my enjoyment.Overall, this is an engaging and well-executed addition to *The Witcher* franchise. I only hope that the upcoming live-action series can match the quality of this animated film.

reviews.title: Stop using cat potion as a super strength serum
reviews.content:
I am a fan of the witcher books and the games,I tried to watch this show with an open mind but so many issues kept cropping up it made the movie unwatchable for me.Cat potion should not be treated as some super strength serum and Aard should not be able to pull you only push.You need to stick to the source material if you want witcher fans to watch it.but on a sidenote
Having a animated show about the witcher is a nice idea.it becomes easier to execute than a movie especially the monsters.Just better writing please,these mistakes are so silly and easily rectified but to a witcher fan it's annoying to see.You have a gold mine here in story but it's poorly executed
Anyway avoid this if you a witcher fan.

reviews.title: Stunning Action, But Geralt Deserved More Spotlight
reviews.content: "The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep" offers a visually captivating journey into Geralt of Rivia's world, with animation that fluidly brings to life the treacherous beauty of its maritime settings. The action sequences are particularly noteworthy, delivering intense and dynamic combat that showcases the animators' prowess. However, the narrative often diverts its focus towards secondary characters and subplots, which dilutes the depth of Geralt's character development. This dispersion of attention leaves a desire for a more Geralt-centric storyline that delves deeper into his complexities. Nevertheless, the film's exploration of moral ambiguities and its rich, atmospheric design contribute to an engaging, albeit somewhat unbalanced, addition to the Witcher saga.

reviews.title: Better adaptation than the show
reviews.content: This movie adapts one of my favorite stories from the books and treats it more reverence than the show ever has tried, the writers show they know the source material and lovingly brought us the story of Geralts other great love and one of the best adaptations of the little mermaid story outside of the Disney animated movie. I hope Netflix continues with the anime adaptations and skips a season 4 or 5 of the show now that cavil has departed I'd love to see them adapt more of geralts solo adventures separate from his search for Ciri and her training into being a Witcher. If they make more of these hopefully they bring Sapkowski in to write them.

reviews.title: It does the job, but it could have given more.
reviews.content: A new film from the saga of the most famous wizard currently.Focused on a story from the second book "The Sword of Destiny" and with a return to the somewhat darker tale of "The Little Mermaid".Chronologically it is set between chapters 5 and 6 of the first season given the mentions made in it.Personally I liked it, no more than "The Wolf's Nightmare" from 2021 but I think the vast majority of the changes with respect to the short story are a success.Perhaps many fans will not like this but we must assume that this could be a good path to take in future installments: adapting short stories to this format.At times there is abuse of CGI in the fights, which are quite bloody by the way.However, I think it is quite successful to change the story of the lovers and show how the human being is more selfish than anything as demonstrated by the king losing his two sons.I think the musical moment was also quite unnecessary.Beyond that, and in general terms, it is a solid movie, with good animation and very epic fights.

reviews.title: So disappointed initially, then it improved
reviews.content: I understand that this is based on an actual Witcher story, but when it became essentially a facsimile of The Little Mermaid I totally lost interest. The flashbacks were boring and seemed superfluous and I can't say that I really loved the animation thus far. I'm sure some people disagree, but I really loved the Nightmare of the Wolf. I found it very original, beautiful and really engaging to watch. It's pretty sad to see what Netflix has done to the whole Witcher franchise after the success of the first season. While it is admirable that they decided to choose some true source material as a vehicle for this movie, I think we're all just a little burnt out on the Little Mermaid.theme. They are even singing as she's making the potion to transform her into a human. This is where I stopped it, and I was moderately enjoying it up to this point. I would have greatly appreciated seeing something less familiar to me as a vehicle for another Witcher iteration.Update: upon finishing this in his entirety I definitely liked it a bit more. Again, I definitely did not find it as engaging as I did nightmare of the wolf, but in the end it was enjoyable overall.

reviews.title: I cried.
reviews.content: I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who is a fan of human x mermaid romance. There were scenes in this movie that made me cry tears of happiness because those scenes have only ever appeared in my head.No other mermaid fantasy movie or short video showed me scenes like the ones in this movie.I've always loved mermaids and dreamed of being with one. The scenes in this movie described that fantasy perfectly.At the very least, if you're a mermaid lover, like me, some of the scenes in this movie will make you smile at the LEAST!Note: The paragraph at the top is also something I posted on most of the trailers for this movie on YouTube.

reviews.title: A great short story that has been completely changed
reviews.content: When I saw this was based off of the short story, A Little Sacrifice, I had to temper my expectations. This short story, from the book Sword of Destiny, is one of my favorites of all the short stories. The story is touching, funny, and touched on a lot of different subjects. Geralt is hired by Agloval to serve as a translator to speak with a Merwoman he is in love with. Along the way, Geralt and Dandelion meet up with Esi, a female bard. The sexual tension between her and Geralt in the story is well written. But in this anime movie, they've completely made Esi different from what she was in the short story. Instead, she is more of the aggressor, as well as knowing how to fight, can interpret, and apparently is from the town this takes place in, as well as having family. In the short story, she actually wasn't from the town, didn't know the prince, and just seems to be someone that knows everything. These changes affects her interaction with Geralt in a negative way in this story. And adding so much back story with Esi and Dandelion and the prince and his brother, as well as tying this movie to the live-action Netflix series is something else I didn't really like. So many characters have been changed from what they were, as well as so many added back stories that I feel detract from the relationship that Dandelion and Esi have in the short story. And adding a "sea witch" and other aspects that were there just ruins the story for me. I just wish they could have stuck more to the story as it was written, but then this is Netflix, so why am I surprised? A perfectly well written story in the book that could have been told pretty faithfully, but they had to insert messages that weren't there, change characters from what they were, has pretty much ruined this story for me. I only give a 4 stars because of Doug Cockle voicing Geralt. Hearing Geralt as he was in the games was excellent. Doug knows Geralt as he has voiced him through three games. Just wish they would have stuck to the lore of the story more faithfully.

reviews.title: Misses the mark
reviews.content: This animation adaption of the Witcher misses the mark. Geralt is used primarily as a side character in this movie, than the main protagonist. Indeed he is there front and center when it comes time for action scenes otherwise he is a casual bystander. From a storyline standpoint, it is extremely predictable, lacking any real suspense. The voice acting for the most part is flat making each scene just "meh.". The movie is watchable but it certainly isn't memorable. Have writers lost any semblance of creativity ? As for the animation itself? Given today's technology, the animation is mediocre. I had hoped for more for an addition to the Witcher franchise.

reviews.title: Terrible story, voice acting is alright except the girl boss
reviews.content: Christina wren's English accent is just dreadful. It's like she's just watched Oliver Twist over again to try and capture a cockney accent but butchers it completely. Why they didn't just hire someone with an English accent is beyond me.Storyline is boring.Action is good.Besides Wren, voice acting is good. Interesting to get a bit of background on dandelion. Don't know why they made him a giant pussy though.There's some mad similarities to this story and the little mermaid which is hilarious.I can't tell you how bad the accent is. It's literally making me want to lower my rating more.

reviews.title: Doug Cockle really is the 1 true Geralt of Rivia
reviews.content: Look it ... it really doesn't matter about the story or the script. Fans want the voice. Fans want the game. Fans only ever want to hear Doug Cockle's gravel pit growl.The eye candy of self confessed super fan Henry Cavill (pardon the pun) was never the right physical choice but he owned for sure. But with Geralt ... there really is no getting away from that most critical trait.... The voice.Now this animation won't break new ground at all but any adaptation of Witcher stories will always resonate. The games are great. Witcher 3 : The Wild Hunt is knocking on the door of perfection and if they adapted that into a miniseries we'd all be better off!As you can tell Im a bit biased - but if you love Geralt... you 'll love this because Doug's involved.

reviews.title: Weightless
reviews.content: I guess Japanese animation has spoiled me. And Arcane, too. This one felt very cheap to me. The mouths' animation felt especially so with just very quick closing and opening, which did even try to match the spoken words. Japanese know that their anime may get dubs, and still do animate properly. Arcane has several dubs, last time I checked - still animated lips properly.But it's not just lips-syncing. Even the very first fight felt... Meh. It felt like it did not have weight. I know that Geralt from books is supposed to be an acrobat, and I am definitely not expecting him to feel as "heavy" as Batman from Arkham games trilogy, but this one felt more like Spider-Man, and his strikes looked very light. You can find videos explaining what makes a good fight in animation, and they all basically lean to the same thing: "weight". They may call it slightly differently, but essentially it's the feeling of impact from each strike, even when there is none (opponent is just too strong). Or the "danger" of the fight.Maybe it gets better, but 15 minutes or so were enough for me. I am giving it 1 extra start just for proper Geralt's voice.

reviews.title: A Deceptive and Lazy Adaptation - "The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep"
reviews.content: "The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep" Fails to Capture the Spirit of Its Origins It's no surprise that Henry Cavill isn't involved in this latest Witcher project. The fingerprints of Lauren Schmidt Hissrich's influence on the franchise are impossible to ignore, and it's clear that the lackluster approach to this adaptation follows a troubling pattern seen in other recent franchise revivals: a blatant disregard for the source material and the use of an established fan base as a vehicle for mediocrity. Rather than taking the time to create a meaningful, original story set in the Witcher universe, the creators of Sirens of the Deep have resorted to the common tactic of purchasing a beloved franchise, not to honor it, but to milk it for its existing appeal. It's become a predictable, frustrating trend: writers and creators latch onto an established intellectual property (IP) and fail to put in the work necessary to develop something worthwhile, instead opting to lean on the existing fan loyalty to carry the weight of their subpar creation. This is, quite frankly, an insult to both the legacy of the franchise and its audience. What's even more egregious, however, is the degree to which the creators of Sirens of the Deep have simply plagiarized aspects of another beloved story-The Little Mermaid-with all the subtlety of a hammer to the face. The parallels are so glaringly obvious that it's difficult to understand how this wasn't a conscious, deliberate decision. Characters, plot beats, and key story elements are lifted straight from the classic tale, with no attempt to disguise the parallels. It's a lazy and uninspired adaptation, relying on tired tropes instead of creating something fresh within the rich, complex world that Sapkowski's Witcher novels and the games have built. The lack of originality here is staggering. In a world where creatives are constantly urged to innovate, it's disheartening to see such a transparent attempt to cut corners, relying on a tired rehash of a well-known story that most viewers will recognize immediately. If you are familiar with The Little Mermaid, it's practically impossible to ignore the parallels-and that's not a compliment. This isn't just a missed opportunity-it's a betrayal of the Witcher universe and a disservice to its fans. Conclusion: The Witcher: Sirens of the Deep doesn't just fail to capture the essence of the original material-it actively undermines it. Instead of offering a thoughtful, engaging story, it relies on tired, uninspired tropes that have been recycled from other sources. The creators' failure to put any meaningful effort into honoring the franchise is only amplified by their lack of originality and blatant plagiarism. It's a disappointing addition to the Witcher legacy, and frankly, it deserves to be called out for what it is.. a disgraceful pathetic waste. PS. I created this account today only for the purposes of leaving this review.

reviews.title: Boxes are Ticked
reviews.content:
Let's discuss the animation. It sucked. Stick figures in faded pastel coloures.Let's discuss the story. It was ok, but not I triguing
The game had better stories in the side quests.Let's discuss the voice actors. It was awesome to see Doug Cockle as Geralt again he was brilliant as usual.Yet Anya Chalotra who had only 4 speaking lines was credited first.......hmmmmm.? Everyone else was ok except the kings son, Agloval. He sounded like he was struggling to speak English. But he was needed to tick a box.Let's talk about the characters. They sucked too. The king had surely had to search that city thoroughly to find the only one of her kind so that they could produce what was needed to tick the box. You'll see what this means.Let's talk about the content. Except for Essie the other females had to be drawn with almost no features especially the mermaids. Unlike the games and tb series, there is no nudity in this one as it is sure to upset us and offend us that beautiful people can exist. We were saved and baptized from.this corruption.Good thing they hid this offensive sexual material behind all the cutting and slashing and bloodletting.This is indeed a let down for the true gamers and readers who were hyped for Witcher content. I really hope they don't make another one.Curiously I also see the score is locked at the time of writing.

reviews.title: mcdonaldization of the witcher and completely misunderstanding of source material
reviews.content: A complete distortion of the original, turning it into a story meant for everyone-meaning for no one. Yet another tale in the vein of The Little Mermaid, even though Sapkowski originally wrote it as a critique of clich√© fantasy tropes. The lack of nuance stripped the story of its depth-particularly in the relationship between Essi and Geralt, which was meant to explore shades of gray. Instead, the creators opted for a black-and-white narrative that completely hollowed out the emotional weight of the original. The only real positive is the animation of the fight scenes, though at times they feel more flashy than truly impactful.

reviews.title: Good first half, disappointing Second Half
reviews.content: This is a prime example of a show that gets a lot of things right and overall is an above average product, however due to the poor track record of some of the people involved, it gets dragged down in the mud.Yes, the second season of Witcher was an absolute mess riddled with many flaws, however, that failure should not reflect onto this show. This show does a much better job of staying FAITHFUL to the source material and takes a lot of positive inspiration from the video game. They even got many of the original video game voice actor , who reprise their roles and nail the setting of this movie perfectly.The weakest part of the movie comes in form of the final half, where logic goes out of the window and Geralt for some reason refuses to use 90% of his arsenal during battle. I honestly feel like an entirely different writing team handled the climax scenes and failed MISERABLY.Visually it is nothing special, but the aesthetic is true to the source and really makes you feel like you are back in the game.The movie is not a masterpiece, but give it a chance, it is a much better watch than the live action TV show, or at least better than what the TV show later became.

reviews.title: Poor Witcher
reviews.content: Something has happened to the Witcher. Somewhere along the way, he has become a side character.Story: It's not well developed but is serviceable.Characters: As mentioned, somehow the focus is no longer on our hero - where it should always be - and it's not even on recurring characters important to our hero. This was a major error.Animation: Passable but clearly on a very limited budget. Had the story been very good, this would have been easily forgivable.Sound/Music/Voice: Low quality. The voice actors aren't very good, unfortunately. There's not much emoting, if any.Verdict: Unless you're a die-hard Witcher fan, this anime is not worth your time. I gave six stars, mostly for nostalgia.

reviews.title: Fantastic
reviews.content: Any witcher book fan knows a little sacrifice is a fan favourite of all the short stories so this one has been highly anticipated! I actually didn't mind the changes to give jaskier more backstory and make the ending less tragic and heartbreaking. The animation was beautifully done just like nightmare of the wolf. Loved anya, joey and doug's return to their respective roles and so glad to see percival from the game soundtrack working on the witcher netflix universe again! This would've been a 10/10 if not for the god awful voice acting for essi, that accent work was a right mess and sounding like a parody-mocking accent you'd hear on a bad snl sketch.

reviews.title: Action, Romance, Comedy
reviews.content: Ya I am going to admit that it was a little slow for me in the beginning. But so the movie kept going I really liked it. And also I am a sucker for romance. The Witcher might not be able to have a happy ending for his life story but it felt really good to see the prince make his choice and choosing love in the end of the story. This movie had a not only humor but it was also a little bit of a musical where other characters had a bring in a song or two. I know Henry Cavill left as the Witcher but the actor who did the vice in this movie did a really good job in this movie. I hope him and Netflix will collab in future projects.

reviews.title: Little mermaid??
reviews.content: At first I thought, awesome! But after the sea witch scene with singing. It turned into the little mermaid for me.And after that it didn't feel original anymore or awesome.A mermaid and a human fell in love.The potion to be human and the war between spieces. The way the king used everything for personal gain. The way he worked with the seawitch as a human.And geralt being the hero and the rest just stand and watch. He keeps trying to make things better but people keep telling him no or giving him other orders.When he is seeing the real threat from miles away.Lets hope things in the future will be better.

reviews.title: It just kept getting better
reviews.content: Near-perfect movie. The writing was immaculate, the songs were mindblowing. At the start of the movie I saw some harshly animated shots, and was afraid that this was gonna be the worst piece of Netflix's The Witcher adaptation series, but I was happily surprised to see that the animation picked up and during the fights nearing the end I instantly replayed couple scenes of Geralt fighting the kraken-witch.It has to be said that Geralt in this movie is the most powerful version of Geralt in any form of media. He does triple spins, jumps incredibly high, does not die from fall damage like in the video games, and his signs (the small, basic magic witchers use) are incredibly powerful. His IQ seems to have also increased, as the Geralt in this movie uses his signs really creatively. Anyone giving this movie a rating below 7/10 is just a dumb hater, who cannot separate their hate of Netflix. This movie is a must-watch for anyone. It contains the true spirit of The Witcher world with brutality, deep discussions and life philosophy, hot women, the bard cracking silly jokes and most importantly, badass monster killing and detective work. I am excited for more.

reviews.title: Its alright... bit boring really
reviews.content: Voice acting is good... animation is alright... it's just a very boring story and overly childish. It could be a side story of "insert any superhero" on a little mermaid adventure. It doesn't feel 'Witcher'. Right now, I'm trying to watch it again - maybe it'll hold my attention - but there's a bit too much PG-13 "Japanime", like the scene where the bar keep takes the chicken leg from Jaskier, or the young Jaskier scenes by the lake. I wanted Witcher, not My Hero Acadmia... I keep expecting one of them to get red cheeks and throw a V sign whilst being embarrassed about dropping some food or something. Wasted effort really.

reviews.title: pretty but insultingly stupid
reviews.content: I've kinda lost interest in netflix main Witcher experience - but was curious for about animated movie (after not half bad previous one and exceptional cyberpunk edgerunners). But what I've got is a mess story wise - not going to main spoilers but some of the details are ... hard to imagine that adult human wrote them.For example:main love interest is between man and a mermaid (and it's spilled out clumsily in like first 10 minutes of the movie so light spoiler) ...and it turns out that that protagonist can't talk to each other ... at all... due to a language barrier (but other characters, Geralt and random bard included, know the umm.. "mermglish" so it's not out of reach to learn it)... how they fell in love, who knows, will it be resolved later ... absolutely not.the war part ... god damn... creators wanted battles, so they figured out that best way for humans to fight mere-people (beings living strictly underwater) is on ships... on the ocean... with swords and arrows, and, best of all, absolutely without magic. So you go to location 100% in favor of your enemy, using weapons that won't affect them in water, without a way to defend ship from ... bottom (best of all movie shows how this would basically end in first 15 minutes), fighting with an enemy highly skilled in magic (which humans knew) using melee. Story twists and bends to accommodate for this stupidity but fails miserably. Who the hell came with this stupid idea ??Geralts motivations are... odd at best, inconsequencial at worst. Sometimes fighting humans (without good reason) sometimes monsters (with better reasons.. ) in "same-ish" circumstances.All in all - all of the spectacle, nice animations, Doug Cockle reprisng Geralt, fall short due to brain rotted screenplay for this disappointing movie.And adding insult to injruy, all of the new songs (especially "Little mermaid" inspired and implemented totally out of character for Melusine) suck terribly, same as voice acting of the cast of main show (they really seem to struggle with this form of acting).

reviews.title: When talentlessness is passed off as talent!
reviews.content: In short, it's a parody of "Aquaman" and all Japanese anime, about a flying dude with a sword, which for some reason was called "The Witcher", although I think many people have already read the books and should remember what was in the original, and what we were offered to watch... It's like, you're waiting for your ordered steak in a restaurant, and they bring you a piece of raw, rotten meat with worms, which the chef calls a delicacy, well, that's how he sees it. The plot is twisted, some unnecessary new characters, unnecessary events were invented, but those that were fundamental and created the essence of the story written in the book were thrown out. I won't spoil it. Just read the book, it will be more useful for both the mind and the senses. And to those who say, "-well, this is an adaptation", I'll say then adapt something else and don't spoil the good things.I understand that Netflix executives, like rams, will run into a thick concrete wall and think that this will destroy it. They ruined the series, the prequel to it, and now the cartoon. What kind of "talent" must you have to ruin everything like that, instead of earning a couple of billions on it. I especially want to mention Lauren Schmidt-Hissrich, a talentless, ambitious person who "has her own vision". I think a lot of fans have already mentioned "not evil" and "kind" words to everyone involved in this nonsense, as well as wishes of "good health" and "prosperity."

reviews.title: Please do not malign source materials to push an agenda
reviews.content: Netflix, you want to market your show to an existing fanbase of classic works. Great! But then at least have the respect to not change it to the point that it's unrecognizable. When the characters only look the same, but are entirely different people with very different values and behaviors, what you've done is create a new story. That new story no longer deserves to carry the original's name.This pattern of Netflix shows is shameful and reprehensible false marketing. And it's not just the Witcher. It's simply tricking the fanbase into remaining subscribed.Honestly, its high time writers stopped selling absolute rights over their work, for people like Lauren Hissrich to tarnish it. They should maintain veto power over the brand name of their creation.

reviews.title: LOT'S OF FAULTS BUT, ITS STILL A FILM WORTH SEEING!
reviews.content: Although I enjoyed the film it was not up to the standard of the Witcher live action films etc. The fight scenes with monsters were in too close and therefore spoilt; especially with all the gymnastics Geralt was doing. The story was not the best and you think at times, that its not a Witcher story. The vocals were frequently mumbled (something that is abundant in far too many films these day's) and, really...really annoying!Colours were quite faded looking when they should have been vibrant and, the clarity/detail was poor; though neither spoilt the ability to view it.Although I personally enjoyed my viewing of it, I personally did not feel it had a strong enough Wither feel about it. So I tend to agree with much of what has been said in other viewers reviews.

reviews.title: Rubbish
reviews.content: Imagine the Little Mermaid with blood. When the songs started I turned it off. Expected more from this movie but was sorely disappointed. Seriously Netflix you had a great live action show and have now ruined it with this animation. When the mermaid was offered an elixir to give her legs by the obvious villain I wondered how long it would be before Disney launched a lawsuit against Netflix. Up until that point I was in two minds about how I felt watching it as it had some semblance of a decent story. The only thing missing was Aquaman turning up to save the day. If you have a couple of hours to fill then go and watch some paint dry....it'll be more fun.

reviews.title: Very Poorly Written and Executed
reviews.content: Voice acting often times didnt even align with the facial expressions depicted on screen.I had to pause to come look if I was tripping, nope, the issues that stand out are glaring.The female lead's voice actress did a terrible job, she often sounded like she was rambling off in song, just skip through her scenes, you'll pick up on it.This animated film is pale in comparison to the previous one. I don't know if they knew where they wanted to take this one, we have serious mature and even explicit tones and then bam, a disney singy song like huhNot good. They wrote this based on their cliff notes on the Original Story.

reviews.title: So disappointed by this that I've downloaded the IMDB app to write a review
reviews.content: Netflix needs to give up. Give The Witcher to someone that actually understands and knows what to do. This film is an abomination.It would be bad enough standing on its own merit. The voice acting of Little Eye was horrible enough to make me want to turn it off early. Why ask an American voice actress to do a common English accent? Surely just get someone who understands the region or dialect? At the very least hire a decent actress, this is maybe the worst voice acting performance I've ever experienced. Honestly I'd almost recommend watching this film purely to laugh at this disaster.Sirens of the Deep becomes that much worse when you consider how wonderfully written the original story is written. This film takes perhaps my favourite Witcher short story and massacres it.Why do they hire people with egos so big that they feel as though they have to change things so drastically? They did the same thing with the show. Take an award winning, widely loved book series, and then shit all over it.What an embarrassment.I will mention the two good things in this film. Dandelion, sorry Jaskier, has great banter with Geralt and manages to capture their relationship well. And Geralt's fighting style was well animated and looked similar to how it is portrayed in the books, if a little too over the top.

reviews.title: Nothing standout, but it has its moments
reviews.content: This is a very average movie with some scenes that are pretty decent, but for the most part it is entirely forgettable. The story isn't particularly engaging. It is full of typical tropes with typical villains. Much of it can be described as, "good enough". There is also a weird musical number out of nowhere that felt incredibly out of place and very Disney. I don't dislike the film overall, but halfway through found myself losing interest. No strong feelings one way or the other.The combat is just slightly above par. There are a few good fights, but Geralt does too many flips and downward attacks. None of it conveys impact or significance, and gives the impression of choreography rehearsal. Included are also some twists and turns befitting a Witcher story, but much of it feels artificial. Like they were trying for this specific thing the Witcher is known for and you can tell. Honestly, the best part is Geralt being himself, and his interactions with Essi. Outside of Jaskier (who is exactly as you expect him to be), Essi is the only character worth paying attention to, and unsurprisingly one that ultimately justified the time spent watching. But even then, her best scenes come at the end.Recommended for casual fans only.

reviews.title: TOTAL UPGRADE FOR INDONESIAN HORROR CINEMA
reviews.content: Qodrat 2 has successfully become one of the best religious horror action films that doesn't just rely on monotonous scenes merely to "sell religion." Instead, it delivers a total upgrade in cinematography and sound design, improved direction, grand action choreography, outstanding performances, and an absolutely terrifying opening and ending execution.Vino G. Bastian & Acha Septriasa deliver mesmerizing performances, keeping the audience glued to the screen from start to finish. Although the plot remains simple and doesn't undergo significant innovation, its narrative exploration deserves praise for successfully opening the gates to the 'Qodrat Universe'-which has the potential to become one of the most ambitious horror universes ever created.A GROUNDBREAKING AND UNFORGETTABLE EXPERIENCE.90/100.

reviews.title: The sequel gets even more exciting
reviews.content: The sequel is even more exciting. Not only from the action that always fascinates, but also the test of faith that gives goosebumps when watching it. The acting is top-notch.The action is quite intense but also interspersed with humor that provokes laughter. Ustadz Qodrat's search efforts are faced with quite heavy obstacles. The fight against evil forces is even more powerful. The terror that is presented is increasingly widespread. It emphasizes that the devil is relentless in misleading humans. There are scenes that make me wince. Appreciation for all the extras and new characters that appear in this sequel.The romance made me smile to myself. Accompanied by "Akulah Lelakimu" from The Dance Company & Pongki Barata and the wind blowing, it momentarily eases the tension before the next threat hits.My favorite part is in the last quarter. Assuala's threat becomes more real. Seeing her face close up on such a big screen made me want to close my eyes but I finally saw it. Appreciation also goes to the make-up team. The test of faith experienced by Ustadz Qodrat and Azizah really gave me goosebumps. It's like a reminder that only to God we worship, only to God we will return. This movie is also a reminder that as long as this breath blows, humans are still given the opportunity to repent.In that part, Acha Septriasa's acting is really crazy. Every word she says to her character is heartfelt and meaningful. The effort to appreciate what she reads is really cool. Watching it was speechless.

reviews.title: What a Awesome Sequel
reviews.content:
Qodrat 2, the highly anticipated sequel to the first Qodrat I
absolutely loved deep in my heart, has taken audiences by
storm with its captivating storyline and impressive visuals. The film builds upon the success of the original, delivering a bigger, bolder, and more intense cinematic experience,
Viewers are treated to two different perspectives, showcasing the journey of one character to strengthen faith and another's struggle to maintain it. This exploration of faith and relationships adds depth to the narrative. One of the most striking aspects of Qodrat 2 is its masterful use of sound, music, and visuals. Director Charles Gozali expertly crafts action sequences that keep audiences engaged and on the edge of their seats. The performances of Vino G. Bastian and Acha Septriasa are particularly noteworthy, with Acha commanding the screen with a mind-blowing portrayal, The film successfully balances humor and emotion, creating a well-rounded viewing experience. While the film excels in many aspects, some viewers may find the final act to be slightly underwhelming. Expectations for a grand finale maybe fully met, but the overall impact of the film remains powerful and significant. The opening sequence immediately sets a tense and unsettling tone, drawing viewers into the story from the start. Qodrat 2 proves to be a worthy sequel that expands upon the original while maintaining its core essence. The possibility of a larger franchise is hinted at, thanks to the film's solid storyline and engaging characters Despite some nit picky drawbacks, the overall experience is a religious one, leaving audiences with a sense of awe and anticipation. Stay for the post-credit scene to fully immerse yourself in this cinematic journey.

reviews.title: Love qodrat 2 so much
reviews.content: "Qadrat 2" stands as a testament to the power of cinematic storytelling, a film that resonates deeply through its meticulously crafted narrative, compelling performances, and striking visual presentation. The film's ability to captivate and engage stems from its commitment to delivering a holistic cinematic experience, where each element works in harmony to elevate the overall impact.The narrative of "Qadrat 2" is its cornerstone, a carefully constructed web of intrigue and emotional depth. The pacing is expertly managed, ensuring that the tension builds steadily, drawing the viewer deeper into the story's complexities. The narrative's depth invites reflection, prompting audiences to engage with the film's themes on a deeper level. This intricate storytelling distinguishes "Qadrat 2" as more than just a genre piece; it's a work of art that demands attention and thoughtful consideration.Complementing the compelling narrative are the exceptional performances delivered by the cast. Each actor embodies their character with remarkable authenticity, bringing a palpable sense of realism to the screen. The emotional range displayed is impressive, conveying the characters' inner turmoil and external conflicts with genuine conviction. The chemistry between the actors is palpable, enhancing the dynamics of the relationships portrayed and contributing to the overall impact of the narrative. The nuanced performances elevate the film, transforming it from a simple sequence of events into a deeply human experience. The actors' dedication to their craft is evident in every scene, contributing significantly to the film's emotional resonance and critical acclaim.Furthermore, "Qadrat 2" excels in its cinematic execution. The film's visual language is both striking and evocative, employing a range of techniques to enhance the storytelling. The cinematography is masterful, capturing the essence of each scene with precision and artistry. The use of lighting, composition, and camera movement creates a visually immersive experience that draws the viewer into the world of the film. The production design and art direction are equally impressive, creating a rich and believable environment that enhances the narrative's authenticity. The film's sound design is also noteworthy, contributing to the atmosphere and emotional impact of the scenes. The seamless integration of visual and auditory elements demonstrates a keen understanding of cinematic language, resulting in a cohesive and compelling viewing experience.The film's direction is also worthy of praise, demonstrating a clear vision and a meticulous attention to detail. The director's ability to balance the narrative's complexity with the visual and emotional elements is commendable. The film's thematic depth is handled with sensitivity and intelligence, inviting viewers to contemplate the deeper meanings embedded within the story. The director's skillful guidance allows the actors to shine, ensuring that each performance contributes to the overall impact of the film.In essence, "Qadrat 2" is a cinematic triumph. Its harmonious blend of a well-crafted story, powerful acting, and impressive cinematic execution makes it a must-watch for any discerning film enthusiast. The film's ability to evoke emotion, stimulate thought, and leave a lasting impression is a testament to its quality. It is a film that deserves to be seen and appreciated, offering a rich and rewarding cinematic experience that will resonate with audiences long after they leave the theater. The film's success lies in its ability to connect with audiences on multiple levels, offering both entertainment and intellectual stimulation. "Qadrat 2" is a film that demands to be experienced, a testament to the power of cinema to move and inspire.

reviews.title: Qodrat is different from other Indonesian horror films
reviews.content:
The storyline is very good, different from other Indonesian horror films, lots of jump scares. Very worthy of appreciation.Storyline: good.Acting: good.Film shooting : good.Story density: good enough (should be denser and more intense).Exorcism character: good enough (could be strengthened, like John Constantine).Criticism is in the section:
1) Sugar factory scene, the story should be more condensed.2) During the exorcism scene, it should be made more straightforward and powerful.Hopefully the sequel will be better.Hopefully it will be an inspiration for Indonesian horror films in the future.

reviews.title: More intense action and exorcism than the previously film
reviews.content: Qodrat 2 offers significant improvements in production quality, featuring more dynamic visuals, haunting sound design, and mature technical details. Action scenes are smoother with light comedic touches, even though the final battle lacks climactic and slow paced for some viewers.The story expands by exploring the Qodrat family's background through Azizah, the wife, adding psychological depth and stronger relationship dynamics. Azizah plays a more active role, moving beyond the typical victim trope.Horror elements are enhanced through the terrifying design of the ghost "Assuala," tension-building lighting, and immersive scenes like mass possessions and 360-degree shots.Overall, the film is a more mature and immersive sequel.

reviews.title: Two 45 min episodes
reviews.content: The first half featured Char's alternate timeliness story, but he disappeared in the second half so we focus on another group of characters. Great story but felt like an abrupt finish with no post credit scene. Excellent animation and exciting battles. It's too bad that this story doesn't appear to be cannon for the original U. C. timline but true fans are used to that being the case since the late 90s. The mecha redesign has a Recongista look about it, and some of the characters are very colorful and expressive. I look forward to watching the series whenever it comes out. The pacing between scene was pretty fast so keep your eyes peeled, worth a rewatch in the theaters.

reviews.title: Might be for diehard fans
reviews.content: After the war between Zeon and the Earth Federation, a Zeon captain and his Gundam disappear. Years later, a Gundam resembling the captain's is seen outside a space colony. Zeon dispatches a prototype Gundam to chase it down, ultimately leading to the mysterious Gundam disappearing and the prototype being lost. Both Gundams end up in an underground battle operated by mysterious pilots.This Gundam movie is hit or miss, depending on the viewer. The animation style changes halfway through, which is confusing. The story is slow, mainly about the war and the captain, and has little to do with the new part. With a runtime of one hour and twenty-one minutes, there are a decent number of mobile suit battles. It is excellent for the series and franchise fans, but it might not be worth it for newbies and novices.

reviews.title: Mobile Suit Gundam GQuuuuuuX - Beginning
reviews.content: This is an amalgam of four episodes that depict the end of the war between the breakaway "Zeon" and the "Earth Federation" some years after much of mankind had taken to living in cities located throughout the solar system. That war is touch and go, verging on stalemate, when the audacious "Char" manages to steal a prototype mobile suit (think "Pacific Rim") and turn it on their designers. It's a battle royal that ensues but as that concludes the enigmatic young "Char" disappears. The second part of the story skips on a few years as the search for "Char" and his suit has still to bear fruit, but a feisty young girl is the one to beat as she takes to her new "Gundam" suit only to find she seems to have natural powers to augment it's formidable capabilities. What's going on with her and where is the redoubtable champion? Well we don't find any of that out here, as this is just the start of the series, but what we do have works well enough as a stand alone adventure. The first section was my favourite, with much more intergalactic action, battles and combat going on. The second part reverted a little to the more traditionally frat-based team contest which attracts a bit less, but there's still plenty going on and it teases the rest of the story encouragingly. It's short and sweet and worth a watch.

reviews.title: Not good from a movie perspective.
reviews.content: I don't like it. It feels more like a web series than a proper movie. The pacing, the storytelling, and the overall execution make it seem like an episodic show rather than a theatrical film. A movie should feel grand, immersive, and emotionally gripping, but this one lacks that depth. The structure feels broken into segments as if it were designed for an OTT release rather than a cinematic experience. The way the scenes are arranged, the transitions, and the overall flow just scream web series rather than a movie. It doesn't have the impact, scale, or artistic depth that a theater-worthy film should have. Instead, it feels small, contained, and more suited for home viewing. This isn't a movie meant for the big screen; it belongs on a streaming platform where episodic content thrives. The entire execution lacks the cinematic brilliance that makes a movie truly memorable.

reviews.title: A Heartfelt Story Better Suited for OTT
reviews.content: Daagi, led by Afran Nisho, delivers a touching storyline and some solid performances-especially from Nisho himself, who brings depth and sincerity to his role. The emotional core of the film is definitely there, and the story has the potential to resonate with many.However, despite its strengths, Daagi falls short in terms of overall production quality and cinematic impact. It lacks the visual and technical polish expected from a theatrical release. Watching it in a theatre didn't deliver the experience I was hoping for; it felt more like a made-for-OTT film.This one would have been much better appreciated on a streaming platform, where its emotional depth could shine without the expectation of a big-screen spectacle.

reviews.title: Review of Daagi (2024) - A Disappointing Thriller
reviews.content: Review of Daagi (2024) - A Disappointing ThrillerAfran Nisho's much-anticipated film Daagi promised an intense thriller but ultimately failed to deliver anything memorable. While the marketing built hype around a gripping storyline, the execution felt sluggish, predictable, and underwhelming.One of the biggest letdowns was the screenplay. The story had potential, but it was riddled with clich√©s and forced twists that felt more confusing than thrilling. Instead of keeping viewers on the edge of their seats, Daagi dragged through unnecessary subplots and weak character development.Afran Nisho's performance was another mixed bag. While he has proven his acting skills in dramas, his portrayal in Daagi felt overdone at times and completely flat in others. The emotional depth needed for the character was missing, making it hard to connect with his journey. The supporting cast also struggled, with many performances feeling either exaggerated or lifeless.The direction and cinematography were also underwhelming. The film tried to create a dark, intense atmosphere, but poor pacing and inconsistent editing killed any tension it built. The action sequences lacked impact, and the background score, instead of enhancing the experience, often felt mismatched and overused.Overall, Daagi fails to live up to expectations. It's a forgettable thriller that neither excites nor leaves a lasting impression. With a tighter script and better execution, this could have been a strong entry in Afran Nisho's film career, but unfortunately, it falls short in almost every way.Rating: 2/10.

reviews.title: Awesome Making
reviews.content: A great film is often defined by its screenplay, and Dagi excels in this aspect. The script is well-written, ensuring that every scene has meaning and relevance. The dialogues are impactful, blending natural conversation with profound statements that linger in the audience's mind.The film also effectively uses silence as a storytelling tool, allowing emotions to be conveyed without the need for excessive dialogue. This adds a layer of depth to the characters and makes their experiences more relatable. The balance between intense, dramatic moments and lighter, heartfelt interactions creates a well-rounded cinematic experience.

reviews.title: Best movie of the yearüòä
reviews.content:
I am totally satisfied by watching this movie daagi. Specifically Afran nisho acting was amazing at this movie. It's totally I mean absolutelly worth it. Everyone should watch that movie I think ‚úÖDaagi is not just a movie; it's an experience that lingers in the heart long after the credits roll. Directed by the visionary Shihab Shaheen, this film brings together an emotionally charged story, breathtaking cinematography, and a stellar performance from none other than the legendary Afran Nisho.Afran Nisho is a name that resonates with excellence. A true craftsman of emotions, a versatile genius, and an icon of Bangladeshi cinema, he once again proves why he is in a league of his own. His portrayal of Nishan, a man burdened by his past and seeking redemption, is nothing short of phenomenal. Every expression, every pause, and every dialogue he delivers carries weight, making the audience feel deeply connected to his journey.Alongside him, the talented Tama Mirza shines as Zerin, bringing a refreshing charm to the screen. Their chemistry is beautifully showcased in the mesmerizing song "Ektukhani Mon," sung by Tahsan Khan and Masha Islam-a song that has already become a fan favorite.With a power-packed supporting cast, including Sunerah Binte Kamal, Shahiduzzaman Selim, Gazi Rakayet, and Mili Bashar, Daagi stands tall as a cinematic gem. The film is produced by SVF, Alpha-i Entertainment Limited, and Chorki, further ensuring top-notch production value.The cinematography captures every emotion with precision, the background score enhances every moment, and the screenplay grips you till the very end. Daagi is more than just a film; it's a poetic journey of love, loss, and redemption, woven together with the magic of Afran Nisho's brilliance.Final Verdict:
Daagi is not just the best movie of the year-it's a benchmark in Bangladeshi cinema. A film that will be remembered for years to come, thanks to the sheer dedication of a legend like Afran Nisho. If you watch one movie this year, let it be Daagi. This is cinema at its finest.

reviews.title: A true masterpiece from Afran Nisho (The Boss)
reviews.content: Daagi is more than just a film-it's an unforgettable experience. From its captivating cinematography to its deeply emotional storytelling, every element is crafted with precision. The screenplay, music, and direction blend seamlessly, creating a visually stunning and emotionally resonant journey. Afran Nisho delivers a phenomenal performance, bringing incredible depth and realism to his character. His presence on screen is magnetic, making every scene impactful. This isn't just a movie; it's a work of art that stays with you long after the credits roll. A must-watch for true cinema lovers!Review by Fahim.

reviews.title: This doesn't fit into any movie category, it's a drama.

Zach is a Sheriff in a small town that gets robbed by Scott and friends on motorcycles. Billy plays a US Marshal that has been in hot pursuit of Scott, because when Scott robbed a different bank, he killed 7 deputies, including some of Billy's friends. Billy teams up with Zach and they track down Cara, Scott's girlfriend and set a trap for Scott. Scott is warned off by Cara and goes to Trace, a friend that offers some of his own men to help Scott kill the cops and get Cara back. There are lots of gun battles and fisticuffs and Scott gets to show off his fighting skills-if you are unfamiliar with Scott, he is a pretty good martial artist-and there are a few plot twists. There is a scene just as the end credits start but nothing at the very end.It's rated R for violence, grisly images, language and sexual content-no nudity-and has a running time of 1 hour & 46 minutes.I liked it more than I thought I would and I would buy it on DVD.
